Refreshing your memory by that document; you said if you had the document you could tell, have you any doubt that in the month of January, 1855, you were called upon by William Palmer to attest another proposal upon his brother's life for 13,000l. in another office? A. If you will give me the paper, perhaps I can tell you—this is my signature to it—the body seeins to have been filled up by Mr. Palmer—I might have signed it in blank—I cannot swear that I did or did not—I nave some doubt whether I did not sign several of those in blank—the body is in William Palmer's writing.

Q. Do not trifle, sir, with the Court, and with the jury, and myself; upon your oath, looking at that document, do not you know that William Palmer applied to you to attest a proposal upon his brother's life for 13,000l. in January in that office? A. He did apply to me for a proposal in some offices in January—one was for 13,000l.—I might be applied to to attest another for a like sum in the Universal Office, for this simple reason, they might say that they had not insured in the other, and I had no reason to know—I do not recollect having any answers at all—I am not aware of being applied to by William Palmer to attest a proposal to the Universal Office after the execution of that assignment of the policy which I knew that Walter Palmer signed—I think I might venture to swear that I was not—I should be very sorry, if I was not quite positive, to speak that which was not true—I do not know when the document bears date—I have never seen the assignment till I saw it this morning—William Palmer gave it to me, but it was not signed then—I do not recollect that I was present when it was signed—it is a very good imitation of my writing.

Q. Will you swear that you were not present when it was signed, when Walter Palmer executed the deed of assignment; now, be cautious, you will hear of this another day if you do not take care; will you swear upon your oath that you were not present when Walter Palmer signed that document? A. I do not know—I say that the "Jeremiah Smith" is very much like my writing—this part,"Solicitor, Rugeley," does not look like mine—I am not quite positive whether, upon some occasion or other, I did not attest a deed of assignment by Walter Palmer to his brother of his interest in the policy for 13,000l.—as I said before, I believe the "Jeremiah Smith" is very much like my writing, but "Rugeley" is not.
Q. I ask you the question upon your oath, whether at some time or other you did not attest the assignment by Walter Palmer to William Palmer of
the policy for 13,000l.? A. I might—as I said before, it is a very good imitation—I might have attested it—I really do not recollect.
Q. Did not you get a cheque for 5l. for doing it? A. I wish to have it brought to my recollection.

Q. Look at that (a paper) and say whether you did not see William Pal
mer write that on the counterfoil of his cheque book; is that his hand
writing? A. That is William Palmer's handwriting—I might have seen him write it—I cannot swear positively that I did.

Q. Did you get a piece of paper, and go to the bank and get 5l. upon it? A. I most likely might—I might have got it from the bank, but not for the purpose of signing that document—I say that I might have got 5l. from the bank, but not for attesting that document—I am not positive that I got it for attesting the signature of Walter Palmer.

Q. That piece of paper seems to burn your fingers? A. No, upon my honour it does not—I am come here to speak the truth as far as my memory serves me, for or against—the 200l. I got for Mr. Cook was, 100l. from Mrs. Palmer, and the other from William Palmer—and he gave 10l. to William Palmer for the accommodation.

Q. Do not you know that he gave William Palmer his acceptance upon that occasion to enable him to make up the sum of 500l.? A. I know that William Palmer was the drawer of the bill, and Mr. Cook was the acceptor—he received 200l. minus 10l. in cash—I believe that the 200l. bill was not given for the purpose of enabling William Palmer to make up the sum of 500l. payable to Mr. Sargent, for Mr. Cook had absolute cash, the 200l. I speak of—he did not have it to enable him to go to London to take up an acceptance—he went to Shrewsbury races with it—I am speaking of the time when the money was lent by Mrs. Palmer and William Palmer—I think it was in May—I believe Shrewsbury races take place in May, the early part of May—I do not know what became of the bill—Mr. Cook gave him a bill for 200l., and he had the absolute cash—I brought 100l. from William Palmer's mother, a hundred pound note, and he had that which Mr. Palmer gave—the bill was drawn in favour of William Palmer—that is the bill that is referred to in one of these notes—it was cashed—it was charged two guineas—I do not know what became of it—he writes to me about a money lender issuing a writ—that money lender was Mr. Pratt, I believe—I do not know that—when the bill was given I handed it over to Mr. Palmer—what he did with it I do not know—I cannot tell whether Palmer discounted it with Mr. Pratt—I have never seen the bill since—that was not at the very time that William Palmer was short of money—he was not short of money because he lent Mr. Cook 100l.—I do not know that he wanted some money to make up the sum of 500l. payable to Mr. Sargent—he lent Mr. Cook 100l.—he lent him 90l., and he took 10l. for the accommodation—I weni once to Mr. Palmer when he was in Stafford gaol, but never spoke to him on the subject of this trial—during the time that I was there an officer was in the room—I was at the inquest, but I was not examined, excepting there was something named about the assignment, and I said, if it was produced I would say whether it was my handwriting as the attesting witness—I was not present at the inquest on Mr. Cook—T was staying in the town.

Q. Who saw you when you went in on Monday night to Mr. Cook's room at the Talbot Arms? A. I cannot say whether it was Miss Bond, or whether it was the chambermaid, or the waiter—they gave us a candle, and we went up stairs—I cannot say whether I took the candle or Mr. Palmer—it was the waiter, or Miss Bond, or the chambermaid—I do not

know that they saw us—we asked for a candle—I cannot tell you who saw me that night go into the Talbot Arms, and go up to Mr. Cook's room—Mr. Palmer was in a hurry to get down to his mother's—I cannot say which of the three saw me go into the hotel that night—I believe it was one of the three—I believe one of the servants gave us a candle—I believe it to have been one of those three—I did not notice the man who drove the fly from Stafford—I did not notice the man—it was cold, and I did not notice which of the drivers it was.

MR. SERJEANT SHEE. Q. How long have you known Mrs. Palmer? A. Many years, twenty years, I should say—I knew her before her hus
band's death—I was not acquainted with her then—it is many years since her husband died, upwards of twenty years ago—I should think Mrs. Palmer is about sixty years of age, by her sons—she has grandchildren, and I should say she is sixty—William is not her eldest son, Joseph is—he is a timber merchant in Liverpool—I should think he is about forty
five or forty-six—I think George is the next son—that is the gentleman now present—he lived at Rugeley—he was frequently at his mother's—he was acquainted with me—there is a son a clergyman of the Church of England—he lives at Coton-in-Elmes, sixteen miles from Rugeley—he was frequently at his mother's till he became a curate—when he came from college he stayed at her house—it is two years since he ceased to reside at his mother's house—up to that time he lived at his mother's, except when he was at college—they have a sister—she lives with her mother—there are three servants—they do not go out very much in the neighbourhood—being a large family them-selves, they do not visit much—it is a good-sized house—I think there are five bed rooms, six altogether—there is a room for the man, and the maids occupy one—there are four rooms for the family, and two for the servants—I slept in one nearest the old church, on the opposite side, and the new church is facing the house—the old church is at the side.
Q. Is there any pretence for saying, or have you ever been charged with any improper intimacy with Mrs. Palmer? A. I should hope not—there ought not to be any pretence for anything of the kind.

Q. Cannot you answer the question; is there or is there not any pretence for saying, or is there any truth in the statement or suggestion that you have been improperly intimate at any time with Mrs. Palmer? A. They might have said so, but they have no reason to say so—I should say there is not any truth in that statement; I mean not—I do not recollect the proposal to in
sure Walter Palmer's life coming to my knowledge till the inquest was held on Mrs. Palmer—there was some talk then about my being connected with some insurances.
(William Joseph Sounders was again called on his subpoena, but did not appear.)

The following letter was handed in and read as follows: ("Lutterworth, 4th of January, 1855. My dear Sir,—I sent up to London on Tuesday to back St. Hubert for 50l., and my commissioner has returned 10 to 1. I have therefore backed 250l. to 25l. against him to our gain. There is a small balance of 18l. due to you which I forgot to give you the other day. Tell Will to debit me with it on account of your share of training Pyrrhina I will also write to him to do so, as there will be a balance due from him to me. Yours faithfully,—J. Parsons Cook.—W. Palmer, Esq.")

(MR. SERJEANT SHEE. submitted that he was entitled to a reply, in con
sequence of the course which the ATTORNEY-GENERAL. had taken in getting out the substance of a cheque, and the contents of an assignment of a policy on Walter Palmers life, which he might just as well have read, and his
examining the witness as regards proposals to various office for inversions THE COURT. was of opinion that there was no right to reply.)
MR. ATTORNEY-GENERAL. having replied, the Court adjourned.
Monday, 26th, May, and part of Tuesday, 27th, was occupied by LORD. CAMPBELL'S. summing up.

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
DEATH .

div0.p: LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.
OLD COURT.—Monday, May 12th, 1856.
PRESENT—The Right Hon. the LORD MAYOR; Mr. Ald. SIDNEY.;
Sir FRANCIS GRAHAM MOON, Bart., Ald.; Mr. RECORDER.; Mr. Ald.

FINNIS.; Sir ROBERT WALTER CARDEN, Knt., Ald.; Mr. Ald. EAGLE
TON.; and Mr. Ald. LAWRENCE.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the First Jury.

div1.p:
491.
HENRY WILLIAMS was indicted
for a burglary in the dwelling house of
Joseph Bishop, and stealing 40 rolls of ribbon, 23 neck ties, and 17 pairs of gloves, his property.

JOSEPH BISHOP . I am a draper, at No. 7, Market-street, Stepney. Oh Saturday night, 8th March, I shut up the shop and premises—I live on the premises—the shop was not'opened on the Sunday—I was in the shop between 10 and 11 o'clock in the morning—it was then perfectly safe—I went to bed about 10 o'clock on Sunday night—T had not seen the shop since the morning, it appeared all quite secure, the shutters were up—I was aroused, between 1 and 2 o'clock on the Monday morning, by a policeman—I then went down to the shop—I found an outside shutter had been moved on one side, and a square of glass broken—I missed three boxes of ribbon, neck ties, and gloves—a person could reach them by putting an arm through the broken pane, it was not more than twenty or thirty inches from the window—the shop communicates with the dwelling house—there are two houses, but I made a door communicating between the two—I kept that door looked, and kept the key.

WILLIAM CHURCH . (policeman, K 304). On Monday morning, 10th March, I was on duty in High-street, Stepney, about half past 1 o'clock, and saw three men walking along, and the prisoner on the opposite side, with a bag on his right shoulder—I spoke to the sergeant, and went across for the purpose of stopping the prisoner—as soon as I got in front of him, he made a dart on one side to avoid me—I then made a grasp at him and the bag, and in so doing I was kicked between the feet, and fell on the ground on my knees—I instantly rose, and sprang my rattle for assistance, and called out "Stop thief!"—the prisoner ran away, I retained the bag—I did not see him stopped, I lost sight of him at the time I was getting up off my knees—he was taken by West, another constable, I should say a good 400 yards from the spot where he left me—he ran in the direction of Stepney-green; there is a bit of a bend in the road, and I just lost sight of him there—when I first got up on my feet I saw him, and I lost sight of him as he went round the bend towards Stepney-green—I followed him round

the corner, but did not see him till he was brought back to me by another constable—I should say that was nearly a quarter of an hour afterwards—I was looking after the prisoner during that time—I had been round Garnet-street, in some other direction—he must have taken one turning, and I another—I have no doubt whatever that he is the man—there was a gas lamp near the spot—I pointed out to West the place where I had seized the prisoner—I searched the prisoner at the station, and found on him a knife and a tobacco pouch—I went with the sergeant nexfc morning, and saw him compare this knife with the marks on the prosecutor's shutter and in the putty—I have the bag here—it contains gloves and other things.

Prisoner. Q. When the other policeman brought me back, did not you say, "We will make him answer our purpose, as we cannot find the other"? A. No, nor anything to that effect—I said, "That is the man"—that was all I said—I am sure the prisoner is the man—he had a grey rough coat on—it was the prisoner who kicked me between the feet, and tripped me up.

JAMES WEST . (policeman, K 308). I was on duty, on the morning of 10th March, in Garnet-street, near Stepney-green, and about half past 1 o'clock I heard the springing of a rattle, and the cry of "Stop thief!"—I saw the prisoner and two more men running—I made a grasp at the prisoner, and laid hold of him by the left side, and I was tripped up by two men who were following him—I seized the prisoner by the left breast—as soon as I laid hold of him I was tripped up by two men who were follow
ing close behind—I let go of him directly I fell down—I got up and pursued him—I followed him about 500 or 600 yards, and never lost sight of him except momentarily, in turning round the corner from one street into another—I sprang my rattle, at the same time I saw the constable coming up—I sang out, "Stop thief!" and the prisoner immediately stopped, and placed himself against a wall, under a lamp—he was taken into custody—another constable came up to him rather before me, but I took charge of him—I told him he must go back with me to where the springing of the rattle was—he said, "What for?"—I took him back on to the Green, the place where the springing of the rattle was—it was in Fayer-terrace that I stopped him, opposite the station—I met Church on Stepney-green, about 500 or 600 yards from the spot where he was taken into custody—Church said, on seeing the prisoner, "That is the man"—the prisoner denied it, and said he had done nothing—Church afterwards pointed out to me the place where he had first seized him—that was about 150 yards from where I first saw the prisoner running—he appeared to be coming from that direction, and I saw the light turned on at the same time they were running—the prisoner is the man—he had on a rough coat and a black cap—when I took him he was very much out of breath—he could scarcely speak.
Prisoner. That was because they knocked me about so.

ROBERT YOUNG . (police sergeant, K 9). I was present when the prisoner was searched—I saw this knife found upon him—I afterwards compared it I with five dents in the window putty at the prosecutor's premises—there was a pane of glass broken, but not taken out—they had apparently attempted to get it out whole—it was broken sufficient to admit of a man's hand, I could put mine in—there is a bend on the point of the knife which exactly corresponds with the marks in the window—the shutter had been prised by some instrument—on the pavement near the shutter I found some matches partly burnt—I received a jemmy and a chisel from the

witness Rawlinson—I compared this jemmy with some marks underneath the shutter, and also on the window sill, they appeared to correspond—the chisel corresponded with a dent in the window sill, and the jemmy was used to prise the shutter up—I was with Church at the time the prisoner passed—Rawlinson lives in Wellington-place—the prisoner would pass his house, it turns out of High-street, Stepney.

JAMES WEST . re-examined. I saw the prisoner go through Wellington-place—I ran after him through there, and flaw him pass Mr. Rawlinson's premises—I did not see him drop anything—I was running and springing my rattle at the time.

GEORGE RAWLINSON . I live at No. 4, Wellington-place, Stepney. I picked up these two instruments, at 8 o'clock in the morning, about twenty-one feet from my door, on the flag of a door step on the opposite side—I sent them over to the station—in order to go from High-street, Stepney, to Garnet-street, a person would pass through Wellington-place.
JOSEPH BISHOP . re-examined. These are my goods—there are plain marks on the ribbons, in my own writing—the other things are not marked.

Prisoners Defence. I am innocent; I had been to a friend's house, and stopped rather late, and was returning, when the policeman came up, and Mid he wanted me; I asked what it was for; he took me back to the other policeman; they knocked me down and kicked me shamefully; I had only been in London three days; I come from Manchester.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

492.
WILLIAM GRAVES
, stealing 1 spoon and 1 fork, value 18s.; the goods of
Joseph Worth Croom: having been before convicted: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

493.
ALFRED FREDERICK COMPERE
, stealing 2 boxes, and other articles; the goods of
Henry Walker, his master: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Six Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner, for a misdemeanor.)

494.
WILLIAM CLEMENTS
, stealing 30lbs. weight of bark; the goods of
Samuel Lloyd Howard.—2nd COUNT, unlawfully receiving the same.
MR. ROBINSON. conducted the Prosecution.

SAMUEL LLOYD HOWARD . I carry on business at Deptford, as a manufacturing chemist—there are five partners in the firm—we buy a large quantity of Peruvian bark of the importers—we buy a very large pro-portion of that which comes to this country—the prisoner was in our service for about thirteen months—in consequence of certain matters that came to my knowledge, he was dismissed in Nov.—he was one of those who ground the bark, one of the millers—this (produced) is the sort of stuff that it would be when ground—it is not a marketable article in this condition—this is one of the processes of making it into quinine—there being no mark or anything about this, I cannot, of course, swear to it, but as near as it is possible to swear to anything, I can, like a mechanic can swear to a tool of his own making, without being able to explain exactly why—to the best of my belief, it is my bark, I have no moral doubt about it—I cannot swear to the paper in which it is wrapped, it is similar paper to that we use.
GEORGE EVANS . I am a miller, in the prosecutor's employ. The prisoner was in their employment some time before he left—I found a parcel of bark

in the water house Against the wheel—I moved it and laid it in the same place, but further up—I came on again at night, and moved it again into the mill, and let it lie till next morning—I did not say anything about it, and at breakfast time next morning, the prisoner came and said, "I think I am let into a great secret"—I said, "Oh! what is that?"—he said, "Fred Wallidge wanted a little piece of bark for himself, and I asked him to put up a little piece for me, as I wanted a little piece for a friend, and I am afraid the foreman has found it and taken it to the counting house"—he said that it had been put in the water house for him, and when he went to look it was gone—I said that I had found it—he said, "Oh, you found it, then, that is all right, I shall tell the master"—when he said that it was a little piece, I said, "There is three or four pounds of it"—I had not then weighed it, but I did afterwards, and it weighed three pounds and a half—he said that he did not see it, he did not put it there, the other man put it there—he begged me not to say anything about it, for the sake of their wives and families; and if I did not they would never do anything of the kind any more—Wallidge was with him, and they asked me to have some beer; I said that I did not want any—I made a communication to the foreman, Mr. Mason, and he told me to let it be till he found them out, he should like to find them out himself—on a subsequent occasion I was on the grind
ing floor, and heard some one up stairs—I went up the ladder, and saw Clements putting a brown paper parcel into his pocket—I said, "What game now, Clements?"—he said, "I am mending my old pocket;" another witness heard him as well—he had a smock on which came down to his knees—I know Beckley, I saw him tried about three months since; I saw him on one occasion in front of the mill talking to Clements, who was at work, that was in the latter part of the summer—the bark is of the same description as my master's, and I believe it to be his—I live at No. 5, Stratford-place, and the prisoner lived nearly opposite to me, but before he was discharged he moved into West-street, I think it is called, or South-street—I only saw him twice up to the time of Beckley's apprehension, which was very soon after he left our place—after Beckley's apprehension I went with the police, but could not find him anywhere.
Prisoner. Q. Will you take your oath that you saw me putting the bark into my pocket? A. Yes—I am not selling my soul for the sake of revenge.

ALFRED FULLER . I am a labourer in the prosecutor's service. I saw the prisoner go up stairs, and saw him putting a paper parcel in his pocket—that was a month or two after we found the parcel, he remained in the service about two months after that—I have heard the conversation Evans has detailed, it is true—two or three days after the parcel was found I was talking to the prisoner, and he said, "The bark is not worth so much a pound as they have stated, by a good bit"—I said, "How can you know?"—he said, "I have a friend in London who is in the habit of buying bark," and that his friend had been an assistant in a doctor's shop—he said that we might all be as happy as the birds in the air if it was not for that b—y black-legged old b—, meaning Evans; and that we might put a few shillings into each other's pocket if it was not for him—I told him that I should not have anything to do with it, he would not put any money into my pocket that way—he said that we were not like they were at other places, but we were all against each other—I was present when the parcel was found by Evans—I was not down when the conversation between Evans and the prisoner began, but I heard the latter part—I heard the prisoner
swearing at Evans, and he told him to hold his noise about it and he Would stand some beer; but Evans said that he would not hare any.

THOMAS JOHN GOUGH . I am a tailor, of No, 5, Lauderdale-buildings, Aldersgate-street. Beckley lodged with me till some short time after Nov. last, and the prisoner used to come to see him, sometimes once a week, and sometimes twice—he came invariably on Saturday evenings, and occasionally on Tuesday evenings, and he invariably carried a basket; and on one occa
sion I saw in it something in a brown paper, parcel—one Saturday night, about 6 o'clock in the evening, it might be three weeks prior to Beckley, being taken, the prisoner came; I opened the door, and he asked for Beckley, I told him he was not within; he seemed vexed, and said that he had come a long journey, from Stratford, and was tired—I told him if he liked to leave his banket, which seemed to be heavy, I would take care of it till Beckley came—he declined leaving it, and said that he would go over to the public house opposite, and await Beckley's return, if I would let one of my children let him know when Beckley came in, and invited me to partake of a little porter at the public house—I told my children, and then went over with him to the public house where he put a brown paper parcel on a form, and I saw a brown powder which seemed to ooze from it, as it does from these parcels produced—I did not remain two minutes with him, I had no drink—I did not see him afterwards at my house, but my children told me something—subsequent to Beckley's apprehension, I saw him at my house and opened the door to him, and I met him in Barbican after Beckley'a apprehension, and noticed that his whiskers were shaved off.
Prisoner. I know nothing of this person, nor yet the statement he has made.

CHANLES OGBURN . (City policeman 26). On 5th Dec, I apprehended Beckley—I searched his lodging, No. 5, Lauderdale-buildiugs, Aldersgate-street, and found some articles, but not the drugs; I found them at No, 92 1/2, Aldersgate-street, in a third floor room, a lodging which, the mother of the girl who was living with Beckley took, after Beckley wan in custody—it was a Miss Heath who he was living with—I there found the four parcels pro
duced—I saw Miss Heath there, that is her (pointing to her)—I endea
voured to apprehend the prisoner, and went with Evans to his house, but Evans did not go in with me; I found the prisoner's wife there, but could get no tidings of him for four or five days after Beckley was taken.

ELIZABETH HEATH . I lived with Beckley, at No. 5, Lauderdale-buildings. I knew of these parcels being there, they were Beckley's property, he brought them there—I helped to remove them to the new lodging—I used to see the prisoner at No. 5, Lauderdale-buildings—I did not see him bring any parcels there of any description; his wife used to come with a basket, but not parcels—she brought me a loaf done up in paper two or three times on Saturday evenings.

JOHN WILLIAM MANNING . (police sergeant, K 5). I telegraphed to Cam
bridge, and from information I received, I went dpwn and communicated with the authorities at Houghton, in Huntingdonshire, on 7th March—I went in plain clothes—I had been looking out for the prisoner from the beginning of Dec.—I had seen some furniture leaving his house at dusk, on, 22nd Feb., and afterwards saw it at the railway station at Stratford, addressed, "William Leader, to be left at the railway station, Cambridge, till called for"—that was on a card nailed to each case, I wrote it down at the time, but have not got my pocket book with me: I have an independent

recollection that the name was Leader—it was in consequence of that that I communicated with the police, with instructions to watch the goods—when I went to Houghton I went to the water mill where the prisoner was at work, a flour mill, and saw the prisoner coming down stairs, round a corner of the mill inside, and Evans, who was with me, said, "That is him;" he then turned his back towards us—Evans did not say that loud enough for him to hear, and I do not think he could see Evans—as we approached him, from information I had obtained, I called out, "Simmers;" he said, "Sir;" and turned half round; I called "Simmers" again, and he turned quite round, faced me, and said, "Sir;" I said, "Oh, your name is Clements"—he paused a short time, dropped his head, and said, "It is"—I told him I was about taking him into custody on suspicion of stealing a quantity of bark and other chemicals from his late masters at Stratford—he said, "I know nothing about it, and do not care a d—for fifty b—Howards and Kents"—I said, "What made you leave Stratford?"—he said, "To look for work," and that he had been there about six weeks—I took him into custody; he said that he did not go in the name of Simmers, but I told him that he had.

Prisoner. Q. Who informed you that I went by a wrong name? A. The constable; the foreman asked what Simmers had been at; I said, "That is not his name, his name is Clements," and told him what I took you for—the constable of the parish also told me that you went by the name of Simmers.

JOHN HENRY BREEZE . I am goods clerk at the Eastern Counties Rail
way station at St. Ivea, which is about three miles and a half from Hough
ton. I only know the prisoner from seeing him at the station—he came there to receive some goods which had come down for him by railway—I cannot say how they were addressed, but he signed his name William Leader in this book in my presence—the book is in my writing, it only gives the name—I took it from the invoice—we held the goods for Leader, and delivered them to him as Leader—I did not see them; somebody else delivered them.

WILLIAM ELY . I am a publican, of Whitton, in Huntingdonshire, adjoin
ing Houghton. The prisoner asked my permission for his letters to be addressed to my house, and I gave him leave—four or five letters came, the first one was delivered to him by my wife in my presence—I saw two or three of them delivered to him.

COURT. to, ALFRED FULLER. Q. Where is the bark put after it is ground? A. It is shot on the floor, and afterwards put into casks—we saw placet where bark had been taken off the hoop of the stone which keeps the dust in, that was what he had got to put into his pocket—I missed four or five good handfuls—after it is ground it runs down between the two stones, and the dust flies up and settles, that is the finest—in another room a great deal had been shot down, and we could see where it had been shot down and picked up, none was left but the dust on the floor; that was not a proper place for sifting it—we do not sift it at all.

COURT. to MR. HOWARD. Q. What quantity do you have in a week? A. One or two tons—I cannot tell to what extent my stock has been decreased, from the immense quantity which is ground, and the quantity of dust which hangs in hundredweights about the walls of the room, and which is just as valuable as the rest.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Two Years.

495.
WILLIAM SWILSON and
JAMES MARSHALL
, stealing 49l. 10s. in money, of
Robert Gregory.
MR. RYLAND. conducted the Prosecution.

ROBERT GREGORY . I am an emigrant, about to sail in the Sea King for Australia; she is now lying in the London Docks. On Thursday, 1st May, I saw Marshall on board the Sea King—he introduced himself to me as a gentleman going out by the same ship, and said that he had some machinery on board—after talking with him on board for some time about the Colonies and other matters, he got me to walk off with him as far as the Spread Eagle, in Graoechurch-street—from thence he proposed going for a stroll to see the sights of London, and he took me to a public house near West-minster Bridge, and treated me with a glass of ale and a biscuit—while we were there, Marshall came in, he fined me and Swilson—he said that he had just come from America in consequence of an uncle haying left him a great deal of money—he pulled out his money, and showed several notes, end several sovereigns, and seemed greatly rejoiced—he said that he would treat us with a glass each to drink his health, which he did—this was about 3 o'clock in the afternoon—Swilson then proposed that we should go to Cremorne Gardens—we all three left the public house together, and walked about different streets—I am not much acquainted with London—we after
wards took a boat—we then went to another public house near Cremorne Gardens—I know it was near Cremorne Gardens, I had beer there—while we were in that public house Swilson gave me a small bag, and also Marshall, and he also said he would give us an American dollar each, to keep for his sake—there was nothing in the bag that he gave me—I had at that time in my possession a bag containing about fifty sove-reigns, among it there were two old guineas—there had been 50l., sovereigns and half sovereigns, I had changed one half sovereign—my bag was within another bag, about the same size and colour as tins one (produced)—I took my bag out of my pocket, and put it on the table before Swilson—Swilson took it up, and also this bag, and said he would put it in for me with the American dollar—he appeared to do so, bag and all, tied it up, and returned it to me, and I put it into my pocket, thinking that I had got my money right—shortly after we all three left the house together—when we had got a little way Swilson said, "I hare forgot my pocket handkerchief, which can run the fastest?"—the other hesitated, and I turned back and ran to see if there was any pocket handkerchief left behind, but there was no pocket handkerchief—I then returned to the spot where I had left the prisoners, and they were both gone—I did not look at my money then—it roused my suspicions, and as soon as I pulled it out, I found my money was gone—I cannot tell at what time that was, it was at some time in that evening—I believe it was as I was going to pay for my breakfast—it must have been next morning, therefore—I Slept at some public house at Ken
sington that night—I went to see a cousin, and then to the public house where I slept—next morning, when I was going to pay for my breakfast, I took out my bag and opened it, and none of my sovereigns were there, nor the two guineas, nor the American dollar, but a quantity of farthings, I think more than fifty; part of them are here, the other part I had to pay for my breakfast with, as I had no more money in my pocket—I then gave information to the police—I had never seen the prisoners before—I am perfectly satisfied they are the men.
COURT. Q. What time was it when Swilson came into the public house near Westminster Bridge? A. I should think about 3 o'clock—it was
nearly 5 o'clock when they went away—we had been together more than two hours.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Where was it you slept? A. I do not know the name of the public house—I slept alone, and locked myself in—after the prisoners went away, at 5 o'clock, I walked straight on to my cousin's, at Kensington—I went to bed early, before 10 o'clock; it might be about 9 o'clock—I sat with jny cousin, and we had a glass of ale at the public house where I lodged, and a journeyman with him—my cousin then went home, and I went to bed—I first drank a glass of ale with the prisoners, then a glass of brandy and water at the Victoria tavern, and one glass of brandy and water at the place where Swilson came in—I should say we had about three in the course of the day—I believe we went to three public houses—I will not swear we had no more; I will swear we had not a great deal—I never was drunk in my life.

Q. How came you to pull out your money, and allow them to shift it into a different bag? A. From their respectable appearance and manner, I thought they were gentlemen—I had not the slightest suspicion of them—immediately I found they were gone, I put my hand into my pocket, and felt that my bag was all right; I did not look inside until I went to pay for my breakfast—I gave a description of the prisoners, and was for some time looking after them, and Mr. Smith and an officer, 63 F, I believe, came to me, and said they had taken a person on suspicion from my description—I went with them to the station, and saw Swilson in the cell—I looked at him, and hesitated at first; I said his features were like, but his dress and appearance was so much altered that I doubted for the moment; but when I came to hear him speak, and saw him with his other coat on, I had not the slightest hesitation in saying he was the man—we afterwards went with him in a cab somewhere—he pulled his hat off in the cab, and said to me, "Look at me again, and be very careful, for it is a very serious charge; you are quite mistaken in the man," or something of that sort—I did not make any answer—I did not, when the charge was being booked at the police station, say that Swilson had whiskers and eyes like the man, but that I was not positive about him—Swilson told the Magistrate that I had said so, and the Magistrate asked me if I had any doubt about him, and I said, "No, not the least"—Smith did not tell me that he was the man—he said that he had given a person into custody whom he called Flash Harry, and he pre
sumed he was the man from the description I had given, and wanted me to go and see him—I had not seen either of the prisoners before to my knowledge.

MR. RYLAND. Q. What change was there in Swilson's dress and appear
ance? A. He was so shabby, and dirty, and untirly—when I saw him before, his appearance and manner were like a gentleman.

JAMES SMITH . I am agent to the Maritime Insurance Company, in Fenchurch-street. I know the two prisoners—I think I have known Swilson four or five years, and Marshall from one to two years—I have frequently seen them together—I do not believe that Swilson has been to America for the last year or two; he has not been at all to my knowledge—I have seen him frequently, perhaps two or three times a month, during the last year—it is possible he may have gone out in a very fast steamer, and just come back again, but I do not think he could have done it; it is barely possible; I am only speaking from recollection.
Crss-examined. Q. You are agent to the Maritime Insurance Society? A. Yes; I am a regularly appointed agent by the Company—I am the

London agent; we have very fine offices at No. 113, Fencburch-street; my office is there, and the office of the Company—the Company rents it—it is a regularly chartered Company—they gave me a certain salary, fifty guineas a year, and ten per cent, commission on all policies—the salary is simply for expenses—I have not been to Liverpool or Manchester since June or July last—I resided at Liverpool many years—I have been a good deal at Man
chester—I have not been a good deal before the Magistrates there—I have never been in the dock—I have been a witness there, I suppose two, three, or four times; three times within the last four or five years—some of these characters that you defend say I am a sort of amateur policeman—I never receive any money for it, not for my expenses—I have never pocketed my expenses; I have always given them to the officer in the case—I do it on public grounds—I have never made any mistake—it is not true that a woman was wrongly convicted on my evidence at Manchester, and after
wards pardoned—I do not recollect any woman being convicted there of picking pockets on my evidence, and being afterwards pardoned, because it was found out that I was wrong—I never heard of it—I will not swear it is not true—I have not given evidence a dozen times at Manchester; perhaps three or four times; it might be five—I will not swear it was not half a dozen; I will swear it was not a dozen—I have given evidence a great many times at Liverpool, perhaps twenty or thirty—I do not know how many times in London; two or three times, perhaps—you may not see these things; perhaps you have not the observation—I lived at Liverpool seven
teen years, and have received the thanks of the Magistrates, and of the Judges—I left Liverpool to suit myself; I prefer London in every way as a place for business—I have been before Mr. Maude, the Magistrate, at Man
chester; he knows me very well; it is an infamous fabrication to say that Mr. Maude ever told me that he wished not to see me there again, and that the police were much better without my services than with them—he never said anything of the kind; he has thanked me once or twice from the bench—any expenses I might get I hare always given to the officer employed in the case—I have never received any expenses in London; I have not been a witness here—I do not recollect the names of any officers in Liverpool or Manchester to whom I have handed over my expenses.

COURT. Q. How came you to have anything to do with helping the police? A. Merely on public grounds; wherever I can be of any service I do it—I became connected with this case through the captain of the Sea King, who is a particular friend of mine, and, hearing the description of the men, I thought I knew them—Swilson used to live at Liverpool—I did not know Where lie lived at the time this matter occurred—I knew one house that he did reside in, and I sent the officer there.

THOMAS HANSCOMB . (policeman, F 63). I took Swilson into custody on Friday morning, about 10 o'clock, near Exeter-hall, in the Strand—I told him I took him on suspicion of stealing fifty sovereigns from a gentleman near Cremorne—he said he was innocent of the charge—Mr. Smith gave me information; in consequence of which, I found the prosecutor, and took him to the station to see Swilson, and he identified him as one of the men who had robbed him—he was alone in the dock when he saw him—we gene
rally show several prisoners together, but he was the only one we had there then—I took Marshall into custody about 7 o'clock, that same evening, in the Strand—the prosecutor was with me, and pointed him out—I told him the charge—he uaid, "Oh"—I took hold of the cuff of his coat, and he said, "Well, lift my arm up, so that you won't show me up"—I searched him,
and found on him thirteen sovereigns, half a crown, and a counterfeit coin like a half sovereign—we asked the prisoners their addresses at the station, and they refused to give them.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you ever been in a case with Smith before? A. Never—I did not know that I was going to get his fees—I should not take them without reporting it to the Commissioners—if I did I should be dis
charged—there is a rule against it—Mr. Smith has not said anything to me about giving me bis fees—Swilson said he was innocent—he said Smith had never seen him before in his life, and that he was setting the prosecutor on to him.

SWILSON—
GUILTY .† Aged 36.

MARSHALL—
GUILTY .† Aged 38.

div0.p: NEW COURT.—Monday, May 12th, 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. FINNIS. and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Third Jury.

div1.p:
496.
SAMUEL NEALE and
JOHN GRAMPTON
, unlawfully obtain
ing money by false pretences.
MR. METCALFE. conducted the Prosecution.
(No evidence was offered against NEALE.)
NOT GUILTY .

THOMAS JAMES STRONG . I am a cow keeper, and live in West-street, Hackney. Neale was in my service—I was in the habit of sending him to the distiller's for grains in my cart—he was to bring home to me three quarters, and to leave two quarters at Mrs. Eagle's—there were throe quar
ters thrown into the cart, a board was laid over them, and two quarters were thrown on the top—on 14th March I gave him 25s. to get five quarters of grains, and he was to leave two quarters at Mrs. Eagle's—the cart would only hold five quarters.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Would it not hold five quarters and a half? A. It would not hold six quarters—I never tried whether it would hold five quarters and a half—I did not give him any direction as to what he was to leave at Mrs. Eagle's—he would leave what she wanted—he did not give me any written memorandum—he paid me for two quarters as left with Mrs. Eagle.

MARY O'BRIEN . I am the wife of Michael O'Brien. I am the daughter of Mrs. Eagle, who is a cow keeper, at Hackney—Crampton was her foreman—his duty was to receive grains, and tread them in—I paid the money to Neale—sometimes Crampton came and sometimes Neale, and said that the grains were come—they were paid for one week under the other—on 14th March three quarters were charged to me by a written memorandum, which was brought to me by Neale—I paid on 19th for those delivered on 14th—he ought to have brought the memorandum from Mr. Strong—I took it from Neale, and paid him the money—this is it, "3 quarters of grains, draw from Mr. Strong, 19s. 2d."—Crampton was in the yard at the time they were delivered—I asked him bow many grains there were—he said, "Three quarters"—I thought there were not so many—I said there was a very short three quarters, and I asked him how many the cart would hold—he said six quarters.

Cross-examined. Q. Mrs. Eagle is a very old person? A. Yes—my husband does not manage the business, he is away altogether; I do what I can, as I always did—Crampton had been in the service I dare say tea years—my husband had nothing to do with the business—he was out of employ at that time, but since that he has got some employment at the wharves in East Smithfield—he went on errands for my mother, but he had nothing to do in the yard—I know Crampton cannot write—I have paid him one week under another, and sometimes my mother has.

THOMAS HORNER . I am potman at the Three Colts, in Grove-street, Hackney, close by Mrs. Eagle's. I saw Mr. Strong's cart on 19th March, and Neale with it—he asked me if I had seen Crampton—I said, "Yes"—he told me to tell him he wanted to see him—I went and delivered the message to Crampton—he said he could not come down, he had better see the old lady—he gave me this ticket to give to Neale—I gave it to Neale—the cart was at that time at the public house with grains in it—after I gave Neale the ticket, he took the cart down to the yard, and delivered the grains—after that Neale came back with the cart which had some grains in it, and he told me to take a pot of beer round to Crampton, which I did—I did not take it the usual way, but another way, a back way, because of Mr. O'Brien—Crampton told me that when his gave me the ticket—that was on the 19th, the time before the last that the cart came—I saw Neale with the cart, and he and Crampton came into the tap room after the grains had been delivered—that was four or five days before the 19th—they used to settle for the beer: they had—sometimes it would, be St.;, Neale paid for it.
Cross-examined. Q. Some directions were given to you by Crampton on 19th? A. Yea—I never mentioned before about his telling me to go another way—I was not asked that before.
MARY O'BRIEN . re-examined. I never saw Crampton read writing—I asked him how many grains had been left on the 14th, and oa the 19th also.

SAMUEL NEALE . (the prisoner). I was carman to Mr. Strong; I forget whether I took any grains to Mrs. Eagle's on 14th. March—it is a long time ago—I remember the two last times I went there with grains—I quite entirely forget how many grains I took there the last tine but one—I got five quarters from the distiller's—they wen put into the cart—they were not measured—there was a board dividing them—there were three quarters at the bottom, and two at the top—I delivered those on the top of the board to Mrs. Eagle—no more, as far as I can recollectr—this seems like, the bill I gave Mrs. O'Brien on the last occasion, but I cannot read it—the pot
man gave me one on the last occasion, and I gave it to Mrs. O'Brien—I received for three quarters 19s. 3d.—Crampton did not, say anything to me about receiving for three quarters at that time—he has sometimes said so—I forget now what it was that Crampton said to ma—after I had paid 12s. 6d. to Mr. Strong, I believe the rest of the money was nearly all spent in beer—it might not be all spent that day—I do not recollect that I paid any money to Crampton—no, I did not—I did not, pay him any on the 14th, or on the last day—I am sure I do not know how I came to spend it all in beer with Crampton—I quite forget now what he said to me about the three quarters.
NOT GUILTY .

497.
SAMUEL NEALE was again indicted
for stealing 14s.; the moneys of
Thomas James Strong; on which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

498.
JOHN HENNESSY
, burglary in the dwelling house of
Alexander John Kerr, and stealing 1 dressing case, the goods of
Samuel Goodfellow; and 1 key and 1 work box; the goods of
Mary Wilkinson.

MARY WILKINSON . I am in the service of Mr. Alexander John Kerr, No. 67, Grosvenor-street, Grosvenor-square. On Sunday evening, 13th April, I was in my mistress's room on the second floor, at a quarter past 9 o'clock—I heard footsteps in the room above—I took the candle, and ran up stairs to the attic, and as I entered the door I could see the prisoner get
ting out of the window—I saw his face, and he spoke to me—he got out of the window down into the gutter—I believe there is a communication with the next house by means of that gutter—the same person came in again—my candle was gone out then—he came in half way, and took a work box of my own—when my candle was gone out there was merely the light of the window—it was moonlight—the prisoner was brought into the house again in about ten minutes—the window was quite shut down about 2 o'clock, it was not fastened.
Prisoner. When she was before the Magistrate, she said she could not swear to my features. Witness. I said so, but I could to his voice, and to his general appearance.
COURT. Q. Could you hear this sound above before you went up at a quarter past 9 o'clock—I heard footsteps before I went into my mistreat room—the persons might have got in before 9 o'clock.

HENRY MORRIS . I am in the service of Mr. Colster. I was in Grosve
nor-street on Sunday evening, 13th April; I heard an alarm—I saw the prisoner coming down a ladder, from the top of a house—I believe it was No. 64, three doors from the prosecutor's—I laid hold of him—he said, "For God's sake let me go"—I gave him in charge—he said he had done nothing.

JOHN SHEPHERD . (policeman, C 116). I heard a cry of "Police!" about a quarter before 10 o'clock that night—I ran to No. 67, Grosvenor-street—the prisoner was given into my custody—I found on him a piece of candle, some lucifers, a knife, and two keys—I went up Mr. Kerr's house, and found a bar had been removed from the attic window.
MARY WILKINSON . re-examined. One of these keys found on the prisoner is my mistress's—it was safe in the room that afternoon.

Prisoner's Defence. I was coming down Grosvenor-street; I heard screams of "Murder!" I saw some person on the top of the house; I went up the ladder to the top; when I got a little way I could not get any far
ther, I picked up the matches and keys, and came down, and this man stopped me; this woman said two or three different things, first, she could not swear to me, and then she could; I hope you will look into the case; no pro
perty was found on me; I was seen on a house three doors off.
GUILTY .

p.hi: The prisoner was further charged with having been before convicted.

div1.p: WALTER HOLMES . (policeman, F 50). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read: "Westminster Sessions, Dec., 1854; George Wiltiams, convicted of larceny, after a previous conviction, and confined six months")—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY.** Aged 17.—
Four Years Penal Servitude.

499.
THOMAS TAYLOR
, stealing 2 dead salmon, value 15s.; the goods of the
Great Northern Railway Company, his masters.
MR. COOPER. conducted the Prosecution.
WILLIAM SMITH . (City policeman, 572). At a little past 6 o'clock, in the

morning, on 1st May, I saw a van belonging to the Great Northern Rail
way Company, in King William-street—the prisoner was in that van in a stooping position, which induced me to watch him—I saw him take out of his pocket, under his waistcoat, this hammer (producing it)—he next proceeded to prise up the lid of the top box—there were two boxes—after he had raised the lid and released the nails, he lifted the lid up and took a salmon out, and placed it under some straw—he lifted the lid of the same box again and took another salmon, and secreted it in the same place—after" he had done that he nailed the lid down again with this hammer—he then got down and got on the driving box, apparently going to drive off—I told him I wanted him, and he must come down—he said, "I am going to deliver these goods at the South Eastern Railway station, and must go"—I said, "Yon must go with me; I must deliver you and the goods at the police station"—he got down, and I said, "How about these fish?"—he said, "For God's sake, don't say anything about it; if you do I am a ruined man"—after some little time I got the assistance of a brother officer to take charge of the van, and I took the prisoner—in going along, he said, "For God's sake, take no notice of it; I will give you a sovereign or anything"—I said if he would give me 100l. I could not do it—in going along, he said, "I will give you 5l., I will give you anything in the world"—he was taken to the station, and while the charge was being booked, he took this hammer out of his pocket under his waistcoat, and said, "This is what I opened the box with"—I found the salmon secreted in the straw under the tarpaulin.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Where were they secreted? A. In the middle of the van—there were some baskets of fish in the van which were to be delivered, according to the address—there was straw in the body of the van—there was nothing done to the other box—the first I saw was, the prisoner was in a stooping position, that attracted my attention—he was before me—I could see his face and the box—I did not Intend that he should see me—I got in a doorway—I will swear he could not see me—I examined the box at the station—I found the lid closely nailed down—I could not swear whether it was an old lid—the prisoner said the nails were loose; the lid was old, and the fish were coming out—he said he would give me a pound, a sovereign; nay, he would give me 5l., if I would not take him to the station—he said, "I shall be a ruined man; I hare a wife and six chil
dren; I will give you 5l."

HILTON JOHNSON . I am a porter at the Great Northern Railway. On 1st May, the prisoner drove a van from there—I checked the goods that he took out that morning—he took three boxes of salmon—they were in a good state when he left the station—they were for Boulogne.

Q. I believe the drivers take hammers and nails with them, in case it should be necessary in the passage of the goods to use them? A. I never knew it—I do not know that it is done—I do not know that the lids some
times get loose, and ttfe nails come out on the way—they are always well examined before they leave—it might be the case that the boxes might get loose and they might repair them at the instant, but I do not know it.

HECTOR CAHEROH . I am a van boy in the employ of the Great Northern Railway. Between 5 and 6 o'clock in the morning, on 1st May, I saw the van which the prisoner drove—amongst the goods were three salmon boxes—I noticed that the lid of one was a little loose—it was open about half an inch when he left the station—they were to be taken to the South Eastern Railway—the Van stopped at London-bridge, and the prisoner told me to go down to the market to see whether there was any ice—I went and was

away about ten minutes—when I came back I missed the prisoner—I went towards the South Eastern Railway, and as I was going over the bridge, a man told me he was gone to the station—I went to Seething-lane station—I found the van there—I looked round, and the boxes were all nailed down.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you know that drivers of vans take hammers and nails with them? A. I never heard of it—I once saw a lid come off at the South Western Railway, and the prisoner sent me for a stone to drive the nails in—I have not seen that he has carried a hammer and nails since that—I think this box had been used several times before—the lid that came off before might be with the jolting of the van—we were going to deliver this van at the South Eastern Railway—nothing happened to the other boxes—I do not recollect the prisoner saying that Mr. Phillips, a fishmonger, had desired him to see if there was any ice—I went down to Billingsgate market—I have seen packages open at the Great Northern Railway station, and the prisoner has sent me for a hammer to knock them down—I think it was of the smaller box that the lid was loose—to the best of my recollection, the smaller box was on the top.

(The prisoner received a good character.)
GUILTY . Aged 41.—Recom
mended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Four Months.

500.
THOMAS NASH
, stealing 1 counterpane, 2 sheets, 1 towel, and 1 pillow case; the goods of
Joyce Brown: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Twelve Months.
(The policeman stated there were twelve or fifteen other cases against him.)

501.
HENRY NASH
, stealing 1 wrapper and 228 yards of cotton sheeting; the goods of
Joseph Hornby Baxendale and others.
MR. PLATT. conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM TURNER . (City policeman, 449). About 10 o'clock in the morn
ing, on 25th April, I saw the prisoner turn out of Cheapside into Lawrence-lane—he was carrying this bale of goods in an awkward manner—I followed him to Basinghall-street, and he put the bale down in a doorway—I went to him, and said, "Where did you get that bale from?" he said, "From Cheapside"—I said, "From what house there?" he said, "From no house; I saw a man in the street with a velvet coat on, he asked me to take it to London-wall, to the Grand Junction booking office, he said he would give me a pot of beer to carry it"—he said he knew the man by sight, but he did not know his name.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did he not ask you to go with him to where the man was? A. Yes—he did not ask me to leave the goods in care of another policeman, who was there—I said, "It is no use going to the booking office; it is an old tale, it won't do for me."

JAMES KNIGHT . I am warehouseman to Messrs. Grant, in Cheapside. This bale of goods was consigned to our house—it contains five pieces of cotton sheeting—the value of them is 6l. 9s. 7d.—I produce the invoice which contains the number which corresponds with the number on the bale and the number on the goods—there were fourteen bales delivered, and this one was not.

ALFRED IREDALE . I am book keeper to Joseph Hornby Baxendale and others, at Camden-town station. On the morning of 25th April, I assisted in loading the van at the station—there were fifteen packages addressed to

Messrs. Grant, and this was one of them—there is a delivery book, but I did not bring it—the mark on this bale is the same as the mark on the other packages—I saw this safe in St. Martin's-le-Grand when I went into Hanson Smith's for a few minutes—I delivered goods there, and at several other places—I was there between 9 and 10 o'clock—I went into those places to get my book signed—when I got to Messrs. Grant's, I counted the goods, and missed one bale—as far as I know, this is the bale, by the mark, and size, and everything—I cannot say that I saw the prisoner at all.

Cross-examined. Q. How many go with a van? A. Two went on that occasion—it was supposed to be the duty of the other man to watch the van while I went in to get my book signed—I cannot tell where he was—he is not here.
COURT. Q. How was the man dressed who went with you? A. He had a cord jacket on, not a velvet one.
(The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate fang read, was, that he way employed by a man to carry the parcel to the booking office.)
NOT GUILTY .

502.
JAMES GOURD,
Burglariously breaking and entering the dwell
ing house of
Edward Ashley, and stealing 1 clock, 2 table covers, 1 bird
cage, and other goods, value 4l. 10s.; his property.
MR. CAARTEEN. conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN COX . (policeman, N 369). I met the prisoner, about a quarter before 6 o'clock in the morning, on 11th April, at the top of Canonbury-street, Lower-road, Islington—he was carrying a birdcage with two birds in it—I followed him as far as Queen-street, about 200 or 300 yards, stopped him, and asked where he brought the birdcage from—he said, "If you win come with me, I will show you"—I went with him about two yards, when he dropped the cage at my feet, and ran away—I pursued him about a dozen yards, when he turned round, drew a knife from his pocket, and said, "You b—, if you come nigh me, you will have it"—he then con
tinued running till I stopped him again, about a dozen yards further—before I secured him he turned round several times, and attempted to stab me time after time—at the corner of George-street he took two tablecloths from his waistcoat—he threw one on a wall, with intent to throw it into a garden, and the other he threw in the middle of the road—he then ran about fifty yards further—he then dropped the knife, and I secured him—another policeman came to my assistance, and we searched the prisoner, and found this piece of ribbon in his waistcoat pocket—I got one of the table-cloths—a butcher came by, and took one, and ran away with it—I have not the least doubt that the prisoner is the man I saw with the birdcage—I never lost sight of him.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How far is the place where you saw him with the birdcage, from where he was taken? A. About half a mile—when he threw the cloths away, he buttoned up his clothes, and said, "Now come on," and he ran some distance, and dropped the knife, and I took him—it was fifty or sixty yards from where the things were thrown down to where he was taken—I did not lose sight of him till I took him—Atkins saw the whole of it—I never saw Atkins before—I believe he has been a witness in one case before—he is not an amateur policeman.

JABEZ ATKINS . I live in New Norfolk-street, and am a cowman. I was in Queen-street about a quarter past 6 o'clock in the morning on 11th April—I saw the prisoner in Lower Queen-street, carrying a birdcage under his arm—I saw Cox go up to him—the prisoner put the cage dow

at his feet, and ran away—Cox ran after him—I joined in the pursuit—the prisoner was stopped at the end of George-street—before he was stopped I saw he had a knife in his hand, and he kept running at the policeman—the policeman sprang his rattle—I went towards the prisoner, and he said, "What the b—hell do you want P—he had part of a brick in his hand—I saw these tablecloths up above his waistcoat, and he threw one on the wall at Mr. Fowler's, the corner of Rotherfield-street, and I saw another tablecloth lying at the corner of Halliford-street, by which the prisoner ran—I left Cox before the prisoner was taken—I saw him taken into custody when I returned—the sergeant was running along with me.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you first see the prisoner? A. When I was putting the horse to the cart—I had seen the policeman on the same beat for about two months before—I am quite sure the prisoner is the man who had the birdcage—he took the cloths out of his waistcoat in George-street—one he threw on the wall—I went away, and got assistance—I am quite sure the man I saw throw the things away was the same man I after
wards saw in custody.

EDWARD ASHLEY . I live at No. 4, Clifton-villas, Grange-road, about three minutes' walk from the top of Canonbury-street. On Thursday night, 10th April, I went to bed, a few minutes alter 10 o'clock—the window of the dining room was not closed within half an inch—the servant had had the sash down in the day, and we could not get it up—the door of the dining room was locked outside—I was alarmed about hall past 6 o'clock next morning—I went into the dining room, and found the window open wide, and the things in great confusion—some boxes, the cheffonier, and other things, were broken open—there had been two cages there, which had one bird in each; one cage was left, but the bird had been taken out of it, and put into the cage which was missing—that cage was afterwards shown to me, it was mine, and the birds, which had been in my room—I missed two tablecloths, this is one of them—on the Thursday night this was with the other, folded up, and put on a chair in the dining room—I can identify this piece of blue silk, it was in my wife's workbox the night before—my house is in the parish of St. Mary, Islington.

Cross-examined. Q. How can you venture to swear to a bit of silk in your wife's workbox? A. On the afternoon before I was very unwell, lying on the sofa, and my little girl was unpicking this from another piece—I have fitted it, to see that it corresponds—I am a lock manufacturer by business—I mean to say that this was in my wife's box—I have not had this compared with the article it was upon, but I did it in my eye.
COURT. Q. How was the dining room door in the morning? A. It was locked, in the same state as it was the night before—it had not been interfered with.

GUILTY. of stealing only. Aged 21.—
Confined Twelve Months.

503.
JOHN QUAID and
PETER PETERS
, unlawfully assaulting
Henry Ginn, a constable, in the execution of his office.
MESSRS. RYLAND. and LOCKE. conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN FREEMAN VALLER . I am a warehouseman, and live in Poors
terrace, Bath-street, City-road; I am in the employment of Mr. Cowan, a stationer. On 10th March, between 7 and 8 o'clock in the evening, I was standing on Finsbury-pavement, filling my pipe with tobacco—while I was doing that, Peters put his hand round, and struck me on the side of the head—I asked him what he did that for, and Quaid came and hit me on the nose, and knocked

me into the doorway of a public house—he gave me a black eye—I got up and collared Quaid, and said I would hold him till a policeman came—Quaid threw me, but I still held him—Peters came up, and they both punched and kicked me while I was on the ground—I never saw them before—they were not intoxicated—they might have had a trifle to drink, but nothing but what they were capable of taking care of themselves—I dare say there were fifty or sixty persons round me; and some one, I cannot say who it was, pulled Peters off me—I cannot say how long they were beating me about; it seemed a long time to me—they went off, and I followed them—they said they would serve me a great deal worse—I saw the policeman on the oppo
site side—I went and spoke to him, and he came across the road with me—the prisoners were going with the crowd; I should think there were 300 persons—I gave charge of the prisoners—I was bleeding very much from the nose, and some one snatched my handkerchief out of my hand—when I gave charge of Peters, just at the time the policeman collared him, Peters knocked me down, and he began kicking the policeman—Quaid said that he should not take his partner to the station—Quaid was holding the police
man by the collar, and Peters was kicking him—they did that for a long time—I do not know whether they got him down—he got his staff out, and Peters tried to take his staff from him—the policeman was very much hurt—I did not see the prisoners taken to the station, I was obliged to leave; I was so hurt and kicked about that I could not get along so fast as they did—I was taken to the station, and from there to the hospital—I was an out patient for three weeks—I made a charge against the prisoners, and they were looked up, and I was taken to the hospital—I had a black eye—the bridge of my nose was very much bruised, and my face all over blood—before I was struck I had not said a word to the prisoners—I was standing on the pavement, filling my pipe—I was perfectly sober—I had just left work.

Cross-examined by MR. PLATT. Q. They were quite strangers to yon? A. Yes—some person pulled Peters off me—Quaid had got hold of ins then—Peters came up, put his hand round my neck, and slapped me on the face, ai a drunken man would—it appeared to me that this was done by way of a joke—on that I called him a nasty, a—humbug—he did not say, "I could not help it"—they were coming straight along; they were not stag-gering—I was filling my pipe—the tobacco box was not knocked out of my hand—when I had called Peters what I did, Quaid knocked me down—I did not go after them before the blows were struck—Quaid came back, and struck me on the nose—I collared Quaid after that—no nght took place—nothing but the blow on the nose was given me in answer to she language used by me—all the ill usage I got was before I went to the policeman, except one kick on the leg—I do not know where Ginn was when the blows were given to me—the blows were all over before I went to the policeman—I went to him, and said, "Here are two chaps have been insulting me, and kicking me about"—he came across the road, and asked me which they were—I could not get at the prisoners, because the crowd was so great—I pointed to them, and said, "Those are the persons"—he did not refuse to take them because he had not seen the assault—I did not look at Peters' shoes that night, I saw them afterwards at the station: they appear to lace up in front, such as costennongers wear, they were tipped, or hob
nailed.
HENRY GINN . (City policeman, 166). On Monday evening, 10th March, between 7 and 8 o'clock, I was on duty in Moorgate-street, on the left hand

side, going towards the Bank—I saw a great many respectable persons on the opposite side, and very likely some who were not respectable—the last witness came to me—I had not known him before—he complained of being ill used, and he appeared as if he had been ill used—he had blood on his face—I went across with him, and he pointed out the two prisoners, and charged them with having assaulted him—in consequence of his making that charge, I endeavoured to take them—one of them, I cannot say which, struck me in the face—I got hold of Peters, and he began kicking my legs—I did not observe his shoes—they were very violent kicks that he gave my legs—I still persevered in endeavouring to take them, and they kept kicking me—some of the people called out, "Get your truncheon"—some gentleman got it out, and gave it to me—it was taken from me—soon after
wards I saw Ham—I called him, and soon afterwards two policemen came up—after that the prisoners were taken to the station—it took three or four men to take Peters to the station—I had received a great many kicks and bruises on my legs—I was confined to my bed for five weeks—I have been under the doctor's hands ever since—I have not been able to resume my duty—I have suffered a great deal of pain.

Cross-examined. Q. I suppose you have had a great many kicks before? A. Never—those kicks were very violent—I did not see either of the pri
soners assault Valler—I did not refuse to take the prisoner on his state-ment—I asked him whether he meant to give them in charge, and he said, "Yes," and immediately one of them gave me a blow on the face—I do not generally say, "I won't take them without I see the assault committed"—I very often do refuse—I was induced to take these prisoners became Valler had blood on his face—the prisoners had been drinking—I did not say anything to them before I put my hand on Peters—I did not say why I took them—there were several respectable men went to the station, and said that they had seen the witness assaulted—I had not struck the prisoner before these kicks took place; I gave them a slight touch with my staff, it did touch them, I believe, but it did not take effect, the staff dropped from my hand—I went to strike him on the side of the head—some one said, "Take your truncheon," but Peters was kicking me all the time—I have no recollection of Quaid kicking me at all—I do not believe he did kick me.
COURT. Q. Was Quaid holding you? A. He was holding Peters, to try to get him away from me, that I should not take him.

ABRAHAM HAM . I am beadle of St. Stephen's, Coleman-street, and lire in Little Bell-alley. On 10th March, about a quarter past 7 o'clock in the evening, I was crossing Moorgate-street, and saw a large crowd of persons—I crossed to see the cause, and saw Ginn attempting to take the two prisoners—they were struggling with him, and Peters was kicking him—I took Quaid by the collar, and I said if he had done no harm he could not object to go to the station—he took Ginn by the collar—I took hold of Quaid, and kept him at arm's length from Peters—I saw Ginn with his staff, and saw him strike Peters a slight blow on the side of the head—Peters was kicking him very violently at the time, and Ginn called to me, "He has got my truncheon," and I saw it in Peters's hand—Peters said, "It is mine"—I seized Peters by the right wrist, and prevented him from using it, while I had Quaid by the collar—Ginn was nearly exhausted—I saw Peters taken to the station—I went with him—there were four to take him—I got a severe kick on my hand—when at the station I examined Peters's shoes—they were tipped at the heels, and had hobnails at the front, enough to kill a man with a kick.
Cross-examined. Q. Were the prisoners drunk? A. Quaid was not very drunk, Peters was rather drunk, but he was sober enough to say, "It is mine," when he had got the staff.

GEORGE TAYLOR . I am a waterman at the cab stand in Moorgate-street. I was there on 10th March, in the evening—I saw the prisoners coming towards Moorgate-street, and Valler was standing on the pavement—Peters put his hand round his neck, and slapped his face—Valler came I beck to speak to them, and Quaid shoved Peters on one side, and struck Valler—there was a struggle, and they both fell on the pavement—I did not see much more—I saw Peters interfere, and they all went on the pave
ment, and one of the bystanders pulled Peters from him.

JOHN MILLER . (City policeman, 99). I was in Moorgate-street, and saw Ginn struggling with the two prisoners—I took Quaid into custody—he kicked me a violent kick on the leg immediately I laid hold of him—we struggled violently together, and got on the pavement; he got up again—I got assistance and got him to the station—both the prisoners were very violent indeed.

EDWARD MITCHELL . (City policeman, 126). I was called to assist Ginn—he was very much exhausted, and had lost his hat in the struggle—I assisted in taking Peters—he was very violent indeed, I had to strap his legs with my belt, and while doing so he kicked me on the head—it took four men to take him.

CHARLES SWALET SMITH . I am assistant to Mr. Child, the surgeon to the police. I first saw Ginn on the night that this occurred, he was in bed, and his legs were in a very inflamed state—he had been kicked very much about the shins, and was suffering acute pain, so much so that he could not bear the clothes on his legs—the skin was off in several parts—he has been prevented from going on duty till now, and will be for some time.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

QUAID—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Four Months.

PETERS—
GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Seven Months.

div0.p: OLD COURT.—Tuesday, May 13th, 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. HUMPHERY.; Mr. Ald. FARHCOMB.; Mr. RECORDER.; and Mr. Ald. WIRE.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Second Jury.

div1.p:
504.
RICHARD REYNOLDS
, stealing on 1st April, 1 lens, value 16l.; the goods of
George Herbert Watkins, his master; also, 2 lenses, value 3l. 15s., of
George Fenton, his master; also, obtaining 2 lenses, value 30l., from
Fallow Home, by false pretences: to all which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Judgment Respited.

505.
HENRY MITCHELL
, feloniously being at large before the expi
ration of his sentence: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

506.
JOHN FORD and
WILLIAM TAYLOR
, stealing 1 ring and 2 lockets, value 15l.; the goods of
Benjamin Worthy Home, and another, the masters of Ford.
MR. BALLANTINE. conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN DEATH . I am assistant to Mr. William Mott, silversmith, of Cheap
side. On 17th April, I packed up a diamond ring, and two small lockets, in a wooden box, wrapped the box in two brown papers, sealed it at both ends, and addressed it to Mrs. Rendall, Pier-terrace, Ryde, Isle of Wight—I I gave the parcel to William Griffiths—they were worth about 14l.; the lockets had been repaired, and the ring remounted.
WILLIAM GRIFFITHS . I am in Mr. Mott's employment. On 17th April I took the parcel delivered to me by Death, to the Cross Keys, and left it there in the booking office.
GEORGE HIBBITT . I am porter at the Cross Keys. I received a parcel from Griffiths, and laid it with other parcels in the place intended for the Southampton Railway—I never saw it again.

Ford. Q. How many parcels did Howard have that night; what num
ber did he make? A. I cannot say—Howard is in the employ of the Southampton Railway Company, and comes to the office for the parcels—he came for them on that evening—I cannot say how many he had that even
ing, there is a book in which they are entered; it is not here, it is at the office; it is kept by Mr. Underdown.
THOMAS HOWARD . I took the parcels from the Cross Keys on 17th—I took forty-six parcels—I took them to the South Western Railway, Water-loo-road.

Ford. Q. How many parcels did you make that night when you left the office? A. I told Mr. Underdown that I had forty-three from over the counter, and three on this side the counter, making forty-six—Mr. Under
down said I ought to have had forty-seven; forty-four from the counter, and three boxes on this side the counter.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you quite sure you only took forty-six? A. Forty-six—Mr. Underdown called my attention at the time to the fact that there ought to have been forty-seven.

COURT. Q. What did you say? A. I said I had but forty-six, but I could not count them there, as I had intermixed them with the other par-cels from the Swan with Two Necks—it was a very busy night with us—I took them up two or three at the time—I keep account of them—I do not enter them in any book.

CHARLES UNDERDOWN . I am book keeper to Benjamin Worthy Horne and another, at the Cross Keys, Cheapside. They are carriers in connection with the railway—Ford was in their employment as a porter—his duty wai to sleep in the office nightly, and to assist generally throughout the day—Taylor was a sort of stable man, not in the employment of the firm, but assisting the foreman in the yard—when parcels are delivered at our office for the purpose of being transmitted by rail, they are placed in different partitions allotted to certain lines of railway—those partitions are not on the counter, but at the further end of the office, not open to persons coming to the office; they would be open to a man in Ford's position, and to the servants there—the compartment under the counter was for the Eastern Counties' parcels—forty-seven parcels ought to have gone by Howard on the 17th April; he only collects for the South Western—on the following day he called to say that he was a parcel short, and on the second day Mr. Mott's assistant called, and then I learned what the parcel was—it was known to be missing the next day when Howard called, but I made it officially known to all the persons in the office on the Saturday afternoon, including Ford—I mentioned that it contained a ring—I do not think I mentioned the lockets—I am certain Ford was present.

Ford. Q. When Howard had his bill who gave him the answer? you or Mr. Pollard? A. Mr. Pollard, to the best of my belief; he ia my junior clerk—I cannot say how many parcels Howard said he had; Mr. Pollard told me next morning that he understood Howard to make forty-seven—I was busy at the time, and did not notice; Mr. Pollard made the entry in the book—they are called out by one of the porters, Sidey was the porter who called them out that day—he is at the office.

SAMUEL EVANS . (City policeman, 459).
