On Monday, 21st April, I went with Legg to the Cross Keys, in Wood-street—I found Ford standing at the door of the booking office—I was in plain clothes—I went with him into the office, told him I was a police officer, and said, "I suppose you are aware of the loss of a parcel that was to be sent to the Isle of Wight?"—he said, "I have heard of it, but I know nothing about it"—I said, "It contained a diamond ring and a gold locket"—he said, "I have not seen it"—I said, "Have you not had a diamond ring in your possession within these last few days?"—he replied, "No"—I said, "Have you not given a diamond ring to a person I to dispose of within the last few days?"—he said, "No"—I said, "Recollect yourself," and after a pause, I said, "Am I to understand that you know nothing whatever about a diamond ring and a gold locket?"—he said, "I know nothing whatever about it"—I waited in the office, and after a time Taylor came in—I told him I was a police officer, and said, "Have you not been trying to dispose of a diamond ring?"—he said, "Yes"—(Ford was present and heard what passed)—I said, "Have you got it in your posses
sion?"—he said, "Yes," and produced it—this is it—I said, "Who gave you this ring?"—he said, "A friend"—I told him look round, and see if that friend was present—he then said, "Yes, Ford gave it me"—Ford made no remark—Taylor answered all the questions very readily.

WILLIAM JAMES MITCHELL . (City police inspector). In consequence of being sent for by Ford, I went to the cell in which he was confined—he said he wished to make a statement to me—I told him that whatever statement he made must be entirely voluntary, and that I should make use of it, and asked if he had well considered the matter—he said he wished to give me the full particulars—he said that when he left the office at about 20 minutes after 8 o'clock on the 17th, in passing up Wood-street, he kicked his toe against a small parcel, that he picked it up and put it into his pocket, with
out examining the contents; that upon his return to the office about a quarter past 9 o'clock he examined the parcel, and found it to contain a diamond ring, and two gold lockets; that he said nothing about it to any one until the Saturday, and he then asked Taylor if he could dispose of it for him; he said that Mr. Mott appeared very anxious to have the lockets, and he could tell me where they were concealed, they were his between the rafters and the tiles in the hay loft of the stable in Wood-street—I sent an officer there—Ford also said that on the night in question he had counted, out forty-seven parcels, and he was not aware that this was one of them, because there was no mark on it, and all their parcels were numbered.

GEORGE LEGG . (City policeman, 440). In consequence of directions from Mr. Mitchell, I went to a loft over the stable in the Cross Keys yard, and between the rafters and the tiles I found these two lockets (produced)—this book was found on Ford by Evans at the station.

CHARLES UNDERDOWN . re-examined. All the parcels are numbered when they are called out—it was Sidey's duty to number them that night—if there was a number on, it would show at once that it belonged to the office—the box has never been traced—I know Ford's writing—this "Rendall, Ryde," in this book is his.
(MR. BALLANTINE. here withdrew from the case as to Taylor, who was acquitted.)

WILLIAM TAYLOR . (the prisoner). I was employed jobbing about the yard—I received this diamond ring from Ford on Monday—he told me that a female gave it to him whom be knew, in York-street, by Astley's theatre that a gentleman had made it a present to her, and that she gave it to him—I made this same statement before the Magistrate.
JOHN DEATH . re-examined. This is the ring, and these are the lockets—one of Mr. Mott's shop cards was inside the paper.

JOHN POLLARD . I asked Howard how many parcels he had on this night, and he said forty-four, and three boxes on the other side made forty-seven—I booked the parcels that afternoon, Sidey called them over—nothing was said that night about there being one less than the number, but next morn
ing Howard called and said he was one short for Ryde, a small one—I asked him how he knew it was a small one, and when I referred to the book I found it was "Carriage paid, 1s.,"so be knew it must have been under seven pounds.

THOMAS HOWARD . re-examined. have heard what Mr. Pollard has said, it is false—I had forty-three parcels from the counter—I did not tell him I had forty-four—I thought it was Mr. Underdown who said I ought to have forty-four; I understood it was his voice over the counter, but we were so busy I could not see.

Ford's Defence. On leaving the office in Wood-street, at 20 minutes past 8 o'clock on the evening of 17th April, about thirty yards from the door, I picked up a small parcel; I could not see the address, as it was completely covered with mud; I put it into my pocket, and on going to the office at 20 minutes past 9 o'clock I opened it, and found it contained a ring and two lockets; I did not hear any inquiry about it till Monday, when a gentleman from Mr. Mott's came to inquire about it; Taylor is perfectly innocent of how I came possessed of it; I am the only party con
oerned; I am not guilty of stealing it, but I found it as I say. (Ford received a good character.)

FORD—
GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Four Years Penal Servitude.

TAYLOR—
NOT GUILTY .

507.
JOHN GRIFFITHS
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwell
ing house of
Thomas Tomlinson, and stealing a looking glass, work box, snuff box, and brooch, value 13s.; his property.
MR. HORRY. conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN CARTY . I am a labourer, and live in the house of Mr. Tomlinson, a fishmonger, No. 71, Lower Thames-street Between 3 and 4 o'clock on. Sunday morning, 20th April, I had occasion to come down stairs to the water closet, and found a man bursting out through the window on to a bench underneath, it—the house stands up a passage, and the window faces the street—I pursued the man, calling "Stop thief!"—I did not see his face, only his back, but I never lost sight of him till I left the constable in pursuit of him and then both the man and the constable got out of my sight—to the best of my belief, the prisoner is the man; he is the man that was brought back—I could not swear to him, because I did not see his face, but he resembles the man in size and dress—I after
wards examined the window, it was open, the lower part slides up, two panes of glass were broken, and two nails which fastened down the sash were removed.
Prisoner. Q. What distance were you from where the man jumped out
of the window? A. About one pace—he came out on his hands and knees, which prevented my fleeing his face, and ran down the passage, and I after him.

JOSEPH TOMKINS . (City policeman, 587). A little before 4 o'clock on Sun
day morning, 20th April, I was in Lower Thames-street—I heard the breaking of glass—I went to No. 71, I waited two or three minutes, and saw the prisoner come out of the court—I pursued him along Thames-street—I lost sight of him for about half a minute on Tower-hill, I sprang my rattle, and after I turned the corner of the rails round the Tower ditch, I saw him ia the hands of H 75—he was not half a minute out of my sight—I had seen him during the night, about 1 o'clock, in company with another man, standing very near the court; I watched them away, and they went towards London-bridge—I afterwards saw him again, about 3 o'clock, coming out of Harp-lane into Thames-street, that is about fifty yards from the prosecutor's premises.
Prisoner. Q. Whereabouts were you standing when you say I came I down the court? A. I was about two yards from the court when you ran out—you ran faster than me, or I should have laid hold of you.

WILLIAM STARTIN . (policeman, H 75). On Sunday morning, 20th April, About a quarter to 4 o'clock, I was in Trinity-square, Tower-hill, and heard the springing of a rattle—I turned, and saw the prisoner running across Tower-hill, towards the Mint, in a direction from Lower Thames-street—I stopped him, he was out of breath—Tomkins came up in about half a minute, and recognised him—I searched him—before I did so, he gave me 6d. and a lucifer match when I asked what he had got about him.

CHARLES BUTTON . (City policemen, 569). A little before 4 o'clock on Sunday morning I was on duty in Lower Thames-street, and heard a cry of "Stop thief!"—I went to No. 71, Lower Thames-street, and saw Carty—I picked up this looking glass on a bench under the window—two panes of the lower sash of that window were broken, near the fastening—I found a work box and a snuff box outside—I called Mrs. Tomlinson and her son up, and then examined the room—I found one of the drawers open, and some things that were taken from it, on the window ledge—I found this screw-driver outside in the street, and some lucifer matches about fifty yards from the passage in Thames-street, nearer to Tower-hill—this snuff box, brooch, and pair of tweezers were picked up in Thames-street—I also found a piece of candle in the court—the matches correspond with the one which the prisoner had on him.

THOMAS TOMLINSON . I am a fishmonger, at No. 71, Lower Thames-street, in the parish of St. Dunstan in the East I was not at home on the night in question, my son and my wife were in the house—these articles (produced) are mine—I lost a silk handkerchief altogether, from a drawer that was not locked.

THOMAS CHARLES TOMLIKSON . I am the son of the last witness. I went to bed at a quarter to 11 o'clock on 19th April—before doing so I examined the window of the ground floor room—it was fastened with two nails, quite secure—I saw some of these things on the sideboard, in front of the window, and some were in the drawers—the handkerchief that is lost was in a drawer—I saw it there about 8 o'clock on Saturday evening, and also a sixpence in the work box—the street door was not fastened—I locked the room door, and had the key—I found it still locked in the morning.
CHARLES BUTTON . re-excmined. There was no sixpence in the box when I found it.

Prisoner's Defence. On the night of the robbery I went to Drury-lane Theatre, and fell in company with a young man, a sailor, who said he was steward on board a ship; we went to a public house, and met a friend of his, and went to his house, where we remained till about 3 o'clock in the morning; we then came away, and, coming along Drury-lane, there was a disturbance, and I missed the young man; I thought I could meet with him by the Docks or Blackwall, and, crossing Tower-hill, the policeman stopped me; he says I was out of breath, but it was a severe cold I had.

GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Confined Twelve Months.

508.
ROBERT WATSON
, stealing 10 printed books, value 10l.; the goods of
William Daniel Henry Ochme.
MR. DENNY. conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES THOMAS . I am clerk to Messrs. Ochme and Lloyd, solicitors No. 124, Bishopsgate-street; they have also a place of business at Calcutta, On 8th April I was in the back office on the second floor, near 2 o'clock in the day, and heard footsteps crossing the landing; I went on to the landing and saw the prisoner descending the stairs, with a large canvass bag on his shoulder, apparently heavy—I went into the front room, and missed ten volumes of Bittlewood's "Conveyancing Precedents" from the shelves—I immediately pursued the prisoner, and overtook him at the bottom of the second flight of stairs—I called out, "Drop them; I have got you"—he immediately dropped it, and ran off—I pursued him about fifty yards, and, after a considerable struggle, brought him back, sent for a policeman, and gave him into custody—the books were lying on the mat; they were the pro
perty of Mr. Ochme, which I had missed—when I brought the prisoner back, he said, "You had better let me go, and go after the other man; he is going up the street"—I saw no other man.

CHARLES BROWN . (City policeman, 654). The prisoner was given into my custody; I found on him 5d. in copper, and 6d. in silver—on taking him to the lock-up, he said, "I was in a public house in Houndsditch, and met a gentleman there, who said he wanted something moved from his office; he took me to the house in question, in Bishopsgate-street, took me to the second floor, into an office, and, pointing to the books in question, he said, 'Take these, and follow me;' I took the books, and followed the gentleman, and when I got down stairs the last witness ran after me and collared me."
(The prisoner, in Ms defence, repeated the statement he had made to the officer.)

GUILTY . Aged 59.—
Confined Six Months.

509.
THOMAS KEMP and
EMMA SAGE
, stealing 1 pocket book: to which

KEMP
PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined Twelve Months.

MR. RYLAND. offered no evidence against SAGE.—
NOT GUILTY .

510.
ANN PRICE
, stealing 1 shawl; the goods of
Sarah Egerton.
MR. PLATT. conducted the Prosecution.

SARAH EGERTON . I am servant at the King's Arms Inn, Uxbridge. On 8th April I had a shawl—I hung it up in the taproom at half past 2 o'clock, and missed it a little before 4—this (produced) is it—the prisoner was in the taproom that day for three or four hours, and left about half past 3 o'clock, by the bus.
Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Did you know her at all? A. No; I never saw her before that day—I was not in the habit of lending my shawl to any one.

JAMES WESTON . I am assistant to Mr. Davis, a pawnbroker, at Uxbridge. On 8th April, between 3 and 4 o'clock, the prisoner pawned this shawl—she asked 3s., and took 1s.—I had seen her at the shop before—the proeecutrix I afterwards came, and claimed it.

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Confined Two Months.

511.
JOHN M'KENLEY,
JAMES RANDS , and
JOSEPH OAKENFULL
, robbery on
William Fudge, and stealing 3l. 10s.; his moneys.
MR. SLEIGH. conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM FUDGE . I am a carpenter and builder, and live at No. 26, Sale-street, Edgware-road. On Tuesday, 1st April, before 12 o'clock, I went to the Rose and Crown public house, in Burn-street—I remained there until between 3 and 4 o'clock—I went there to see a person on business—I had 3l. 10s. Of with me in gold, and 3s. 6d. in silver—I am quite positive I had it safe while I was there—I had a portion of some drink there—I was there, I should say, an hour and a half, or more, before I saw any of the prisoners—my friend and I went into the skittle ground, and played—there were various parties there who were acquainted with me—somewhere about 2 o'clock the prisoners came in—they each came in separately—Bands wanted to force me to bet, and I would not—I was going to the bar to get some spirits, when Rands caught me by the collar, and said, "You shan't go, for you owe me a shilling"—the other prisoners were present—I had betted a penny or two with some parties on the ground; I do not know who they were; I did not bet with either of the prisoners that I know of—I had not played with either of them, only with my two friends, Breewood and Henley—when Rands collared me, each of the other prisoners held me in a position that I could scarcely tell what they were about; they threw me across a rail, and held me, whilst one of them got his hand into my left hand pocket, and took out the money—I could not say who it was that rifled my pockets, because I was lying with my back across the rail, and my head down—I felt somebody's hand in my pocket, and they took my money out—I am quite sure that the three prisoners were engaged in holding me down at that time—they then left me, and escaped.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Have you been drinking to
day? A. have not; I have had a glass of porter; nothing beyond that—on this afternoon I had been drinking, perhaps, for about two hours, not all the time; I was both eating and drinking—I called there to see Breewood on some business that he was transacting for me—I will swear I had not betted or lost a shilling to anybody before this occurred—perhaps I have had two or three glasses of porter to-day, nothing else; I do not believe I have had any ale; I had one glass before I left Paddington—I have had no spirits—I swear that—I had some rum at the public house on the day in question; we had half a pint between three of us; nothing else, except a beet steak.

GEORGE GIBBS . I am a labourer, at No. 28, Praed-street, Paddington. I was at the Rose and Crown on this afternoon, and saw Mr. Fudge there, playing skittles with several persons, in fours—he played with Rands—the other two prisoners were sitting in the ground; I had not seen them with Rands—I saw Fudge attempt to go out of the ground; Rands laid hold of him by the collar, and thrust him back into the skittle ground, and said he owed him a shilling, what he had betted—Fudge said, "I owe you no shilling"—Rands said, "You do"—Fudge said he did not, and Rands backed him into the skittle ground by the collar—the other two prisoners were then in the ground; there were four of them altogether; one has not been taken—Fudge was backed across the bar—M'Kenley laid hold of him by

the throat, and held him down, while the man who is not in custody put his hand into his pocket, and Bands and Oakenfull held him by the legs—I could not see what was taken oat of his pocket—after it was taken, three of the men disappeared—M'Kenley did not go; he never went away from the house.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear Fudge challenge Rands to play at skittles? A. No, I was not there when they first began to play—Rands challenged Fudge to play—I believe they played three games single handed, for a pint or a quart of porter a game—Rands insisted that Fudge owed him 1s.—I am able to say he did not owe it him—Rands tried to get him to bet, but he would not bet, he simply played for beer—I believe Rands is a shoe
maker by trade—I did not see him come in with any shoes, or any parcel, I believe he came for a parcel—he got a parcel from the landlord; that was the first thing in the morning when he came in—I had never seen him before—I have seen the other prisoners frequently in the street, not in the skittle ground.

COURT. Q. When did you first give any information about this? A. I did not give any until I was accused of being one of the thieves, that was about half past 10 o'clock that night—I did not know that I was bound to give information—I am no thieftaker, I was in dread, of course—the prosecutor ran away out of the skittle ground after he was robbed, and gave no in
formation.

FREDERICK COOK . (police sergeant, D 1). On Tuesday night, 1st April, in consequence of information from Fudge, about a quarter past 10 o'clock, I went to Whitechapel, and met M'Kenley in Chapel-street, coming from the direction of the Rose and Crown, where the robbery had been com
mitted—I followed him, Gibbs came up and said, "That is one of the men"—I then went up to him, and said, "You must go to the station with me"—he said, "What for?"—I said, "For committing a robbery on a person at the Burn's Arms skittle ground"—I thought that was the name of the house at that time—he said, "Who told you I was one of them?"—I said, "You will see that when you get to the station"—I took him there—he was the worse for liquor—the prosecutor had been drinking, but he was perfectly aware of what he was stating, he appeared to be like a man who had been asleep for two or three hours, stupified—on the Wednesday, I went to No. 59, Seymour-place—I found Rands there, in a shoemaker's shop, with his name over the door, he was at work behind the counter—I said, "You must go to the station with me for being concerned in a robbery at the Burn's Arms"—he said, "That is a very unpleasant affair, for I wanted to get these boots home to-night"—on the road to the station he said, "Are they going to make me a witness or a prisoner?"—I said, "I have already made you a prisoner"—I then took him to the station, and fetched the prosecutor and Gibbs, who identified him as one of the party.
Cross-examitied. Q. You found Rands working at hit shop? A. Yes; it is a small shop—there were some children there; he seemed surprised.

SILVESTER THRUSH . (policeman, D 190). On the Monday after the rob
bery, I went in company with sergeant Cook to No. 17, Sadler's-place, London-wall—I saw Oakenfull there, and his brother, standing at the foot of the stairs—Cook told him he must consider himself in custody for being concerned with three others in robbing a man at the Burn's Arms—he said, "That is what I expected"—he was taken to the station and identified by the witnesses.
GEORGE BRIMACOMBE . (police inspector, D). When M'Kenley was brought

I to the station, I reduced the charge against him to writing, and read it out to him—I told him he was charged with robbing William Fudge, in the Rose and Crown public house, of 3l. 10s. in gold—he said nothing—the pro
secutor came to me about half past 4 o'clock on the day of the robbery, and told me he had been robbed, and the men who had robbed him were then at the public house—I immediately sent Hammond, a constable, with him, and he returned in about half an hour, saying they were all gone.

WILLIAM FUDGE . re-examined. At the time this happened, I was in a I state to know what I was about—I went first to the Paddington station, that was a few minutes afterwards, as soon as I could recover myself—they referred me to the station in John-street—I did not call on the landlord or I anybody, to seize the persons who had been robbing me—I could not, I was thrown across the rail, I was in bed for two days—I could not call out; when I got up they were all gone—I hurried off to the nearest police station—I can swear I had my money safe at 1 o'clock in the day—the gold I was in my left pocket and the silver in my right.

---- HAMMOND. (policeman, D 47). I went with the prosecutor, and Tice, another constable, to the Rose and Crown—he did not point out any one there—I took him into the skittle ground, and he said they were all gone—I saw the landlord, and he said they were all gone—he did not know anything about the robbery till I told him of it—I do not recollect seeing M'Kenley in the house, there were five or six persons in the skittle ground (The prisoners received good characters.)
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: NEW COURT.—Tuesday, May 13th, 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. HUMPHREY.; Mr. Ald. SIDHEY.; Mr. Ald. FINNIS.; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Seventh Jury.

div1.p:
512.
CHARLES DAVIS
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Confined nine Months.

513.
CHARLES JACKSON was indicted
for a like offence: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 30,—
Confined Nine Months.

514.
GEORGE PUNSHER, alias Gates
,
feloniously uttering counterfeit coin: having been before convicted: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Four Years Penal Servitude.

515.
JOHN FITZGERALD, alias Jones
, was indicted
for a like offence: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Four Years Penal Servitude.

516.
WILLIAM LEGRAVE
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MESSRS. ELLIS. and BODKIN. conducted the Prosecution.

HARRIET KNIGHT . My husband keeps a shop in St. Martin's-lane. On 20th March, between 3 and 4 o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner came for a pair of boots—I told him the price was 4s. 6d., and he left—he came back in a short time, chose a pair, and gave me a 5s. piece—I gave him a sixpence, and put the crown in my pocket—I had no other crown—I went to a public house, and asked for change for it—the barman put it into the tester, and told me it was bad—I brought it back—it had not been out of

my sight at all—on Saturday, the 22nd, the prisoner was pointed out to me in Newport-market, with two others—I went to him, and said that I wanted him to come with me—he said he could not come—I said he had better come to my husband, he knew what I wanted him for—Mr. Benson, who was with me, told him that he knew he was a notorious smasher, and he had better go with me—the prisoner went with me to my husband's shop—my husband said he would have him locked up—the prisoner said he supposed he did not want to have him locked up, and he would pay him the 5s., he had not got the money then, but he would leave his coat, and come on the following Monday—he left his coat, and came on the following Mon
day, and took it away, and paid the crown—the bad crown was broken up by Mr. Benson—I gave one piece to the policeman, and one piece is lost.

MARY ANN DAY . I am barmaid at the Hand in Hand, in Holborn On 2nd April the prisoner came, about 2 or 3 o'clock in the afternoon—he asked for 1 1/2 d. worth of shrub and a screw of tobacco—they came to 2d., he gave me a shilling, I gave him change, and he left the bar—I put the shilling in the till—there was no other shilling there, only three 4d. pieces—I had cleared out the till just before—after he was gone, something was said to me, and I looked at the shilling, and it was bad—a customer, Mr. Ridding, went after the prisoner, and brought him back—in trying the shilling Mr. Bidding, had bent it—the prisoner said he was not aware it was bad—a constable came in, and I gave him the shilling—it had not been out of my sight.
WILLIAM BASS . (policeman, E 154). I went into the Hand in Hand, took the prisoner, and got this shilling from the last witness, and this part of a crown from Mrs. Knight.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. This shilling and part of a crown are both bad.
Prisoners Defence. The witness gave me a sixpence and a 4d. piece in change; I never saw the 5s. piece from the first time I passed it.

GUILTY .** Aged 23.—
Confined Twelve Months.

517.
EDWARD FELLOWS was indicted
for a like offence.
MESSRS. ELLIS. and BODKIN. conducted the Prosecution.

ELIZABETH BURTON . I am the wife of Thomas Burton, he keeps an eating house in Bakers-row, Whitechapel. On 24th April the prisoner came, in the afternoon, for 1d. worth of pudding and a saveloy—they came to 2d.—he gave me a 2s. piece; I passed it to my husband, who was stepping from the parlour into the shop.

THOMAS BURTON . I saw the prisoner in my shop—my wife served him, and she gave me a florin, I examined it, and found it was bad—I asked the prisoner where he got it, he said, "By selling things in the street"—I was not satisfied, and sent for a policeman, marked the florin, and gave it him.
Prisoner. You said in your deposition that you were in the shop by the side of your wife. Witness. was just coming from the parlour into the shop—I had only three or four yards to come.

DANIEL SMITH . (policeman, K 415). The prisoner was given into my custody—I took him to Worship-street on the 24th—there was no other charge against him, and he was discharged on the 25th—he gave the name of George Chapman, but refused to give any address—this is the 2s. piece.

TRYPHENA MINER . My father is a baker, and lives in High-street, Shad
well On 29th April the prisoner came, about 8 o'clock in the evening, for a half-quartern loaf—I served him—it came to 4d., he gave me a 2s. piece,
I gave him 1s. 8d.—he went out of the shop, walking fast—I kept the 2s. piece in my hand—I asked my mother if it was good, she said it was bad—I went and fetched the prisoner back.
JURY. Q. Had you put the florin in the till? A. No, had kept it in my hand.

FRANCIS RUSHTON . (policeman, K 113). I apprehended the prisoner—I got this 2s. piece from the last witness—there was only 1s. 8d. found on him—he gave the name of Edward Fellows, Brick-lane, Spitalfields.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are both bad.

Prisoners Defence. On the 24th I sold my rings and bracelets, and went to get the pudding and the saveloy; I put down the 2s. piece, and it was bad; I was discharged, and was working on the highway; a woman asked me to go and get the loaf; she gave me the florin; I came out, and was looking about for the woman, and the witness came and gave me into custody.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

518.
THOMAS WILLIAMS was indicted
for a like offence.
MESSRS. ELLIS. and BODKIN. conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLOTTE ANN WALTON . I keep a greengrocer's shop, at Old Brentford. On the morning of 19th April the prisoner came for a pottle of potatoes—they came to 2d., he gave me a shilling—I gave him change, a sixpence and four penny pieces—I said to him, "This it rather a slippery shilling"—he said that it was good—I put the shilling just inside the drawer, but not with the other money—he left, and I tried the shilling directly, and fetched him back—I told him it was bad—he gave me another shilling, and that was bad—I bit them both, and returned them to him—I sent to the station, and gave the prisoner into custody.

EDWARD TALBOT . I was in Mrs. Walton's shop on the 19th—I saw the prisoner there—Mrs. Walton had got a shilling in her hand—she hit it, and said, "This is bad, too"—the prisoner gave her a sixpence—I was present when the prisoner was searched—there were two bad shillings found on him, and 43. or 5d. in copper.

RICHARD CROUCHER . (policeman, T 130). I was on duty at Brentford—I followed the prisoner, took him, and found on him these two bad shillings, four penny pieces, two halfpence, two farthings, and one pocket piece—I found him at his own lodging, two doors from the prosecutrix's—he had only lodged there one night.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are both bad. Prisoner's Defence. I did not know the money was bad.
NOT GUILTY .

519.
JOHN JONES was indicted
for a like offence.
MESSRS. ELLIS. and BODKIN. conducted the Prosecution.

SARAH MONK . My husband keeps the Fox and Hounds, at Brentford. Last Thursday I saw the prisoner at my bar door—he asked for 1 1/2 d. worth of gin, and gave me a sixpence—I gave him 4 1/2 d. in change, laid the sixpence down on the counter, and gave him the halfpence—he put them into his pocket, and went away—I just put the sixpence into the till, but did not mix it with other money—I took it out again in less than two minutes—I am sure what I took out was the same—it was bad—I laid it on one of the shelves, separate from other money—I marked it, and gave it to him.

SUSANNAH LOGSDELL . My father keeps a public house at Old Brentford. last Thursday the prisoner came, and asked for 1 1/2 d. worth of gin—he gave me a sixpence—I gave him a 4d. piece and one halfpenny in change—he

drank tlie gin and went away—J put the sixpence into a small box inside the till, where, if I take money of a stranger, I always put it—I put this sixpence into the box, and there was no other money there—a man came in afterwards, and spoke to me—I looked at the sixpence, and gave it after
wards to a policeman.

SARAH HARDING . My husband keeps the Prince of Wales, at Old Brentford. The prisoner came, last Thursday, for 1 1/2 d. worth of gin—I served him, he gave me a bad sixpence—I had got the change in my band, but I had not given it to the prisoner—a policeman came in, he took the sixpence from the place where I laid it—I am sure it was the one the prisoner gave me.

WILLIAM CRASKE . (policeman, T 125). A young man called me, and went into the Prince of Wales last Thursday, about 3 o'clock—I found the prisoner standing at the bar—the last witness told me he had passed a bad sixpence—the sixpence was lying on the counter, and she took it and gave it into my hand—I took the prisoner—I searched him at the station—I found on him 5 1/2 d. in copper and a 4d. piece—I received these other two sixpences from the other witnesses:
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These three sixpences are all bad, and two of tham are from the same mould.

Prisoner. I did utter the sixpences, but not knowing they were coun
terfeit
GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Nine Months.

520.
HENRY TRUEMAN and
BENJAMIN HOUGH
, stealing 10 cwt. of coals, value 12s.; the goods of
Thomas Freeman, their masters.
MR. ORRIDGE. conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLES CHANNON . I am clerk to Mr. Thomas Freeman, of Blackfrian
wharf, Blackfriars—the prisoners were in his employ. On 3rd May I sent them with ten tons of coals to Mr. Wheeler, in Hyde-park-gardens, seven tons first and then three tons—Trueman, the carman, and Hough, his trouncer, left the yard with a waggon, with three tons, about a quarter past 9 o'clock—I saw them go—there were thirty sacks in the waggon, con
taining each two cwt, or 224lbs. of coals—from what I heard afterwards the prisoners were given into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Did you see the coals put into the waggon? A. I saw them in the waggon when they went out, and I counted the sacks in the waggon—there were ten sacks down the side, and three across, which made thirty—I gave the ticket for that number—Trueman had been with us about two years—during that time he has borne a good character.

ALFRED JAMES GURR . I am butler to Mrs. Wheeler, of Hyde-paik-gardens. On 3rd May some coals were brought to our house—my mistress opened the window, and asked Trueman, the carman, if he had three tons of coals, he said, "Yes"—she asked if he had thirty sacks, he said, "Yes"—my mistress and I watched them, and on shooting two or three sacks, an empty sack turned up—it was taken out by Trueman, and put on the others—in the course of shooting a few more, four more empty sacks turned up, and were put on the others—twenty-five full sacks were shot, and five empty sacks were placed by the side of them—Mrs. Wheeler opened the window, and said, "You have not brought thirty sacks of coals"—Trueman said, "Yes, I have"—she said, "You have not, twenty-five sacks were full, and five were empty"—Hough came into the house afterwards—I told him it was a serious affair, and Mrs. Wheeler would have to go to Mr. Freeman
about it—there were only twenty-five sacks of coals—he said he knew nothing of it—Mrs. Wheeler went down to Mr. Freeman.

Cross-examimd. Q. Did not Hough say, if it were not right, if you would give him the ticket, he would have it made right at the office? A. No, he asked me for the ticket, and I told him I could not give it him, on account of the coals not being the proper quantity.
THOMAS TRIM . (City policeman, 69). I took Trueman into custody, on Saturday, 3rd May, about half past 3 o'clock in the afternoon.
CHABLES BUCKTHORPE . (City policeman, 318) I took Hough into custody on Saturday evening, 3rd May—I told him the charge—he said he was not responsible for it, he was servant to the carman.

MR. METCALFE. to ALFRED JAMES GURR. Q. Did Trueman ask you to have the coals weighed? A. That was not said in my hearing—I asked my mistress, and she said she did not hear it—I could not say whether there was a weighing machine in the waggon—my mistress and I were both standing at the window, which was open.

TRUEMAN—
GUILTY . Aged 36.—Recommended to mercy by the jury,—
Confined Nine Months.

HOUGH—
NOT GUILTY .

521.
JEAN BEAMONT
, stealing 1 porte monnaie and an order for 20s.; the property of
Hannah Helena Baglehole, from her person.
MR. LILLEY. conducted the Prosecution.

HANNAH HELENA BAGLEHOLE . I am a widow, and reside at Keppel-place, Brompton. On 3rd April, about 20 minutes before 3 o'clock in the afternoon, I got into a Royal Blue omnibus in Billiter-street—I was going to Pimlioo—the prisoner got into the omnibus after I was seated—he sat next to me, on my right side—I had my pocket on my right side—the omnibus was crowded—after the prisoner got in I was annoyed by his pressing against me—I endeavoured to get from him, but he still followed me, and pressed against me—he raised up my drees on my right side, and picked my pocket of my purse—I had my purse safe when I got into the omnibus, at the bottom of my pocket—I carried the money to pay for the omnibus in my hand—there was in my purse a Post-office order far 1l.—after the prisoner had taken up my dress I wished to leave, and I desired a man to stop the omnibus, and the moment I was going to leave, the prisoner had fastened his hand in my pocket, and tore the gathers out of my drew—I said, "You have picked my pocket"—he has a very large hand, and he dropped the purse at the right side—I did not see him throw it down, but he had his hand in a position to cover the purse—I was considerably agitated, and so I am now—the prisoner ran away, I ran after him; he crossed the road, and went between the coaches—the conductor pursued him, and he was taken—he said, "Pray don't give me in charge; look at me, look at me"—I did not wish to give him in charge, but a gentleman desired me to do so, for the benefit of the public—this is my purse, the one I had in my pocket—my son Charles had it all the time he was in Calcutta, and I covered it with a piece of my dress.

Crost-excmmed by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you quite sure that the prisoner put his hand into your pocket? A. Yes, because it was fastened there when I rose up—he looked at me in a particular manner—I did not see him drop the purse.

GEORGE STEER . I am a commercial clerk. I was in the omnibus at the time the prosecutrix was there, 3rd April—I sat opposite the prisoner—I observed his conduct, he seemed to sit very uneasily—a gentleman next to

me drew my attention to him—I observed he was very shuffling, and while I was so noticing him the lady wished to get out, and accused him of picking her pocket—I did not see him drop the purse, but I saw it on the floor of the omnibus where he sat, next to the lady—the prisoner is the man who was there.

THOMAS DELANTLEY . (City policeman, 493), I was on duty on that day in Cheapside—the prisoner was brought to me by the omnibus conductor, and given into my custody for stealing a purse—I took him to the shop where the lady was; she said, "You villain, you have robbed me"—he said, "Mother, what do you mean?" in broken English or French—she said, "You know that you did"—he seemed to wish her not to give him into custody, but he spoke such bad English I could not understand him.

JAMES QUINN . I am a conductor of a Royal Blue omnibus. On the day the lady got into the omnibus I remember the prisoner coming, but I do not exactly remember the place—it was probably between the Bank and Cheapside—he sat the second on the left hand side of the omnibus—at the bottom of Cheapside the lady called to me to get out—I saw her get up from her seat—she could scarcely get up, she was entangled with something—when she got up she turned round and looked on the seat, and after she set her foot on the step she looked at the bottom of the omnibus—I looked, but I did not see the purse—the lady stepped on the ground, and the pri
soner immediately got up, pushed by the lady, and ran out, and at that instant I saw the purse on the floor of the omnibus—I chased the prisoner round St. Paul's Churchyard, and caught him.

GUILTY . Aged 65.—
Confined Twelve Months.
(The prisoner was also charged with having been before convicted.)

HENRY ELLIS . I am a conductor of an omnibus. I reside at Turnham
green—I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction—(read: "Central Criminal Court, June, 1846, James M'Grath, Convicted of stealing a purse and money of Mary Gurney, from her person; Transported for ten years")—the prisoner is the man—I was present, and gave evidence against him.
Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner was found at large some time ago, was he not? A. I do not know that—I do not know that he was tried for that.
EDMUND JAMES JONAS . (Clerk of the paper a of Newgate). The prisoner was tried here for being at large while under sentence—he was acquitted.
Cross-examined. Q. Was he acquitted on its being discovered that it was not him, but his brother? A. I am not aware on what ground—I know he was acquitted.NOT GUILTY.

522.
EDWARD CRAWFORD and
HENRY REYNOLDS
, burglari
ously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
William Blanchard, and stealing 1 bag, 21 cigars, 177 pennies, and other moneys; his property.
MR. METCALFE. conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM GLASS . (police sergeant, C 3). At half past 4 o'clock in the morning of 26th April I saw the prisoners—Reynolds was looking round a corner into Mary lebone-lane, and Crawford was a short distance from him, with a bulk under his coat—I followed them, and when they arrived at the corner of Golden-square I saw Reynolds throw something towards the rails of the inclosure—when we came up to him he was taking cigars out of his pocket, and throwing them on the ground—I left him in custody, and followed Crawford, who ran to the east side of the square, took this bulk from under his coat, threw it on the ground, and ran in the direction of

Marshall-street—I sprang my rattle—I lost sight of him for a moment, but he was taken—I took the bulk which he had had, and it contained 177 pence, 585 halfpence, and six farthings—on searching him at the station, I found 3s. 1 1/4 d. on him—on bringing him back to the spot, I picked up thirty-one cigars where I saw Reynolds throwing them away.

Cross-exanined by MR. MACENTEER. Q. Whom did you see first? A. Both nearly at one moment—when I gave Reynolds into custody, Crawford might be twenty-fire yards from me—he was twenty-five or thirty yards from me when he threw these things away—he did not make any resistance.

Cross-examined by MR. POLAND. Q. When you first saw Reynolds, Craw
ford was about a yard in advance? A. Yes—in the square I saw Reynolds take these cigars out of his pocket, and Crawford was on in front—Reynolds was not drunk at all.

JOHN PEACOCK . (policeman, C 170). I followed the prisoners, and took Reynolds—I saw him throw away this jemmy; I found it just by the inclo
sure of the square, where I saw it go from his hand—he had not been drinking—I did not see him throw any cigars away.

WILLIAM CROSS . (policeman, C 121). On the morning of 26th April I saw the two prisoners just before they came to the County Fire Office in Regent-street—it was about a quarter before 5 o'clock—it would take them about two or three minutes to walk from there to Mr. Blanchard's, the Scotch Stores.
Cross-examined by MR. POLAND. Q. Were they together? A. Yes—it wanted a quarter or 20 minutes to 5 o'clock—they were a few yards distant from Marylebone-street.

WILLIAM BLANCHARD . I keep the Scotch Stores, in Beech-street On 25th April I went to bed about half past 1 o'clock—I was the last person up, and all was then safe—I was called at half past 6 o'clock—I found the cords of the fan light so broken that anybody could get in—they had been safe the previous night—the doors were unfastened—I missed some silver mounting; and about 39s. worth of coppers, in pence, halfpence, and farthings; and about 5l. worth of silver; and they had passed into the cellar, and taken some wine—this bag belongs to the Union Bank; I had had it on the Saturday previous, with 100l. worth of silver—it was in my house that night, and was missed in the morning—I had placed some of the coppers in paper, similar to this paper which is wrapped round some of the money—I missed 130 or 140 cigars—I have brought some to correspond with what are here—the copper was not in this bag.

EDWABD PLUMRIDGE . I am porter to the Scotch Stores. I came down about a quarter before 7 o'clock in the morning of the 26th—I have heard what my master has said, and I say the same about the fan light.

Crawford. I said before the Magistrate that I was in a coffee shop that morning till half past 4 o'clock; he told me to consult my legal adviser; the sergeant went to the coffee shop, and I believe he told the persons not to come.
WILLIAM GLASS . re-examined. I went to the coffee shop—I did not desire them not to come.
SUSANNAH PEARSON . I live at a coffee shop, in St. James-street, Hay-market. Crawford came there that morning, at a quarter after 1 o'clock, and did not leave, till half past 4.

COURT. Q. What were you doing? A. Waiting at the coffee shop—it is open all night—Crawford was asleep part of the time—I took him a cup of coffee at half past 4 o'clock—it was from half past 4 to 5 o'clock when the gas was put out—it was getting light at' the time he left—my master cleared the boxes at that time—my master asked me what time he left—I did not go to the police office—my master was not there—there was no
body else up but my master and me—my master is gone to Shropshire, he went last Sunday.

(Crawford received a good character.) CRAWFORD—
GUILTY . Aged 22,—
Confined Nine Months.

REYNOLDS—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—He was also chrged with having been before convicted.

THOMAS SANDFORD . (policeman, D 254). I produce a certificate of Rey
nolds' former conviction—(read: "Guildhall, Westminster, April, 1854, Henry Skinner, convicted of stealing a spoon; confined six months")—I was present—the prisoner is the person—I have known him from that time.

GUILTY.*—
Confined Eighteen Months.

523.
JAMES SCOTT
, stealing 1 dressing case, value 10s.; also, 10 dressing cases, 28 books, 80 purses, and other goods; of
Samuel Moore, his master: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

524.
JOHN THOMPSON
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
William Vince, and stealing 23 penny pieces, and other moneys of his: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Twelve Months.

525.
ELLEN BARRY and
MARGARET QUICK
, stealing 3 dresses, a shawl, 10 yards of alpaca, and other goods, value 40s.; the goods of
Edward Dutton.
MR. THOMPSON. conducted the Prosecution.

EDWARD DUTTON . I am a butcher, and live in Well-street, Cripplegate. In the afternoon of 30th April, I came out Of one room into another, on my first floor—I saw the prisoners there, and they had got these three dresses, a shawl, about twenty yards of calico, and some other things—each of the prisoners had some of them in their arms—they saw me, and dropped them down—I asked them what business they had there—it was about half past 1 o'clock—my house is under repair and the painters had just gone—Quick said that one of the painters had sent her up for half a crown—I had seen these articles safe not ten minutes before, they were then in the further side of the room—I never saw the prisoners before.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was your street door left opent? A. I suppose the door was open—the house was under repair; the lock was taken off to be repaired—Quick said that one of the painters had sent her up for half a crown—the painters were just gone to dinner—I cannot say which of the prisoners had any part of these articles, each of them had some of them in their arms, and they were trying to conceal them under their shawls—I left them in the room in custody of our workpeople while I went to the door and got a policeman.
Quick. I had the bit of calico in my hand. Witness. I think you had the calico and some other things, but Barry had the larger part of them.

HENRY SLATE . (City policeman, 87). I was called in, and took Quick into custody—as she was leaving the house, I saw her throw these three keys behind the door—they are common keys, and are such as will open poor people's room doors—this one has been altered from it's original make,
so that it will open almost any door—I found that both the prisoners live together, at No. 49, Parker-street, Drury-lane.

Cross-examined. Q. You went to the place after the prisoners were in custody? A. Yes—I never saw the prisoners in that place in Parker-street—I took Quick into custody, and from the address they gave at the station I went there.
WILLIAM WALLER . (City policeman, 121). I took Barry into custody—she gave her address, No. 5, Kennedy-court, Middle-row, Holborn—I went there, but no one knew her—I afterwards went to another place.
Quick. This young woman went into the room with a young man; I thought they staid too long, and I went to see for her; I only went to the door of the room.
GUILTY.

(The prisoners were both farther charged with having been before convicted.) JOSEPH MITCHELL. (police sergeant, F 6). I produce a certificate—(read: "Westminster Sessions, Feb., 1855; Ellen Smith, convicted of stealing four gowns, and other articles; Confined twelve months")—I was present, Barry is the person.

WILLIAM GEORGE M'KENZIE , (City policeman, 283) I produce a certi
ficate—(read: "Clerkenwett Sessions, May, 1853; Margaret Quick, con
victed of stealing a frock, and other articles, having been previously convicted; Confined nine months")—I was present, Quick if the person.

BARRY—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

QUICK—
GUILTY . Aged 41.

526.
GEORGIANA CHATTEN
, feloniously cutting and wounding
James Chatten, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.
MR. PLATT. conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES CHATTEN . I keep a coffee shop at Knightsbridge. The prisoner is my wife—she came out of prison on New Year's day—I fetched her home, and she lived with me till 27th March—on the Sunday before this the prisoner's sister had come up from the country on a visit—she and the prisoner were very good friends at first—on the Tuesday I was going to take my wife and her sister to a place of amusement, but instead of that I went over to my own sister's, at Rotherhithe—I left my wife at my sister's, and returned home to business—I expected my wife home the next morning—she never arrived—I staid at home till 11 o'clock at night—I then went out to see if I could find her anywhere in the neighbourhood—I did not go to Rotherhithe to fetch her—I heard something about her, and when I got home, I found the prisoner and her sister quarrelling in the kitchen—the prisoner said to me, "You have been out with some one, and could not come to fetch me"—I tried to make peace—she tore her sister's bonnet off and threw it on the fire—I begged her to be quiet, and tried all I possibly could to keep them both quiet—I could not, and I left them to put on my cap and jacket, and when I came back to the kitchen she flew at me, and scratched my face—I said I was determined I would not put up with that—she said, "I will do for you, I will smash the windows"—she took the poker, and was breaking the glass—I went to take the poker, and received two blows on the front of my head—I fell back insensible into the arms of some one—I was taken to St. George's Hospital; I did not remain there—I continued an out patient about five weeks.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. You got these blows when she was striking the glass? A. I tried to prevent her from striking the glass, and received the blows—I did not tell her I had been out with a woman, nor

had I been—I left home at 11 o'clock, and was home again by 12 o'clock—I had not been in company with a woman, and treating her, while I was out—I had never treated a woman that night—I believe my wife does not say that I am in the habit of doing it—she does not say that I am out night after night with women, treating them—I admit that I have given females a glass of ale in a public house—I know Mary Gibbs, she was my servant—I am given to understand that she is now in the family way—I have not told my wife that I am the father of that child—I deny it.

Q. Have you told your own sister so, who is here? A. No, I deny it—she was living at my place when my wife came home—we have a servant named Jane Bull, aged about fourteen, living with us—I have not been found in bed with that girl—I deny it—these are low characters that they want to bring against me.

Q. Have you ever struck your wife, and given her black eyes frequently? A. I admit I did once strike her—she came home so intoxicated, that I struck her—I gave her one black eye—she was breaking all the things, she was so intoxicated.

WILLIAM BEGBORN . (policeman, B 177). I heard the cry of "Police!" and "Murder!" and found the last witness injured, and in the arms of a civilian; he was bleeding from a wound in the head—I took him in doors, and the prisoner was given in charge—she said, "Oh, James, forgive me!" and on her way to the station, she said, "The poker was not so bad this time as the knife."

GUILTY. of unlawfully wounding. Aged 24.—
Judgment Respited.

div0.p: THIRD COURT.—Tuesday, May 13th, 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. FARNCOMB.; Mr. Ald. FINNIS.; Sir ROBERT WALTER.
CARDEN, Knt., Ald.; MR. Ald. EAGLETON.; and MICHAEL PRENDERGAST, Esq.

p.hi: Before Michael Prendergast, Esq., and the Seventh Jury.

div1.p:
527.
CHARLES MITCHELL and
WILLIAM JENNINGS
, bur
glariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
James Brooks, and stealing therein 1 copper boiler, value 15s.; the goods of
James Hamlet, and fixed in the said dwelling house: to which

MITCHELL
PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 21—
Confined One Year.

JENNINGS
PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Eighteen Months. (A police constable was severely injured by the violence of Jennings.)

528.
CAROLINE CHALLIS
, stealing 23 cigars, value 3s., and 2s. in money; the property of
John Dunater, her master: to which she
PLEADED GUILTY , and received a good character. Aged 19.

529.
THOMAS BRODIE
, stealing 1 pencil case, value 25s.; the goods of
James Kay Mackay.
MR. PAYNE. conducted the Prosecution.

JAMES KAY MACKAY . I am a stationer, of No. 29, John-street, Bedford-row. I manage the business of my brother, a stationer, in Paternoster-row—on 26th April, between 4 and 5 o'clock in the afternoon, the prisoner entered the office—I was busy writing my evening letters for the mail, and had not much time to speak to him—he was standing at my back, the desk

being against the wall—I had finished one letter, and took out my gold pencil case, worth 25s., to seal it with, after which I laid it down on the table—the prisoner, who was about two feet from me, took it up, asked the price, and made some other remarks, which I did not pay much attention to (we do not sell pencil cases, we are wholesale stationers, and only sell paper)—being busy writing, I did not observe him leave the room, but heard the door shut, and then missed the pencil case—I went to the stairs and saw the prisoner just about to go out into Paternoster-row—I called to him, but he made no reply—I hesitated for a moment to leave the place, as there was nobody there but myself—I then ran into Paternoster-row, but did not see him—a man passing spoke to me, and I ran into St. Paul's Churchyard, and saw the prisoner running—he was stopped by a policeman, and I saw my pencil case in the policeman's hand—the prisoner was taken lo the station.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. You have known the prisoner almost all your life? A. No—I have seen him three times in the last eighteen months—I knew him at the Bank of Glasgow—I did not see him often there; I knew him to speak to, and since he has been in town he has called on me three times—he did not tell me that morning that he had an appoint
ment with the member of Parliament for Cavan—he came to call on me, and said that he hoped to have a situation very shortly, I think he said in China, through the member for Cavan—he did not say that he hoped to get a charac
ter from me—I was up a flight of about thirty stairs—after he was committed by the Magistrate, I returned to the Magistrate's room, but I did not say that I did not think he intended to steal it—I might have said something to miti
gate the punishment—I had been detained in London three weeks longer than I should otherwise have been, and said that it was a pity that he was com
mitted, there being nothing found against him—with regard to the pledge tickets found on him, I made a request to Sir Henry Muggeridge that his deci
sion as to his committal to be tried here might be mitigated—I have no idea how long he was at the Bank of Glasgow—he bears a very high character.

MR. PAYNE. Q. Did he ask you to lend him the pencil case, or any money? A. He had previously borrowed some few shillings of me, which he has not paid—I did not authorise him to take this pencil case—he was running in St. Paul's Churchyard, and when I went up to him, he said, "I did not intend to steal your pencil case."

FRANCIS STANWAY . (pity policeman, 311). On Saturday afternoon, 26th April, I saw the prisoner running in St. Paul's Churchyard—I stopped him, and found this gold pencil case in his hand—I searched him at the station, and found on him twenty-one duplicates, twelve of which relate to coats, a 3d. piece, and a hand vice—I ascertained that he lived at a coffee house in Back Church-lane, Whitechapel.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not he say that he did not intend to steal the pencil case? A. Yes, and that he was hurrying off to see a gentleman in; New Cannon-street—I do not know whether the member for Cavan lives in New Cannon street—I could see the end of the pencil case in his hand.
MR. PAYNE. Q. How was he running? A. Very fast, there was a policeman and several persons following him.
COURT. to JAMES KAY MACKAY. Q. When you turned to write, the pencil case was in his hand? A. Yes.
MR. COOPER. Q. Have you a timepiece in your room? A. No, nor down stairs—I did not cry "Stop thief!"
COURT. to FRANCIS STANWAY. Q. Was the policeman who was running
after him calling out "Stop thief?" A. He called out "Stop him!" once or twice in a loud tone.

MR. COOPER. contended that there was no trespass committed. MR. PAYNE. suggested that if the prisoner intended to steal it when he took it up, that it would amount to a felony. The COURT. left the question to the Jury.
NOT GUILTY .

530.
HENRY WOLLENS
, stealing on 22nd April, 5 quires of paper; value 5s.; on 23rd April, 5 quires of paper, value 5s.; and on 24th April, 4 sheets of paper, value 4d.; the goods of
William Hopcroft, his master.
MR. COOPER. conducted the Prosecution.

ABRAHAM BENTLEY . I am a printer, in the service of Mr. Hopcroft, of Mincing-lane. The prisoner was a journeyman in the same employment—I was ordered to watch him, and did so on the night of 23rd April—it was about 2 o'clock when I gave him in charge—I saw him take some paper, roll it up, and put it into his hat—I ran down into Mincing-lane, got a policeman, and told him to look into the prisoner's hat—he found these three sheets of paper (produced)—I then counted the paper that the pri
soner had been working on, and found it twenty sheets short—I had counted the paper before that night, and it was all right—the paper was double demy—the prisoner had no right to take it, unless his employer allows him, but I often take home a sheet of paper.

Cross-examined by MR. METCALPE. Q. You often take home a sheet of paper when it is spoilt, and unfit for printing on? A. Yes—one of these three sheets are spoiled, this one—I should have felt at liberty to take that away—if the paper is too wet it cannot be printed on, but is not spoiled; it cannot be printed on at that time—I am the person who damps it before it goes to him—the paper when found was not as it is now, it was like this (crumpled up)—the prisoner could not see me, but I was where I could command a view of him; I was in the dark in the office at the oppo
site corner—he was at No. 42, Mincing-lane, and I was at No. 1, the opposite corner, looking for the purpose, but, for all the prisoner knew, he was alone—he had had, for some weeks, a latch key to let himself in and out at night—he had access to all the paper—this was in the middle of the night—there are no blinds to either house—1,036 sheets are allowed for every 1,000 to be printed, the thirty-six sheets are for waste—I do not know whether a man may take away the thirty-six sheets if he does not spoil any, but I have often taken a sheet of paper home—there has been no prohibition in the office to taking away paper under any circumstances—there is nothing defective in the other two sheets, but one of them has been torn since.

CHARLES EDWIN DODD . (City policeman, 511). The prisoner was given into my custody, he had his hat on—I asked him what he had in his hat—he took it off, and said, "Two or three sheets of damp paper, too wet to work on"—he took them out, and said that he always thought there was plenty served out, so as to allow for damage in printing.

JOSEPH BROWN . (City policeman, 584). On this night I went to Mr. Hppcroft's premises, and saw the prisoner given into custody—I went to the address he gave, and found twenty-four packages of blank paper, and a quantity of printed paper.
Cross-examined. Q. Where did you find it? A. In a chest of drawers—he gave me his name and address—he does not keep the whole house, he has apartments on the ground floor.

THOMAS SMITH . I am manager to Mr. Hopcroft, a printer, of Mincing-lane. On the afternoon of 23rd, I counted the paper over, and gave it to Bentley to damp—I have seen the three or four sheets (produced)—they are not in good order now; I should not think they were spoiled before they were doubled up, but I do not know how they were when he had them—I have examined the paper found at the prisoner's house, it is worth 7s. or 8s., and is Mr. Hopcroft's property; they are not spoiled sheets—we do not allow paper to be taken, but it is the custom in the business—the prisoner has been six weeks in the service.

COURT. Q. You do not allow it? A. No, but it is the custom at other houses for pressmen to claim the paper which they do not spoil; they are entitled, as a reward for their care, to the sheets which are not spoiled—very often there are a great many spoiled in the working—these are not fit for circulation.
Cross-examined. Q. Has he been working for five or six years for Seyfang and Co.? A. Yes—the house does not wish to press the case against him.

(MR. COOPER. here withdrew from the Prosecution.)
NOT GUILTY .

531.
ROBERT CHISNELL
, stealing 59 1/2 yards of silk, value 10l. 10s.; the goods of
Edmund Spall.
MR. W. J. PAYNE. conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM TRIM . I am warehouseman to Edmund Spall, a silk agent, of No. 120, Cheapside. On the afternoon of 1st May, about half past 5 o'clock, I left the premises with my master, who fastened the door, and took the key—the warehouse is on the second floor—on the following morning I went to the warehouse, as usual, about 10 minutes to 9 o'clock, and about a minute or two afterwards a policeman came up to me—I found that the door had been broken open, and fastened again with a hinge; the policeman took it off, and we both went in—on looking round I missed a parcel of nlk aprons, which had been on the counter, and the cash box, which had been in a little ante-room on one side, and contained two sovereigns, and a few shillings in silver; it was safe on the Thursday evening—there were nearly twenty pieces of silk, and they were worth about 30l.—on the 2nd I went with an officer to Mr. Duke's, a pawnbroker's, in the New Cut, and two pieces of silk were shown to me there, which I immediately recognized, as a portion of the silk taken from the warehouse—three other pieces of silk were shown to me at Mr. Cole's, in the Waterloo-road, on the same after
noon, which also formed a portion of what I had missed; and last Saturday I saw two more at the Mansion House; they formed a portion of the same silk—I do not know the prisoner.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Is Mr. Spall in a large way of busi
ness? A. Yes—there might, perhaps, be the same quantity of silk on the premises in a drawer that there was on the counter, and of the same pattern and quality, and some other patterns as well—we had about thirty pieces of the same pattern, and have about ten left; we only supply the wholesale houses—we have supplied a great many pieces of this particular pattern to the wholesale houses—Mr. Spall is agent for a manufacturer at Macclesfield.

MR. W. J. PAYNE. Q. I believe this particular silk was made by Mr. Sherrard, of Macclesfield? A. Yes—that in the drawer was not taken away—I recognize this by the pattern and quality; the pattern is made exclusively by Mr. Sherrard for Mr. Spall—from the wholesale houses it goes to the retail.
JOSEPH COMBER KNIGHT . (City policeman, 437). I am a plain clothes

officer. On Thursday night, 1st May, from information I received, I went to Mr. Spall's premises—the housekeeper opened the door—I went to the warehouse on the second floor, and found that the box of the lock had been forced off, and the lock rendered entirely useless—I saw no other marks of violence, and, not being able to ascertain where Mr. Spall lived, I got a strong hinge and fastened up the door, leaving the place in the care of the housekeeper—I got there in the morning, just after the last witness.

CAROLINE FOX . I am the wife of Joseph Fox. I formerly lived as servant with the prisoner—he keeps a beer shop in the Waterloo-road—last Friday week I met the prisoner, between 1 and 2 o'clock, and he asked me if I would go for an errand for him, and he asked me to pledge these things—they were lying before me, folded up—I pledged three pieces at Mr. Cole's, between 4 and 5 o'clock, and these two at Mr. Wharton's—I took two pieces of silk to Mr. Vickers'; and while I was there an officer came and prevented me—I handed the money and duplicates to my mistress, and she passed them over to my master, in my presence—I had taken the articles off the table, in the presence of my master and my mistress; my master told me to take them—I have been in the habit of pawning things before—I received 11s. on each of the three pieces of silk.

Cross-examined. Q. How far do you live from there? A. Ten minutes' walk at the most—I was a servant there when I married—Mr. Cole lives opposite, Mr. Duke lives close by, and Mr. White not far off—I had pawned things there before for the prisoner.

JAMES HOBBES . I am assistant to Mr. Wharton, of Mount-street, Lam
beth. I produce two pieces of silk, pledged on 2nd May, by the last witness, for 15s. each.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know her? A. I had never seen her before, and I have been there twelve months.
SAMUEL HEZEKIAH COLE . I am a pawnbroker, of the Waterloo-road. I produce three pieces of silk, pledged by Cox, on 2nd May, two at 22s., and one at 11s. in the name of Chandler.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know her? Yes; I have known her some time.

GEORGE LEGG . (City policeman, 440). On Friday afternoon, 2nd May, I saw Cox at Mr. Dickers', the pawnbroker's, No. 82, Lambeth
marsh—these two pieces of silk were rolled up on the counter; from information I got there, I went to the Hit or Miss beer shop, Waterloo-road, saw the prisoner there, and asked him if he had sent Fox with two pieces of silk to pledge—he said, "Yes"—I asked him where he had got them from; he said that he bought them of a tallyman on the Tuesday previous (this was on Friday)—I asked him if he had got a bill—he said, "No, I paid ready money, 1l. a piece, to make my wife some dresses"—I asked him if he knew the man, he said that he did not—I told him that the silk would be detained, and left him—I then went to the City, took Mr. Trim to the pawnbroker's to see the silk; then went back to the prisoner's house, took him to Mr. Dickers, and asked him whether the silk on the counter was his property—he said, "Yes;" and that they were the two pieces he had sent his servant to pledge for him—I told him that he must consider himself in custody for having stolen property in his possession, and asked him if he had got any more—he said that he had only those two pieces which he had bought of a tallyman on the Tuesday previous, to make his wife a dress, and that it would be a lesson to him—I searched him at the station, and found 3l. 16s. 6d., a silver watch and guard, a gold ring, and a purse.
Cross-examined. Q. He said that they were his, without hesitation, and that he had sent Fox? A. Yes; I was away about thirty minutes, and when I went back I found him at his house.
WILLIAM TRIM . re-examined. These two pieces of silk found at Dickers' are Mr. Spall's property, and were safe when I left on 1st May.

COURT. Q. Are all the silks found of the same pattern? A. Yes, but of different colours; they are made expressly for aprons, we sell them at 30s. a dozen—they are all my master's property, and are manufactured at Sherrard's—we have sold about 100 dozen of them—they had not been on gale more than six weeks at the time of the loss—I cannot answer for their not being some which had been add, but the lengths tally exactly—there are twelve aprons in each piece, but they always divide them when they are sold, as they would never sell a dozen of one colour; they divide them into quarters or half dozens—finding them thus, implies that they come direct from some wholesale house—we lost twenty pieces with a dozen in each, and have only found seven—they were not ticketed or numbered—the largest quantity we have sold is, perhaps, thirty dozen, to Crocker and Co., of Fri
day-street, but they would cut them up into quarters or half dozens.

GUILTY. on 2nd Count. Aged 55.—
Confined One Year.

532.
WILLIAM WEAVER and
BENJAMIN CLOUSE
, robbery on
Alfred Sharwell, and stealing, from his person, 1 watch, 1 ring, and 2 keys, value 4l. 15s., his property: to which

CLOUSE
PLEADED GUILTY .** Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.
MR. W. J. PAYNE. conducted the Prosecution.

ALFRED SHARWELL . I am a warehouseman, of No. 8, Victoria-street, Hackney-road. On Friday night, 28th March, between 9 and 10 o'clock, I was in High-street, Shoreditch—when I got to Hare-court, which I did not know before, two men came out of it; one of them jumped at me, and snatched at my watch, and the taller one hit me a How under the ear—I fell against the corner of the alley, and then ran after the other party, and was struck a violent blow—the men both went up the court—I ran after the one who had taken my watch, the shorter one—I cannot say who he was, as it was done in a moment—in the court I was struck another violent blow on the back of the neck—I cannot tell by whom, am I was running, the person was on one side of me—that knocked me senseless to the ground, and stunned me—mine was a silver hunting watch, with No. 8172 on it, and my initials—I have not seen it since—this chain was left hanging round my neck.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you nut after the man who snatched your watch? A. Yes—the snatch was first, and then the blow—another man, I cannot say who, struck my head against the wall, the moment it was taken—I do not affect to say who either of them were—I have always said that I was struck two blows.

GEORGE WOOLLARD CLARE . I live at No, 80, High-street, Shoreditch. On Friday, 28th March, at a few minutes past 9 o'clock, I saw Sharwell in High-street—when he got near Hare-alley I saw Clouse rush on him, snatch his watch out of his waistcoat pocket, and run up the court with it—he had been loitering about the court previously—it was fourteen or fifteen yards from my master's door—Sharweli ran after him followed by Weaver, and a man who is not in custody—I had seen these prisoners together ten minutes before the watch was taken, with the man not in custody—I knew them all
three by sight, having seen them pass up and down—I have no doubt that Weaver is one of the men who ran up the court.
Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. Porter to Mr. Blackwell, I stand outside—I am a barker.

HUGH ANDREWS . (policeman, H 62). On Wednesday, the same day that I was before the Magistrate, I saw the prisoners together in George-street, Spitalfields—I took Weaver, and told him that I wanted him for a watch which was stolen at Shoreditch—he said that he knew nothing of it—I had seen the prisoners and another party about 9 o'clock on the night of the robbery standing about thirty yards from where it took place, in High-street—I had a good view of them—I might be three or four yards from them—I knew them before, and have no doubt about them—Weaver is one of the three.
Cross-examined. Q. While the examination was going on, did you hear Weaver say, "I am innocent, Clouse done it"? A. Yes.

COURT. to GEORGE WOOLLARD CLARE. Q. At the time this rushing took place you did not see Weaver? A. Yes, at the moment the watch was taken—he was at the back of Clouse, close by, but I could not see whether he struck Sharwell—he was not near enough to touch him, he was about a yard from him—I am quite sure of Weaver.

JOSEPH DUBBLE . (policeman, H 195). I was with Andrews on Wed
nesday in George-street, and saw the prisoners—as soon as Clouse saw me he ran—I ran past Weaver, telling Andrews to take him—I took Clouse, took him to the station, and charged him with stealing the watch—he looked at Weaver, and said, "We know nothing about it"—after a witness came to identify him, he said, "I did do it, but Weaver had nothing to do with it"—I know them, they are always together.

WEAVER—
GUILTY .**† Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.

533.
ELIZA DAVIS
, stealing 1 watch, value 6l.; the property of
Samuel Hassan, from his person.
MR. LAWRENCE. conducted the Prosecution.

SAMUEL HASSAN . I live at No. 4, Worship-street. On 15th April I was going from St Paul's down to Farringdon-street, about 10 minutes past 9 o'clock—the prisoner spoke to me, and I walked with her a short distance—my watch was then safe in my pocket—we turned up Wheatsheaf-yard,. she remained talking to me there two or three minutes—a man came up, and she ran away—the man tried to hold me, and began to ask me about some chambers—my suspicions were aroused, I felt for my watch, and found that it was gone—I followed the prisoner, and saw her running on the other side of Farringdon-street—I ran across, took her by the arm, and accused her of taking my watch, and she put it into my hand, but said nothing—a policeman came, and took her—I found the handle of my watch on the ground in the yard—the chain was left behind—the watch is worth 6l.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How long were you with her? A. Five minutes, but not two minutes up Wheatsheaf-yard.

MR. LAWRENCE. Q. You did not give it to her? A. No—she is one of my people (a Jewess), but I did not notice that at the time—I do not know whether she is a foreigner; she speaks English like a native—I am from Gibraltar.

WILLIAM ROWLAND . (City policeman, 247). On 15th April, at a quarter past 9 o'clock, I was in Farringdon-street, and saw the prisoner run away by Wheatsheaf-yard, followed by the prosecutor—she ran to Harp
alley,

where he stopped her—I went up, and took her to the station; she was searched, and 1d. found on her—she gave her address, No. 47, Bell
alley, spitalfields—I went there, but there was not a house of that number.
Cross-examined. Q. Did she say Spitaltields? A. She said Bishopsgate-street—I found No. 7 and No. 27—she spoke like a Jewess, but I quite understood what she said.
WILLIAM GOODEYE . (City policeman, 52). I found this ring of a gold watch (produced), in Wheatsheaf-yard, on 15th April.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Four Months.

534.
DANIEL O'KEEFE
, maliciously wounding
Harriet Washington.
MR. THOMPSON. conducted the Prosecution.

RICHARD COUSINS . (policeman). On the evening of 13th March, in con
sequence of information, I went to the Royal Oak public house, and found Harriet Washington, with her head on the tap room table, bleeding very furiously from the eye and the nose—the prisoner was there, and a person present gave him into custody for throwing a quart pot at the woman—the woman could not speak—the prisoner said, "I did do it; I did not intend it for the poor woman, I intended it for my wife"—his wife was not there, I did not see her till we got thirty or forty yards towards the station; she followed us.

HARRIET WASHINGTON . I am a widow, and live at No, 4, Shepherds-place, Westminster. On the evening of 13th March I was at the Royal Oak, and saw the prisoner there, and his wife, whom I did not know—they were having words—my friend set his beer down on the table, and the prisoner's wife took it up and threw it at the prisoner—he then took up the pot, and threw it—I think it was intended for his wife, who was sitting down—I was standing up, not a yard from her, and it struck me with great force over the eye—I was taken to the hospital—I was there five weeks, and am still an out-patient.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Who were you with? A. Mr. Crane, he and I had been drinking together—I did not lose ray senses—I do not recollect the prisoner helping me up, and saying that he was very sorry-his mother came to me in the hospital, brought me several oranges, and said that her son would allow me 5s. a week till I got well, if he could get his liberty—I had no spirits or beer brought me into the hospital, I had a little ale.

JESSE CRANE . I was at the Royal Oak with the last witness—I had drunk once of my pint of beer, and went into the tap room to sit down—the prisoner's wife pushed my pot of beer to him, he threw the pot with Ms left hand, with very great force—I did not see it strike Mrs. Washington—I do not know how he had provoked his wife—they were having words when I went in.

OTHO VITALIS . I am house surgeon to the Westminster Hospital. On 13th March the prisoner was brought there, with a cut on her forehead, part of the nose was broken, and part of the bone of the orbit—she was in danger for about four weeks afterwards, and is still an out-patient—there will still be some trouble from the wound, she has had an attack of ery
sipelas from it.
Cross-examined. Q. Would drinking ale, tend to produce erysipelas? A. Not at all; we gave her a liberal diet, she Bad brandy and port—they would not tend to produce erysipelas.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—Recom
mended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Fourteen Days

div0.p: THIRD COURT.—Saturday, May 11th, 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. CUBITT. and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Sixth Jwry.

div1.p:
535.
WILLIAM SMITH
, stealing 1 printed book, value 3s.; the goods of
Ann Owen; and 1 printed book, value 3s. the goods of
Caroline Smith: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Confined Three Months.

536.
WILLIAM LUNDEY
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Humphrey Clare; with intent to steal.

ELIZABETH CLARE . I reside with my brother, Humphrey Clare, at No. 38, Buttesland-street, Hoxton. Early on Sunday morning, 20th April, I was disturbed by a man opening my bedroom door—I saw his arm, that was all—supposing it to be my brother, I called to ask if it was, but having no answer, I hastened to the door, and the light was extinguished—I went to my brother's bedroom and found him asleep, and rang the bell to give an alarm—Mr. Hayward saw the window open—it had been closed at 20 minutes before 1 o'clock in the morning, but it was not fastened—the back door was bolted.

Prisoner. Q. Did not the Magistrate put the question to you whether you knew me again, and you said that you did not see my face? A. I did not see your face—I noticed your coat, because the light you had, shone on it—there was a little bit of white on the coat—I saw you brought back in about half an hour afterwards, and then there was white on your coat.

EDWIN HAYWARD . I live in the house of Mr. clare. I was alarmed on that Sunday morning—I heard the bell ring—I saw Mrs. Clare—I went down into the passage—I saw the back door open, and the window was wide open—I went into the yard, and saw some footmarks—I gave infor
mation to the policeman—I went into the back yard, and saw the prisoner jumping over the wall—he jumped over four or five walls before we got him—we followed him, and did not lose sight of him—the walls were very low—he was taken in about a quarter of an hour.

DANIEL LUFF . (policeman, N 62). I received information from the last witness—I saw the prisoner leaping over the walls—I called "Stop thief!" and never lost sight of him till I found him in a watercloset about seven gardens off—I said, "What do you want here?"—he said that he was hun
gry, and wanted something to eat—his stockings were off, and were in his trowsers pocket—I took him to the station—he said, "I don't deny being in the house, but the window was open."

GUILTY . Aged 38.—
Confined Twelve Months.

537.
JOHN JONES and
EDWIN COMBE
, stealing 4 frocks, 7 pina
fores, and other articles; the goods of
James Broom, from the person of
Mary Broom: to which

JONES
PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Twelve Months.
MR. WAY. conducted the Prosecution.
