MARY BROOM . I am the wife of James Broom, I live at No. 2, Queen's-square, Bartholomew-close. On 30th April I was at the corner of Princes-street, Barbican, about 5 minutes past 11 o'clock at night, carrying a large bundle—I felt some one's hand on my shoulder, I turned, and saw the two

prisoners togethert—Combe disappeared, lie went off the pavement—Jones snatched my bundle, and they both ran together up Princes-street, and I after them—I ran into Charles-street, Bridgewater-square, and Combe came to me, and said, "What is the matter?"—I said, "Don't talk to me; why don't you catch that man that has got my bundle, which you know?"—he struck me in the face, and I fell down—I got up again, and ran after them—they were both running together down the street—they ran into Golden-lane, and I lost sight of them—from the time I first saw Combe till the time he struck me, I had not lost sight of him—I never lost sight of them till they got into Golden-lane—I saw them about an hour afterwards, I went with the policeman, and gave them into custody—I saw them at a lodging house in Golden-lane, with other persons—my bundle contained four frocks, seven pinafores, five aprons, and some other things—I had an opportunity of seeing the person of Combe before he struck me—he laid hold of my shawl, and I looked him in the face—I am quite sure he is the man.

Combe. Q. I was sitting in the house, conversing with the woman who keeps the house, when you came in with the sergeant and two men, and took me; what time did you see me in the house? A. About an hour after I was robbed, about half past 12 o'clock.

JOHN DELLOW . (City policeman, 95). On 30th April I received infor
mation of this robbery from Mrs. Broom—she gave me a description of the persons who committed it—it was owing to that, that I took her to the lodging house in Golden-lane—I found the two prisoners in the house—they were recognized by the prosecutrix—as soon as she got a fair sight of their faces, she recognized them.
Combe. She did not recognize me, she said I was not the man. Witness. She did recognize you—she said once tnat she did not think you were the man.

COURT. Q. When was that? A. As soon as she went into the room I told him to step forward, and she said, "I don't think that that is the man;" but as soon as he came in sight of her, she said, "That is the man that knocked me down"—she recognized him as soon as she got a fair sight of him.
Combe. Q. You said, "Are you sure that that is anything like the man?" and she said, "Yes;" but did she not say five different times that I was not the man? A. No.
DAHIEL DELLOW . (City policeman, 118). I was present on 30th April when the two prisoners were taken into custody—I heard the prosecutrix recognize them.

FRANCES EGERTON . I am the wife of William Egerton—I live at No. 2, Queen-square, Bartholomew-close. On the night of 30th April I was with Mrs. Broom, at the corner of Princes-street—I saw Jones and another person with him, but whether it was Combe I could not say—I could not identify him—Jones snatched the bundle from the woman, and he ran away—the other party made towards Princes-street—Mrs. Broom had nearly overtaken tfcem, calling out, "Stop thief!"—I followed as quickly as I could, but they; had proceeded too far for me to see anything more done—the other person was the same size as Combe, as near as I could judge—I cannot swear to him.

Combes Defence. On the night of 30th April, while sitting in the house of Mrs. Gardner, three policemen came in, accompanied by Mrs. Broom; I being the nearest person to the police sergeant, he asked her if

there was any person in the room who robbed her; she said she did not know; I was asked to stand up, and I did; the policeman then asked her if I was the man, she said that she could not say; he asked her again if I was like the man; she said that she could not say and could not swear, five different times; I asked Mrs. Broom how long it was since it happened, she said about an hour; I said that I had been in the house more than that time; Mrs. Gardner also said that was not the man, meaning me, at the time; there were several more persons in the room at the tune, who said the same as Mrs. Gardner; one of the policemen then nodded to Mrs. Broom, and she directly said, "Yes, policeman, that is the man that knocked me down;" I then asked Mrs. Gardner if she would be so kind as to come to Guildhall in the morning to speak for me; she was outside the Court when I had my hearing; I was remanded for two days, and when I was brought up, Mrs. Gardner was in the Court; I called on her, and asked Alderman Muggeridge to have my witnesses sworn; he told me, not then, I might call them at Newgate, for he should send me for trial; I have sent to Mrs. Gardner since, and to my friends; I hare sent my friends to her, but her reply is that she would not come for 5l.; the police have been there, so I doubt not but they have put a stop to her coming to prove my innocence; there are more men than me that dress like me in London, there are thousands; I can prove that I do not get my living by thieving; I have been at work for Mr. Henry Hartrey, of Bermondsey, the last six months, and I am not more than seven months from Ireland; I can look any policeman in the face, and bid defiance to any one to say he knows me.

COMBE—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Twelve Months.

538.
JAMES NEWMAN
, assaulting
Mary Ann Crowley, with intent, etc.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

div0.p: OLD COURT.—Friday, May 30th, 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. FARNCOMB.; Mr. Ald. SIDNIY.; MR. RECORDER.; and Mr. Ald. WIRE.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Fourth Jury.

div1.p:
539.
PETER FRANCIS MOGAN
, stealing, whilst employed in the Post Office, a post letter, containing a sovereign and 2 cards; the property of
Her Majesty's Postmaster-General.
MESSRS, CLARKSON. and POLAND. conducted the Prosecution.

MATTHEW PEAK . I am a police constable attached to the Post Office in St. Martin's-Grand—on the morning of the 15th April I saw Blackburn, the plumber, clear out a water closet on the basement floor of the General Post Office—it was the second one on the left, coming out of the London District Office—I believe it is one of the closets appropriated to the letter carriers—Blackburn cleared out the pan, and stopped it, by putting in some brown paper—after he had done this, I watched that closet—I went to the back of it, to what is called an air shaft, and looked through a grating—there is a gas light in the closet, which is burning all day; it was burning then—I watched therefrom about half-past 6 o'clock till about half-past 6—Smee, my brother officer, then came and relieved me—up to that time

nobody had entered the closet—I still continued to watch—I was away for a short time, but about half-past 7 o'clock I heard the door leading from the office shut, and I went back, looked through the grating, and saw the prisoner enter the closet—the grating is at the back of the closet, at the right hand of a person on the seat, it forms part of the wall—the prisoner sat down on the seat—I heard some paper tearing when he was sitting down—I then saw his hand go behind him—he got up in a minute or so, and went out—as soon as he had left, I went and fetched Blackburn, and instructed him to search the closet—I left Smee at the grating—Smee had a better view of the closet than I had, because he was more at the front—I saw Blackburn search the pan, and take out some pieces of paper which appeared to be portions of a letter—I have it here—after the pieces were taken out Blackburn washed them and pot them together, and then they were given to me by Mr. Sculthorpe, and have been in my possession ever since—after the papers had been examined, I went to look after the prisoner in the Sorting Office—that was about half-past 7 o'clock—I could not find him there—I gave information to Mr. Gapes, the inspector of letter carriers, of what I had seen—I afterwards went into the Sorting Office again, about 8 o'clock, and picked out the prisoner, and he was taken into Mr. Sculthorpe's room.

Cross-examined by MR. GIFFAKD. Q. Do you mean to say that the prisoner was not in the Sorting Office at half-past 7 o'clock? A. I did not see him—I looked—I will not swear he was not there—it is a very large office—I believe there are twelve water closets altogether in this basement—four are for the letter earriers—they are parted off by a gate, so that each party can go to his proper place—you cannot go from one to the other without going through a different door—there are three doors, one for the clerks, one for the sorters, and one for the letter carriers—there is also a separate door to each closet—the gates were locked—they are put up on purpose that each person should go to his proper place—they do not always go to their proper places—I dare say they go to whichever is most convenient, but there is an order against it—the closets are all of the same construction—a man would not be able to get rid of a letter mere easily in the carriers' closet than the sorters,' only it would throw off suspicion—the grating is about the height of the man's head when he is sitting down—it is about four inches by eight—I and Smee were both looking through it—we were about two feet from the man, about level with his head—I saw him put a piece of paper down by his side when he first came in—I did not see the letter—I heard it crumple—I should think he sat there seven or eight minutes—I saw him undo his dress—he sat there as if he was using the closet—nobody had used it that morning but the prisoner—I think two used the one next to it—I was watching this particular closet—I saw two persons go to the next closet, one was a riding boy—I spoke to the prisoner afterwards about his having been to the water closet-that morning—he said he had been to the second one—that is the one I have been speaking of.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. What was it that passed between you and the prisoner? A. When I went to Mr. Sculthorpe's room I said to the prisoner, before I searched him, "You have been down to the water closet this morning"—he said, "Yes, I have"—I said, "Which closet did you go to?"—he said, "The second one"—I said, "Yes, you have been seen to destroy a letter there this morning"—he made no answer—I then saw Smee search him, and he produced a sovereign—I saw him take it out of the prisoner's pocket—he either gave it to me or laid it on the table—I took it up, and
asked the prisoner where he got it from—he said he took it in his wages last week.
COURT. Q. Had anything occurred which induced you to watch this particular closet? A. I was instructed to do so, and from information I had from Blackburn.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Was not what the prisoner said, that the sovereign was saved from his wages? A. He said he had saved it from his wages last week—I think he said "got" it, but I will not be certain which—it was one or the other—I knew him by sight, but not by name.

WILLIAM SMEE . I am a constable attached to the Post Office. On the morning of the 15th April I was watching this water closet—I relieved Peak about half-past 6 o'clock—it was one of the letter carriers' closets, the second from the corner, next the iron gate—I remained there until a quarter past 7 o'clock—I could see the entire of the closet through the grating—there is a gas light in the closet—up to that time nobody had entered the closet—at a quarter past 7 o'clock the prisoner came in—he turned himself round, and fastened the door—he then arranged his clothes and sat down on the seat—I then saw him put his left hand into his left coat pocket at the side of him (it was a shooting coat with two pockets)—he took something out, of the appearance of a letter, and brought it in front of him—he tore something with his hand of the appearance of a letter, but he sat in such a stooping position that I could not exactly see whether it was a letter or not—the paper was torn up in small pieces—I then saw him put his right hand behind him to the pan, and drop pieces of paper of the appearance of a letter—I saw a post stamp on part of it as it was felling—it was a red stamp—I directly turned off the water, to prevent them being washed away—after about a minute or so, the prisoner got up, arranged his clothes, and went out, and directly afterwards Blackburn came in—Peak and I were both together all the time—he left me for about a minute, and returned directly—he had the opportunity on his return of seeing into the water closet—he had not so good a position as I had—he could see the person in the closet—he had a better sight of his face when he came in than I had—when Peak went for Blackburn I remained watching, to see that no one else came in—no one but the prisoner came to that closet up to the time of Blackburn's coming—when he came he commenced taking out the fragments of a letter—I saw writing on them—it looked like a letter—it was all in small pieces—I went with him into his shop, which is in the vaults, and there he put them into a bucket of water, and washed them—we then put them together, and saw the address on them—I afterwards delivered them to Mr. Sculthorpe, after Blackburn had put his initials on some portions of them—I have here on this piece of tissue paper the papers I saw Blackburn take out of the pan, and also a portion of two cards—they are the same pieces that I received from Black-burn—one of the cards bears the name of "Mr. G. T. Attwater," and the other "Mrs. Frederick Davidge"—they had been torn up, but have since been put together—I afterwards gave information to Mr. Gapes, the inspector of letter carriers, and was in the office when he took the prisoner into Mr. Sculthorpe's private room—I heard Peak say to him, "You have been down to the water closets this morning"—the prisoner said, "Yes, I have"—Peak said, "The second one on the right from the door, in the letter carriers' closets?"—he said, "Yes"—Peak then said, "We saw you tear up a letter this morning"—the prisoner made no answer to that—I then searched him—in his left trousers pocket I found a purse containing a sovereign, half a crown, and a sixpence, and in his right trousers pocket

two sixpences, and three halfpence in copper—Peak then took up the purse and the sovereign, and asked the prisoner where he got this sovereign from, holding it in his hand at the time—the prisoner said, "I received it last week for my wages"—I then went and fetched Mr. Sculthorpe, and he was told all the circumstances in the prisoner's presence—we told him that we had been watching this certain closet in the basement, and that we saw the prisoner come in and tear up a letter—I then said, "I have searched the prisoner, and found a purse on him containing a sovereign, half a crown, and a sixpence, and two sixpences and three halfpence in the other pocket"—I then handed Mr. Sculthorpe the sovereign, which he closely examined—he held it up in his hand, and said to the prisoner, "Where did you get this sovereign from? I mean this particular sovereign, it is a George and Dragon sovereign of 1824"—the prisoner hesitated for a few seconds, and then said, "I received it from the bank with other money"—Mr. Sculthorpe asked him what bank, and he said, "The Provident Bank, St Martin's-lane"—Mr. Sculthorpe said, "When?"—he said, "About three or four months ago"—he was then given into custody—I took possession of the sovereign—I have had it ever since, and now produce it—from half-past 6 o'clock, when I went to relieve Peak, down to the time when Blackburn, brought these papers from the closet, no one had been to that closet but the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Was not what the prisoner said, that he got the sovereign from the bank last month? A. No; I did not try to ascertain from the Provident Bank, in St Martin's-lane, whether he had drawn out any money the month before, I am not aware that any one has done so—I had no instruction to go—there is a savings bank there, called the Provi
dent Institution—he did not say he got it out of the savings bank last March—he said "three or four months ago," he never mentioned any month—my deposition was read over to me before I signed it—this is my signature (The witness's deposition being ready stated: "The prisoner than stated he received it from the bank in March last")—it is my impression that he said "three or four months ago"—I will not say that what I said before the Magistrate was not true—I think he did say "March last)" I cannot say positively, it is some time ago—when Peak first spoke to him about the sovereign he said, "I received it last week for my wages"—he did not say he had saved it from his wages and drawn it out from the bank in March last—he said nothing about the bank at that time—I did not hear him mention the fact of having received it for his wages more than once, and that was to Peak: nor yet about the bank—the first of these conversations was about a little after 8 o'clock, and the other, I suppose, about 9 o'clock—it was in answer to Mr. Sculthorpe that he mentioned about drawing it from the bank—he did not use the word saved to Peak—that I swear—I heard Peak examined—I was not in the sorters' room about half-past 7 o'clock, I was at the door, and Peak had been in and said he could not see him—I looked through the door—I did not see him—he was not sitting in the same place as he was when I saw Mr. Gapes go in, and took him to the comptrollers' room—he might have been in some other seat—there might have been a dozen sorters there when I looked in, they were just returning from their breakfast—I believe they breakfast down stairs in the kitchen—I cannot say which water closet would be nearest to a person coming up from the kitchin—in order to get from the front of the water closet to the air shaft where Peak and I were, you must come up stairs into the office, go into the hall of the Boat Office and through a door, and down into the vaults—it would take about a minute or a

minute and a half to do that—I continued at the air shaft while Peak went for Blackburn—I saw Blackburn take out the fragments of a letter it was as light there with the gas, as it is here—I could not see right down into the hole, I saw him put an instrument down and bring them up, it was a wooden instrument about three or four feet long, I could not see how far down it went.
COURT. Q. You say you turned off the water, is there a handle in the air shaft for that purpose? A. Yes; each closet has a handle, I turned it off before he rose from the seat.
JURY. Q. Had the prisoner no means of destroying the letter except by putting it into the pan? A. I cannot say, there was an open gas light in the closet by which he could have burnt it.

WILLIAM BLACKBURN . I am a plumber employed at the General Post Office. On the morning of 15th April I was directed to go to the water closets on the basement—I went there about a quarter past 6 o'clock—Peak was not with me, he was in the air shaft; he could see me—I washed out the closet and stopped it, I put a sheet of brown paper into the trap; it is a self acting closet, the seat is on a spring, and when a person rises the water flows in—there is a trap below the pan—I washed that trap out—it is a ten inch trap, made of lead, and contains a gallon of water—the contents of the pan go into that trap in the ordinary way, and when the person rises the fall of water washes out the trap—I put the brown paper in the trap for the purpose of preventing anything from passing down it without my knowledge—after doing that I left the closet, leaving nothing but water and the brown paper in the trap—Peak was then at the grating; about a quarter past 7 o'clock Peak came and fetched me, and I went to the same closet—I examined the pan, I found that it had been used in the usual way—I cleared out the trap—I had an instrument made of two pieces of wood like a pair of tweezers, and with that I pulled up the contents of the trap with the sheet of brown paper—there was soil in the trap—I took out some torn pieces of paper and pieces of card, I picked out the pieces, put them into a sheet of brown paper, took them into my shop and washed them in Smee's presence—these are them—Smee wished me to mark one or two of them, which I did, and gave them to him—here are my marks—my attention had been called to this water closet the day before, and I took out seven letters from it.

Cross-examined. Q. What did you take out of the water closet when you went at a quarter past 7 o'clock, with your wooden tweezers? A. I took out the torn pieces of paper and some fragments of printed paper besides these—some parties had been to the closet, I cannot say who—I have no doubt it had been used in the ordinary way, I merely picked out the letter, I did not want those, I put the pieces of printed paper into the trap again, with the brown paper—the rushing of the water into the pan makes a noise, and can be seen by the person using the closet, about a gallon and a half of water flows in—when the water is turned off, there would, of course, not be that noise, the seat would rattle, but there would be no noise of gushing water—I washed out the four letter carriers' closets that morning—there are ten closets in a row, there is a wide space between the clerks' and the sorters', and an iron gate; that gate divides the two closets belonging to the sorters from the four belonging to the letter carriers—a person coming up from the sorters' kitchen would be nearest the sorters' closets—I cannot say whether the prisoner was in the habit of eating his breakfast in the letter carriers' kitchen, they take their breakfast as they can get the

chance—the place is very small, and they are tied for room, and they go where they can—the sheet of brown paper which I put in the trap I doubled up and pushed down—it would be supported simply by its own pressure against the sides of the trap—I found a great many fragments—I washed them and gave them all to Smee.

COURT. Q. Did you clear out the pan and trap that morning so as to be sure that these fragments were not there at that time? A. I am positive of that, I had special instructions from Mr. Sculthorpe with respect to that morning.
WILLIAM SMEE . re-examined. All the papers that Blackburn gave me I banded over to Mr. Sculthorpe, not arranged, but just as he gave them to me.

WALTER ROBERTSON SCULTHORPE . I am one of the assistant comptrollers of the London District Office. I have been in the Post Office thirty-two years. On the morning of 15th April, Smee came to me at my chambers, and in consequence of what he said, I went to the Post Office—I got there about 9 o'clock—I there found the prisoner in my private room with Peak and Smee—Peak informed me that the prisoner had been seen to destroy a letter in the water closet, and Smee handed me the fragments of a letter, and likewise a sovereign, which he stated he had found in the prisoner's pocket—I closely examined the sovereign, and asked the prisoner where he got it from—he hesitated and then said, "I received it from the bank in St. Martin's-lane"—Peak then said, "Why, you stated you received it for your wages"—I do not recollect that he made any reply to that—he was asked, I think, by Peak, what bank he had received it of, and he replied, "The Provident Bonk, or savings bank in St Martin's-lane"—I did not notice that he said at what time he had received it—I believe he has been in the Post Office about twenty years—I think his wages were 2l. 3s. 9d. a week—I received these fragments of a letter, envelope, and cards, from Smee—I put them together, and gave them to Peak—I find a General Post mark on one of the pieces, of 15th April—that denotes that it arrived at the Post Office in London on the 15th—that impression is pat on before the sorting—I also find the county post mark, "Gloucester"—the portion of the letter containing the date is destroyed—the first despatch to Hackney is at 7 o'clock, and the second at half-past 7.

Cross-examined. Q. I presume they have been pasted together in order to represent them as they were in their original condition before they were torn? A. Yes—I did it in a hurry—my chief object was to make out the address—it does not exactly represent what it was originally—there are some portions of it absent—there might have been another postage label on the envelope—a portion of the address is missing—the pieces do not fit in, because the whole of the envelope was not discovered—the defacing stamp is not all on the label here—it ought to be—but it is not always so—it is frequently done in a hurry—it was a larger envelope than I have made it—I put it in too small a compass—the prisoner would not have remained for twenty years in the Post Office if he had not borne a good character—every inquiry is made, but I am sorry to say that many dishonest persons get into the Post Office—the prisoner was nine years a letter carrier, and eleven years a sorter—I did not think it worth while to inquire as to the truth of his statement about getting the sovereign from the bank, because he had made two statements.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. I understand you that that portion of the envelope which should come next to the effaced stamp is missing? A. Yes—I have

put the other portion too close to the Queen's head, and so made it smaller, but it would not exactly fit if the piece was moved—there is an n, at the end of "Wood-street"—that does not form the proper conclusion of the word "cot
tages"—if the envelope had two stamps to it, that would explain the difficulty.

COURT. Q. If the prisoner was at the Post Office that morning would a Gloucester letter for Hackney pass through the department where he works? A. Yes—he was one of the sorters in that room—there are a great many sorters there, perhaps fifty—there were some other fragments of paper given me besides these, but not with writing on them—I may have thrown them away supposing they did not belong to the envelope.

THOMAS GAPES . I am an inspector of letter carriers of the London district at the General Post Office. I was there on the morning of 15th April—I saw the prisoner in the Sorting Office—I did not notice him until my atten
tion was called to him by the officer—that was, I think, about half-past 8 o'clock, or shortly after—I do not exactly recollect the time—I have the signing book here—the men sign this book when they arrive—it is kept in the Signing Office—it is no part of my duty to see to the signatures—Mr. Cook does that.

Cross-examined. Q. Is there any one here who can tell me whether the prisoner was in the sorters' room about half past 7 o'clock that morning? A. I saw him there about that time—I cannot say to a few minutes—that was before the officer called my attention to him—it was about that time—where they sit depends upon the nature of their duty—Mr. Cook sees to that—there is no fixed time for breakfast—they get it as they can.
THOMAS BURRELL COOK . I am superintendent of the Sorting Department—I saw the prisoner in the Sorting Office on the morning of 15th April; he was there at 5 o'clock.

Cross-examined. Q. Was that the only time you saw him there that morning? A. No; I saw him at 25 minutes past 7 o'clock in the morning—he left then—he was there from 5 o'clock till 25 minutes past 7 o'clock—he was then taken out of the room by the officers—I only remember Peak coming to the room once, that was when he pointed him out—he might have come in without my seeing him, if I was engaged—I know I am accurate about the time—I know how the duty progresses every minute—the prisoner could not have been absent without my knowledge—I cannot say he was there every minute, or every five minutes.

ELLEN ATTWATER . I am the wife of Thomas Attwater, of Brockworth Gonrt, about four miles from Gloucester. Our letters are left at the house of Mr. Watts, a tailor in the village, where they are called for by the postman—on the 14th of April I wrote a letter to my father, enclosing a sovereign in two cards, one of Mr. G. T. Attwater's and one of Mrs. Frederick Davidge—I put it in an envelope, and addressed it, "Mr. Woolbert, No. 2, Palace-cottages, Wells-street, South Hackney, near London"—the papers on this first piece of tissue paper form part of that envelope—I find here Mr. Attwater's card entire, and a portion of Mrs. Davidge's—I believe these to be the cards in which I enclosed the sovereign—I put two stamps on the letter, because I thought it might be over weight—this other piece of tissue paper contains nearly all the letter I wrote to my father—the sovereign I sent was a George and Dragon—I did not notice the date of it—my father is a great invalid—a person named Lizzy attends on him.

COURT. Q. Look at the word above the word "London," on that envelope; there is apparently an "n," can you account for that at all? A. It is "nr," for near London—I wrote that in the same line as "South Hackney."

JANE WHITING . I am servant to Mrs. Attwater. On 14th April my mistress gave me a letter to post—I did not look at the direction—I took it to Mr. Watts, the tailor, in the village, and gave it to him.

WILLIAM WATTS . I am a tailor at Brockworth, near Gloucester. I remember Whiting bringing a letter to me on 14th April—I saw my wife deliver that letter to Richard Bower, the postman, that same evening.

RICHARD BOWER . I am post messenger between Brockworth and Glou
cester. On 14th April I called, in the ordinary course, at Mr. Watts's, and received two letters—my attention was called to one of them—I took them to the Poet Office at Gloucester—I left them there, in the ordinary coarse.
ELIZABETH BERRY . On 15th April I was in attendance upon Mr. Woolbert, of No. 2, Palace-cottages, South Hackney—no letter came there on the morning of 15th April.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury, in consequence of his long services.—MR. CLARKSON. stated that there was another indictment against the prisoner, and that since his apprehension the loss of letters in that department had greatly diminished.—
Six Years Penal Servitude.

div0.p: NEW COURT.—Friday, May 30th, 1856
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. FINNIS.; Mr. Ald. WIRE. Mr. Ald. CURITT.; and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.
Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Seventh Jury)

div1.p:
540.
HARRIET GRAHAM
feloniously assaulting
John Munro Graham, and, by feloniously firing a pistol loaded with gunpowder and a leaden bullet, attempting to kill and murder him.—2nd COUNT, to do grievous bodily harm.
MR. PARKY. conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN MUNRO GRAHAM . I am a tragedian; I reside in Nelson-street, Camden-town; I perform at the Princess's Theatre. On Friday night, 2nd May, before 12 o'clock, I was in company with Mr. and Mrs. Brazier, and Mr. Cook, leaving the theatre—on reaching the gateway in Oxford-street, I saw the prisoner—she stepped forward, and presented a pistol—Mr. Brazier instantly said, "Good God, she has got a pistol!"—a snap was heard immediately—she presented the pistol towards me; as far as I could judge, it was towards my breast, or my face—I think she made an exclams
tion, but I cannot recollect it—a policeman came up, and the prisoner was taken—she had formerly lived with me—I have been separated from her about two years.

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. How long had you lived with her? A. Eleven or twelve years—I called her my wife, and represented her to the world as Mrs. Graham everywhere I went—I did not leave her to live with another woman—I have not been living with another woman at all—I have not been off and on keeping company with another woman, not with any other women—I have been keeping company with a young woman at Bow, but not living with her—I have kept company with her.

Q. During the last two years you have not only not been living with the prisoner, but have done nothing towards her support? A. Yes, I have, for nearly twelve months; I paid her 1l. a week, provided she did not break the
peace, but she did once or twice, and I took her to the police office—I have allowed her something during the last twelve months, but I have not allowed it regularly.

THOMAS BRAZIER . I am engaged as an actor in the same theatre. I was leaving the stage door that night with Mr. Graham, as he has described—I saw the prisoner, in about three or four seconds, coming towards him, and with her hand she presented a pistol—I heard the click of it decidedly, and at the station I saw it unloaded—there was in it a ball, some powder, and other matters.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you hear what the prisoner said? A. No—I was walking arm in arm with Mr. Graham, and she met us—it was all the work of a moment.

COURT. to JOHN MUNRO GRAHAM. Q. Did you hear the prisoner say any
thing about the pistol? A. At the police station some one remarked, after the pistol had been examined, that this pistol would not go off—the prisoner replied, "Yes, it will; go to my place, and you will see where I have tried it; you will see two or three marks."

JAMES CRASKE . (policeman, E 160). I was on duty in Oxford-street that night—the first I saw was Mr. Graham and Mr. Brazier had hold of the prisoner; one had hold of each arm, and she was struggling on the footway—I went towards them, and I beard some one say, "I heard the click"—I went on my hands and knees—the prisoner's petticoat was nearly off—I at last found this pistol under her knees—I took it to the station, and saw the inspector draw the powder and ball from the pistol—the cap was not exploded—some one said, "I don't think the pistol would go off"—the pri
soner said, "Oh, yes, it will; go to my place, and you will see where I have tried it on a door."

COURT. Q. What was in the pistol? A. A ball, some powder, and this paper was at the bottom of the pistol—it is greasy, or oily—I cannot say whether the pistol could have gone off—this is the percussion cap.

JOHN EDWARD HARRISON . I believe I am illegitimately related to the prisoner. I had been in the habit of visiting at the house where she lived for the last three weeks before this occurrence—I am a reporter—this pistol belongs to me—I was in the habit of practising with this pistol in the yard of the house where the prisoner lived, for several days before this took place—on that Friday I was practising with it in the yard—I left there about half past 4 o'clock—when I left, I left this pistol on the table—I did not say anything to the prisoner about it—she was not there at the time I left the house—the detonating powder is still in this percussion cap—if the trigger had struck the pistol, with this cap on—the nipple, it would have exploded.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Had you left the cap on the pistol? A. Yes, on the table in the kitchen, and pulled the cock down—the prisoner lives in the kitchen—I live in William-street, Islington, not in the house where the prisoner lives—I have seen her fire off the pistol several times—she fired it off herself—I used to fire once, and she afterwards, to see which could hit the mark—no other lady did so—the prisoner lives in Little Saffron-hill—I believe I am her brother—I took this pistol from my house to her house, and left it there—I was practising it there for amusement—the prisoner did not ask me to teach her to fire it, but she did fire it—she had fired it on the day before, and on the day before that, and on the day before that—she had only been firing it three or fbur days—I do not know that
she had formerly attempted to stab Mr. Graham—I know that she had been held to bail for threatening to ill-treat him—I did not buy this pistol—I had it given me by a cousin who is gone to Australia.
COURT. Q. Did you load the pistol? A. I loaded it, and I made the ballets—I made this bullet that was found in it—I fired at a mark with bullets like this.
JURY. Q. Is there any yard at the house in which you live? A. No—there is a small yard at the house where the prisoner lived—I could not practise the pistol where I live.

GUILTY. on 2nd Count .—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor and Jury.
Judgment Respited

541.
ELIZABETH JONES and
SUSAN GRANT
, stealing 1 purse, value 6d.; and 8s. 8s. in money; the property of
Charles Masters Terry, from the person of
Rebecca Terry.
MR. COOPER. conducted the Prosecution.

JOSEPH TAYLOR . I am the driver of a Wellington omnibus from the Elephant and Castle to Shoreditch. On 5th May, about half-past 5 o'clock in the afternoon I was driving from the Elephant and Castle, I was hailed by the two prisoners at Thomas-street in the Borough—I had seen the prisoners before and seen them together—they entered my omnibus, and I made a communication to the conductor—I believe the prisoners left my omnibus in Gracechurch-street—I saw them passing towards Leadenhall-street—the conductor made a communication to me.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you take up more passengers after the prisoners got in? A. No; I believe I had ten before them—I only take twelve—believe some one got out at the steps—a lady got in at the statue.

HENRY DEAN . I am conductor of this omnibus. On 5th May, the prisoners got in at Thomas-street in the Borough—the last witness made a com
munication to me when they got in—in consequence of that I occasionally looked in the omnibus—I recollect the prosecutrix getting in between London-bridge and Gracechurch-street—Jones sat on her right side and Grant sat opposite to her—I was called to to stop, and the prisoners got out on the other side of Cornhill—on their stepping out one of them paid me a shilling for the two, and I gave her change—they both left and went across the road—I received some information from the driver, made some inquiries of the persons in the omnibus, and the prosecutriz said that she had lost something—I went after the prisoners with a policeman—when I came up to them they were in a passage in the street, I gave them into custody and fetched the prosecutrix.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. How many persons were in the omnibus when the prisoners got in? A. It was pretty full; I cannot tell whether there were ten or twelve—I think Jones sat the fourth or fifth from the door—they had crossed the road before I said anything to anybody inside the omnibus.

REBECCA TERRY . I am the wife of Charles Masters Terry, of Sutton-street, York-road. I got into the omnibus in Gracechurch-street—I do not remember seeing the prisoners—I had my purse in my hand just before I got in, and I believe I put it into my pocket—I intended to do so—the conductor made a remark, and I put my hand into my pocket, and did not find my purse—I do not know what was in it, but I believe there was 8s.—that was found in it—a gentleman took me to a passage—I there

saw these prisoners—one of them said to me, "Here is the purse, don't say we had it"—I took it—they were close together—one heard what the other said—as far as I remember she said, "Here is the purse, don't say we had it"—I did not wish to prosecute—I did not look in the purse at the time—I looked at it at the station house, and there was 8s. 6d. in it—the officer said something to me—I do not think the prisoners heard it.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Were there many people about? A. I should think there were forty or fifty—I did not say that I had my purse in my hand—I did not say, "Here is my pmrse;" or, "I have got my purse in my hand"—I do not know who put the purse into my hand—I suppose it was the one that spoke to me—I did not say, "Why, here I have got it in my hand"—it was quite my intention to put my purse into my pocket when I got to the omnibus, I will not swear that I did so—I paid the conductor when I got out; I did not take the money out of my purse, I had some halfpence in my pocket—the conductor asked me if I had lost anything—that was before I paid him—I did not intend to get oat—I had but one pocket; that was on my right side.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Had you gloves on? A. Yes—I kept them on when the conductor spoke to me—I did not pull my glove off; I put my hand into my pocket with my glove on—I thought from the conductor's question that I had dropped the purse and the conductor had found it—when one of the prisoners said this to me, the policeman was talking to the conductor—I suppose he was three or four yards from me—there were many persons nearer to me than he was—several of the passengers got out before I got out.
MR. COOPER. Q. Was this an old fashioned pocket? A. It was in my dress on my right hand side—the purse was the only thing I received in that passage, that I am quite sure of.
COURT. to HENRY DEAN. Q. On which side of Mrs. Terry did the prisoner who sat by her, sit? A. On the right side.

THOMAS GOWLAND . I am a silversmith and jeweller, I live in Leaden-hall-street. On the afternoon of 5th May, the two prisoners came hastily into my passage, and I went to the door of my shop—immediately a crowd came round—the lady came up with the policeman—the prisoners were brought further into the passage to the side door of the house—I begged the policeman to keep the people back, and said he had better bring the lady farther in—they went in, and I heard the prisoners urging the lady to take the purse back again—I saw Jones put her hand towards the prosecntrix with something in it—she appeared to me to pass it to the prosecutrix—the prosecutrix said they had given her the purse back again—the prisoners could hear that.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Were you in the shop? A. No, in the passage, I went from the shop to the passage—I saw something in one of the prisoners' hands—I could not tell exactly what it was—it was about the size of the purse—I saw the left hand closed and something in it—I understood from what was said, that they were urging her to take it back—I immediately told the policeman—I cannot tell positively what was said, but I concluded they were urging her to take it back, by their words and actions—before forming that conclusion, I heard the evidence before the Magistrate—there were a few persons outside, I got the policeman to keep them back from the passage—it is the passage leading to my side door—my window goes up the passage, it forms a lobby to my shop.
JOHN JACOB . (City policeman, 35). On 5th May, about 6 o'clock in the

evening, the conductor came to me and I followed die prisoners to the passage of No. 5, Leadenhall-street—I said, "The conductor says there has Seen a lady robbed in the omnibus, and you are suspected of being the parties"—they said, "It is not us, we will go and see the lady"—I said, "Do you live here?"—they said, "No, we are going to make a call"—I did not let them go—I said, "You must remain here till the lady comes"—just then the lady came up—I asked if she had been robbed—she said, "Yes"—I asked if she knew the parties—she said, "No"—Grant came to the outside of the passage endeavouring to get out, and Jones was with the proeecutrix farther in the passage, and Jones turned round and said, "The lady has found her purse, she is not going to press the charge against us"—I said to the lady, "Is that true?"—she held the purse up, but made no answer—I then took them to the station, and in going Jones said she hoped I should not say anything against her, and she would well recom
pense me for it; and Grant threw down or let fall three sovereigns and a Half sovereign—Jones said, "You will go to my address, won't you?"—I said, "I shall go to the one you give me"—she said, "I hope, you will do something for me, a half sovereign would go a long way"—I said, "It is no talking, to me in that way, all you say I shall say before the Magis
trate"—she said, "Then all I said will die away"—I went to the address she gave, No. 24, Walworth-road.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Did you see the prosecutrix come up? A. Yes; I was not near enough to hear all that passed between her and Jones, for Grant came to me and was wanting to get out—Jones and the prosecutrix were at the end of the passage, I could see them, but could not see their movements—I might be two yards from them when Jones dropped? A. I turned round just as they were dropped, one of them was rolling towards me—I stooped and picked it up, and another person took up the others—Grant did not show a hole in her pocket before me.

WILLIAM FITZGERALD . (City policeman, 536). I was with the last witness conveying the prisoners to the station—I saw three sovereigns and a half drop from Grant—I picked up a half sovereign, and three sovereigns were picked up in my presence.

JONES*—
GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Twelve Months.

GRANT—
GUILTY . Aged 33.
(Grant was further charged with having been before convicted.)

JAMES THOMAS SYMONS . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's con
viction—(read: Newington Sessions, May, 1855, Susan Hawkins, con
victed of stealing a purse and 2l. 7s. Confined four months")—Grant is the person—I had her in custody.

GRANT—GUILTY.
Confined Twelve Months.

div0.p: THIRD COURT.—Friday, May 30th 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. CUBITT.; Mr. Ald. EAGLETON.; and MICHAEL PRENDERGAST, Esq.

p.hi: Before Michael Prendergast, Esq., and the Second Jury.

div1.p:
542.
JOHN RAYMOND and
WILLIAM WREN
, robbery on
Char
lotte King, and stealing from her person, 3l. 10s.; her money.
MR. PAYNE. conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLOTTE KING . I am an unfortunate woman, and live at No. 11 Wellesley-street, Seymour-street, New-road. On the night this happened, I went into Smith's coffee shop, Caledonian-road—I had four sovereigns and 3s. in a purge—I had some supper, which came to 5d.—I know Wren, he was a waiter there—I had seen him very often when I have been there—I gave him a sovereign to pay for what I had, and he brought me the change, half a sovereign, and the rest in silver—I then went outside the door, and Wren asked me if I would lend him 5s.—I said, "You do not want it"—he said, "I do"—I said, "I will lend you half a crown," and I did so—while I was talking to him a friend of mine, a girl, came up; she went in with me and I paid for her supper, and a young man's, who was with her—while I was talking to them Wren came in, and said, "There is a young woman waiting to speak to you at the door"—I went out, and he went with me; I said, "Where is she?"—he said, "I do not know"—I looked round the corner to see where she was, and Raymond knocked me down—I have seen him in the coffee shop, he was not employed there—he struck me on the back of the neck, and pushed me as well, knocked me down, and took my purse, which was round my finger—I saw no young woman: Wren stood on the step of the door looking on, while the other knocked me down, but he did not interfere at all—I did not see the man before he knocked me down, he held me down with one hand, and took my purse with the other—he hit me very hard, my neck and head were very sore afterwards; he hit and pushed me both at once—he hit me with his left hand, he had a crutch in his right, but did not hit me with that, he is lame—I screamed when he pulled my purse off my finger, but Wren did not take any notice; he was there when I was knocked down and when I got up, but did not help me, or join in the attack upon me—Raymond walked from me and stood against the lamp post, and there he stood when I got up—I said to Wren, "You have been the instigation of my being robbed, and I will not have you locked up if you will give it to me, and I said the same to Raymond—at the time I was saying it, Jane Hamilton came out at the door; they both denied the charge, and said that they knew nothing of it.

COURT. Q. While you were talking to Wren, Raymond stood near the lamp post? A. Yes, he did not run away—when Jane Hamilton came out I said, "I have lost my money, and this man has robbed me"—I had my hand on his shoulder, and he went into the coffee shop; I followed him, and told Mrs. Smith—she said that she knew nothing about it—when Jane Hamilton came, she accused Wren of the robbery, and he said that he knew nothing about it—while she was talking to Raymond, Wren went into the coffee shop—when I went in and spoke to Mrs. Smith, I left Raymond outside, still talking with my friend, she was accusing him of the robbery when I went in.

MR. PAYNE. Q. After you had spoken to Mrs. Smith, did you go for a policeman? A. I could not get one at King's-cross, and I went to Isling
ton; when I came back I saw a policeman by the coffee shop, and he took Raymond into custody, who was standing on the opposite side of the way—that was nearly an hour afterwards—he said that he knew nothing about it, and did not care—Wren was inside the coffee shop waiting on some one, when the policeman went in; he was taken into custody—he said that he would go, but he did not know anything about it (I had 3l. 15s., or 3l. 16s.)—I think it was a little before 1 o'clock in the morning when the policeman came; it was five or six minutes after 12 o'clock when I lost my money—I had

got none of it that night; I got some of it two or three nights before—I have not got it back nor my purse—I got the money from different gentle
men, and had been saving it up to go into the country—I do not always carry my money about, but I was going to meet some young girls who I knew to wish them good bye—I was only going up to Islington, I do not call that the country—I was going to Bargewell, in Norfolk, fourteen miles from Norwich—I have been in London two or three years—I was knocked down and robbed before I could hardly get off the step of the door.

COURT. Q. You had been in the habit of going to that coffee shop many times? A. Yes—I live some way from it—I had seen Raymond before at the coffee shop when I have walked through—there is convenience at the coffee shop for persons of my calling—I have been there a great many times.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Was there a crowd outside? A. No—at the time I was knocked down I only saw Wren and Raymond there—there was nobody else there—I was knocked down directly I got out-side—I do not know how many persons were in the coffee shop—there was a young girl with me—she was in the private room, and there was a young man who was having supper with her—not a single soul saw me knocked down—Wren is not the owner of the coffee house, he is the waiter—Raymond has nothing to do with the house that I know of—I have seen him there as I passed through sometimes—I have not said that he struck me on the forehead with his crutch or with his hand—I said that he held me down, with his hand on my forehead, but did not knock me hard—that was when I was knocked down, and while he was taking the money from me he hit me with his open hand—Wren was on the step of the door—the girl was inside finishing her supper—the door was not open—she could not see—there are two doors—Wren served in the shop, and Mrs. Smith and the servant girl were serving in the bar, which is through the shop—I did not notice any customers in the shop when I went out, but there were some when I first went in—two men were sitting by the fire when I first went in—it was on the step of the door that Wren asked me to lend him some money—the girl desired me not to pay a sovereign in the shop, but before that I paid down a sovereign and thought it was a shilling—it was before that that Wren asked me to lend him five shillings—I was then outside the door on the step—I had changed the sovereign before that—the other girl came from the Caledonian-road—I went into the shop alone at first, that was to have my supper—I gave Wren the half crown on the step of the door just as the other girl was coming up—the rest of my money was in my purse at that time—I do not know the young man's name—I had seen him before—I am not an acquaintance of hia, but I have seen him with my friend—I do not know whether he is a witness here—I have not seen him since—he was in the coffee shop at the time I was knocked down—he did not call out, but when I called out he came out—he said that he did not hear me—when I first went in with the other girl I do not know whether the two men were there, but they were when I first went in—I brought my money out because I was going to see some girls whom I knew, and I might spend some of it—I did not think anything about losing it or I should not have taken it—I did not show it to the other girl—she knew that I had it, because she lived with me, and knew that I took it out—she left the house with me—I did not see her first in the coffee shop, I left with her at 8 o'clock in the even
ing, and took my money in my purse—I did not tell her the reason I was taking it—she told me to leave the money at home, and I would not—I told her I was going to Islington to see somebody—it was a small green purse, a

long one, with tassels at the end of it—after I left borne I walked about to see if I could see some girls whom I wanted to meet—I was four houre walking about, and went to the coffee shop about a quarter before 12—I had not been in any house, and did not see anybody; yes, I went and had three glasses of stout with three gentlemen—I had no gin, I am quite sure of that—I had appointed to meet the other girl at the coffee shop, and she got there after I came out—only two girls live in the same house.

COURT. Q. Whereabouts is it you live? A. In Wellesley-street, which runs out of Seymour-street—from the time that I was knocked down to the time Raymond was given in charge, he was not very far off the same place—neither purse or money has been found—I had no bruise, but my head was very bad where he hit me.

Cross-examined by MR. M'ENTEER. Q. Did Wren know you? A. Yes, by seeing me go there—there was a public house on the opposite side—nobody came to assist me—I called out my Mend's name very loudly—I have not said that a person named Staines robbed me—I knew Mrs. Smith, and she knew me, as going to that house—she did not come out.

COURT. Q. You made your complaint to Mrs. Smith? A. Yes, and I think Wren heard that—he did not answer, that I know of, when I told her that I had been robbed—I said nothing to her about borrowing the half crown, nor did he—Mrs. Smith saw that I had money, because I paid her some money that T owed her before—I did not get the change for the sove
reign then—my supper only came to 5d.—I paid Mrs. Smith the money before I Went out to see whether the girl was there—I paid her the money when Jane Hamilton was with me—I do not know whether it was two or three shillings I paid her.

JANE HAMILTON . I live in Wellesley-street, at the same house as the last witness. I went out with her on this night—I cannot say the time, but I think it was about 10 o'clock—she had 4l. 3s. with her—I saw it, it was four sovereigns and 3s.—she had it in a long blue purse, with tassels.
COURT. Q. A blue or a brown purse? A. I cannot say exactly, either a blue or green.

MR. PAYNE. Q. About how long had you remained with her when you went out together? A. About half an hour—an appointment was made to meet at the Crown public house in the Caledonian-road—I went there about 12 o'clock, or a little after; I did not find her there, and proceeded to Smith's coffee shop—she was standing outside the door with the waiter—I had a young man named Joseph with me; I do not know his surname—I knew him, and had supper with him, for which Charlotte Ring paid; she took out a sovereign, and called Wren to take it—I told her not to change a sovereign when she had got silver in her purse, and she put down half a crown—after that Wren told her that a girl Wanted her outside, she went out first, and Wren followed—I and the young man remained—in about four or five minutes she screamed, and called my name; I went to the door, which was closed, and as I opened it, she was coming in crying—the prisoners were both standing outside, and she pointed to Raymond, and said, "That man has knocked me down, and taken my money"—he denied it: he had a crutch—Wren said nothing that I heard; he went inside—I am sure that he was standing at the door, because I was the first person that went to the door after the cry—I am sure he did not go to the door before me, he was standing outside when I went out—he came to the table and said, "Here is a young woman wants to speak to you"—she went out, and he followed her out of the shop—I could not see the door where I was—there

is a private place where people can go and have supper, it is next to where they serve—I was in the little room behind, inside—I did not see Wren inside the place after he said that a girl wanted her outside, and went out—there were some people sitting there when we went in—Charlotte King went into the shop first, and left me and Raymond outside—I opened the door in two or three minutes, and she was in the shop accusing Wren of being the instigation of her being robbed, and when I opened the door she came out—we went together to look for a policeman, it may have been half an hour before we found one—Raymond was given in charge, he was then standing opposite the coffee shop—I did not say anything to Raymond outside, nor did I hear what she said to him—he still stood there—the pro
secutrix was perfectly sober, and so was I; I had had nothing to drink that night.

COURT. Q. Have you been long acquainted with Charlotte King? A. About four or five months, but I have known her since she was a child; we were both children together in Norfolk—I lived at Market Dereham, and she at Bargewelt—I have been in London about three years—I knew that the had this money—she was going to meet some friends, and took out the money—I wished her to leave it at home—by friends, I mean females—I do not know what she was going to do, or any object which she had in taking out the money—we lodge at Mr. Watkins's, we are the only two girls in the house—I have got my room, and she has got her's—we do not live together—I know Mrs. Smith who keeps the coffee house, we were in the habit of going there almost every night to have supper—the Crown public house, where we were going to meet, is not far, it is about: five minutes walk—I was in the habit of going to the Crown as well as to this place.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Is this public house near the coffee shop? A. Yes, Mr. Wheeler's is—that is not the Crown, the Crown is further up; it is the Queen's Arms—there is only one public house in the street; there is more than one in the Caledonian-road, but opposite the coffee shop there is but one—I walked as far as Bingham-street, Caledonian-road, with the last witness; I was not more than hall an hour with her—I appointed to meet her at the Crown, we generally used to meet there, outside—I met her close by the Crown, just as I was going in—we generally used to meet each other outside—I had been for a walk after leaving her—I had not been in anywhere, or been drinking—I had nothing to drink with the young man Joseph, but he had a glass of stout—he paid for it—I did pot have any—there was just upon a dozen people at the Crown, drinking at the bar—there was a concert held there, and they had just come down—I remained five or ten minutes, I did not see Charlotte King there; I first saw her outside the coffee house, standing by a lamp post—nobody was with her but the waiter—when I passed through the coffee shop there were some people sitting there—I cannot say whether there were half a dozen, then were more than two, but I cannot say as to three—I do not know what they were doing—as you go through the shop there is a bar where they serve, and there is a door leading into the room, but it is not a room, it is a box—there is a partition and a door; the partition runs up to the ceiling—it is not a very large room—it is in the shop that they serve—after this had happened, Charlotte King told me that she had had nothing to drink—that was as we were going to the station house; she told me that without my askinrr her: I do not know why—I have not been talking about this matter
since to her, we are not together—we have not quarrelled, but she is away from me; she is in Middlesex Hospital as an in-patient.
CHARLOTTE KING . re-examined. I am in the hospital now, I was not when this happened—this (produced) is my certificate.

ROBERT BARR . (policeman, N 207). About 12 o'clock on this night I was in the Caledonian-road, and saw Wren and the prosecutrix outside Smiths coffee house talking—I saw them again about a quarter past 12 o'clock, Hamilton was then there, and they all went into the coffee shop—about a quarter past 1 o'clock I was called to take Raymond into custody; I had seen him by the coffee shop about half past 12 o'clock, and about a quarter of an hour afterwards saw him cross the road from the coffee shop—when I took him he was standing on the opposite side, about forty yards from the coffee shop—they both denied the charge.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. How long was it from the time you first saw these women to the time you apprehended Raymond? A. About an hour and a half—there was a man with them when I saw them first, at a quarter past 12 o'clock, and there might be two or three others, but I cannot be certain whether there were two or three others besides Wren—I did not see Raymond at that time—they were outside the coffee shop then—there were two others, I believe—when I saw Wren the first time, he and the prose
cutri were by themselves—the second'time I saw Wren, the prosecutrix, Hamilton, and, I think, two men, I cannot be certain whether there were one or two—Wren was one—they were strangers to me—Raymond was not there—I do not know when the assault was committed—I cannot tell you whether it was before or after she was knocked down that I am speaking of—they were talking together, and I walked on—my beat is by there—I went on as far as North-street, which is about 150 yards—I went up the Caledonian-road, but at the distance I went did not command a view of the coffee house—I should not have heard a scream, because there are so many carriages—I go down as far as King's-cross—I was at the end of the Caledonian-road by King's-cross when King spoke to me.

Cross-examined by MR. MAC ENTEER. Q. When you accused Wren, what did he say? A. He denied all knowledge of it—the prosecutrix said that she had told Mrs. Smith—when she gave him in charge Mr. Smith was present, but I do not know whether Mrs. Smith was—Wren has been long at the coffee house—I saw Raymond at half past 12 o'clock that evening, and again at a quarter to 1 o'clock, standing by himself just by the door in the Caledonian-road—no complaint was made at that time—I have often seen him standing there, but not lately.

COURT. to CHABLOTTE KING. Q. Did you leave the door to find the young woman? A. No, I had not time to do so—as soon as I got to the door I was robbed—I did not repeat this story about Wren in the presence of Mrs. Smith—I was talking to Wren in the shop, and Mrs. Smith was in the bar—she did not hear what I said that I know of, she was in the parlour—my head was very sore, but there was no bruise—I am not in the hospital in consequence of any hurt that I received on that night.

COURT. to ROBEKT BARR. Q. Did King appear hurt, did she complain? A. She did not complain of being hurt at all—she made the statement that she had been knocked down—(Wren's statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows: "The girl did send me to ask the prosecutrix to come out and see her, but when we went to the door the girl was not there: the prosecutrix ran down the road after her.")

COURT. to ROBERT BARR. Q. Do you know this coffee shop? A. Yes, persons of all sorts are in and out there all night long—it is an accommoda
tion house—I do not mean anything improper, but only for refreshment—I do not think it is a place where men and women go.

COURT. to JANE HAMILTON. Q. You go to this house? A. Yes, I have been there over and over again—you can have beds for the night there—I have slept there, not by myself but with men—I have only slept there once with a man—unless persons apply for a night's lodging, the accommodation is not given—if you ask for a bed for the night, you are accommodated for the night—you would not be accommodated for a quarter of an hour or an hour, that I am aware of—there is a parlour behind the coffee shop—I am not able to say whether that room is kept private if men and women go in—men and women could not carry on that sort of intercourse there, that I am aware of, without interruption—there is a sofa there, but not a bed.

CHARLOTTE KING . re-examined. There is such a room, to my knowledge, and if men and women go into it they will not be interrupted—I do not know whether anything is paid for it—I never paid anything, and never saw anything paid for going into the separate room.
MR. MAC ENTEER . called

MARY LAWRENCE SMITH . I am the keeper of the coffee house where Wren officiates—he has lived with us twice, the first time for one year, and the last time for two years—his character is unimpeachable.

COURT. Q. You heard the complaint of the prosecutrix? A. Yes—she came in some time afterwards, and said that Wren had sent her out, and she was robbed; she did not say by a man with a crutch—I did not send for a policeman—she did not say that she was robbed at our door, she only said that it was outside—I did not hear her cry or call out, "Jane!"—I was in the bar—she called out, "Joseph, Joseph I"—that is the young man who was with them, and then Jane Hamilton went out, and Joseph too—she was in the house when she called out that—she only called out "Joseph!" and they all three went out together—the prosecutrix seemed excited—she ran into the house when she said, "Joseph, Joseph!"—I did not hear her say,"Jane!"—she did not complain, for I sent my waiter out to see what was the matter: that is Wren—about twenty minutes afterwards the prosecutrix came into the bar, and said that Wren was as bad, for he had sent her out—I heard that she had been robbed when Wren returned.

COURT. to JANE HAMILTON. Q. When you were called, how were you called? A. "Jenny, Jenny!"—they were very pitiful cries, they came from outside the house—the bar is in front of where we sat to have our supper—I had to pass through the shop, and as I opened the door King was coming in at the door, crying—I heard her crying before she opened the door, when I was sitting having my supper, and I jumped up and went out—you sit behind the door to have your supper, and the bar is in the front—as you open the door the bar is on one side, and the place where you have your supper is on the other—they are both equally near the door—the cries were quite audible—that was what brought me out—they would be as audible in the bar—they could hear as well in one place as in another—it was in a pitiful voice and a loud voice—she was crying—Wren was outside when I got out, and Raymond" by the side of him—I had seen the purse, I dare say ten minutes before, or more than that—she had it wound round her finger when she went out of the coffee shop.
COURT. to MRS. SMITH. Q. You took some money of her? A. Yes, I gave her change—I saw the purse, but did not notice it—my waiter received

a sovereign from her to pay for the supper, and he gave her the change—it was, I think, half a sovereign, and the rest in silver—I do not know whether she had the purse or not—I gave my waiter the change—I am certain that it was given to her, and after that she brought me 3s. 6d. which she owed me—that was the second time she came in.

COURT. to ROBERT BARR. Q. I suppose there are various little turnings about there? A. Yes, there is a court just by, at the back, which abuts about a dozen yards from the coffee house—there is a light against the door—the house is at the corner of Caledonia-crescent, it stands in the Gale-donian-road—it is quite light at the door, you can distinguish faces fast enough—Raymond did not seem muff confused when I went up to him—I observed no mark of embarrassment about him—he always wears a crutch; he cannot go without it very well.

(—Mitchell, a tailor, of Gresham-place, Portland-road, and William S—, boot maker, of No. 4, Portland-road, gave Raymond a good character; George Dawkins Lane, sturgeon and half-pay officer, and John Fry, fruiter and greengrocer, of No. 75, St. John-street, gave Wren a good character.)

RAYMOND—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

WREN—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

543.
ANN WILLSON was indicted
for wilful and corrupt perjury.
MR. PARRY. conducted the Prosecution, and MR. PAYNE. the Defence.
MR. PARRY. withdrew from the prosecution.
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: OLD COURT.—Saturday, May 31st, 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. RECORDER.; Mr. Ald. FINSIS.; and Mr. Ald. EAGLETON.

p.hi: Before Mr. Recorder and the Seventh Jury.

div1.p:
544.
JOHN MARKHAM
, feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of 91l.; with intent to defraud.
MESSRS. SLEIGH. and POLAND. conducted the Prosecution.

CHARLES FREDERICK ASH . I am an iron merchant, carrying on business at Nos. 20 and 21, Upper Thames-street Early in Feb. last my premises were broken into—among other things, I missed two blank cheques from my cheque book—they were the ordinary cheques of a cheque book of Messrs. Smith, Payne, and Smith's, the bankers, and numbered 15430—other things besides the cheques were also taken—this cheque for 91l. (pro
duced) purporting to be signed by me, is not my writing—I never authorised any one to sign it—I believe it to be one of the blank cheques that were taken from my cheque book when my premises were broken into—it is a very good imitation of my handwriting.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You know nothing about the prisoner? A. No.

COURT. Q. What is your reason for believing that to be one of the cheques you missed from your premises? A. It bears the same number, and is a fac-simile in every respect—the counterfoils were also taken—each cheque bore the same number—I lost some bills and papers at the same time, with my signature to them.
JAMES HUMPHREYS . I live at No. 54, Seymour-place, Bryanston-square.

I am not in any employment at present—I was last employed by Mr. Harris, the tailor, of Oxford-street, as porter—in Feb. last I was out of a situation—on the 18th I put an advertisement in the Times, and among other replies I received one purporting to come from a gentleman of the name of Hammond—in consequence of receiving that note I went next afternoon, between 2 and 3 o'clock, to No. 6, Oakley-crescent, City-road—I inquired for Mr. Hammond, and was shown np stairs, into the front room, and there saw a person calling himself Mr. Hammond—the prisoner is the person—if it is not the same person it is one just like, him—he asked me who I was—I told him I was James Humphreys—he said he wished me to produce the note, and then he should see which it was that had come, because he had written to several—I gave him the note—he said he had got business to do at Oxford and in London, and he should want me to collect bills and likewise to look after his horse and chaise—he said he was in Oxford some
times and sometimes in London, but his residence was in Oxford—I told him I could not take the situation because he said he wished me to go to live at Oxford—he said he would rather I would see him again to
morrow, he should like me to take his situation—he said, "I rather like your appearance, and if you will come to-morrow morning I have a few little jobs for you to do, if you don't mind undertaking them"—I then left—that was all that passed that day—I was with him perhaps six minutes—he—had his hat on during this conversation—he was sitting when' I went in, but he was standing part of the time—I went again next morning about 10 o'clock—he was not in—I waited for him in the passage—he came in in a few minutes—he went up stairs first and asked me to wait a minute—he afterwards called me up stairs—I had told him on the first occasion where I had been living, but that morning I told him I had made up my mind not to undertake the situation—he then asked if I would mind doing a few little jobs for him, and asked me to go to the Euston Station to fetch him luggage, a portmanteau and a carpet bag, coming from Bath, I believe—he said, "You know my name, you can ask; for Mr. Hammond's luggage"—I went and there was no luggage for him there—they said I had better go to the luggage department at Camden-town, which I did, but did not find any—I then went back to the prisoner—I found him waiting for me—I told him I could not find any luggage for Mr. Hammond—he said he did not know how it was that it was not there, it ought to have been there; however, it did not signify, he must send again—he then asked me if I would go to Lombard-street foot him, to take a cheque—I said yes—he gave me the cheque—this produced is it—I was to take it to. Smith and Sons, or Smith and Payne's, in Lombard-street, and get 91l.—he told me to get so much in notes and so much in gold I forget what it was exactly, and bring it back to him—he said, "I suppose, you have not had your dinner"—I said, "No, sir"—he said, "I will give you sixpence, and you can have it before you come back, as I have act got the wherewith here to provide it for you"—I then took the cheque to Smith, Payne, and Smith's, the bankers, in Lombard-street, and presented it at the counter for payment—it was refused—I was taken into the; bank, and from there to Messrs. Mullens, the solicitors—I made a communication to them—I was detained there while they made inquiry about my character, and I was then released—I did not go back to the prisoner—on 5th April, I was taken by Mr. Forrester to the House of Detention (I had previously given a description of the person from whom I had the cheque)—I was taken to the doors of different cells, and was desired to look in each cell as I

passed—two servants of the House of Detention were with us; one went before and opened the door, and the other came behind—I looked into each cell as I passed—I looked into twenty or thirty, it might be—I had passed all the cells except the last one, and after I had passed the servant said, "Have you seen any one that you know I" and I said "The last one that I passed was something like him"—the prisoner was in the last cell—the officer then said, "You have passed them all"—a day or two afterwards I went to Marlborough-street police court—I there saw the prisoner—I recognized him immediately upon his being brought into Court—I now believe him to be the man.

Cross-examined. Q. Have you any doubt? A. Well, I do not feel to have any doubt—I have no doubt but what he is the man—I saw him on three occasions at the house in Oakley-crescent; the first time for five or six minutes, the second time for about the same, and the third not so long—he had a hat on and he had spectacles on, white ones—once he had not got them on, but he put them on when I went into the room—he was a minute or two without them; he went to the window, took them out, and put them on—I solemnly believe him to be the man—I went with Forrester to the House of Detention for the purpose of identifying him—Mr. Mullens was not with me—Forrester did not give me any clue or hint—the gaolers told me not to stop at the cells, but to look and pass on—there was only one person in each cell—the gaoler did not say when I had passed the last cell but one, "You have passed him"—he did not say so till I had passed them all—I said there was no one I could identify, with the exception of the last man, and he was something like the man—I do not believe the gaoler said, "You have passed him," before I said that—after we had passed them all, I believe he said, "That is all, have you seen him?"—he said "You have passed him," when I came to the end—it was then that I said "The last man was something like him"—I said if Iwas compelled to swear to the man, I would not say it was him, by the time I had seen him—on leaving the prison, I believe I told Forrester I had seen them all, but there was but one there that was like him—I do not recollect saying, "My impression is I have not seen the man"—I will not swear I did not—when I saw him at Marlborough-street he was in the dock—I had then heard of his being committed on another charge—I then said he was the man—I have never mentioned before to-day that the man I saw at Oakley-crescent had spectacles on—I told Mr. Mullens so early in the case—I did not say so at the Mansion-house—I did not repass the cells at the House of Detention, after having once looked into them.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. About what is the size of these cells? A. About as far as from me to the door—they are light—each prisoner got up as the gaoler opened the door and said, "Come to the front"—they faced me—their back was towards the window of the cell—none of them were brought out of the cells—I recognised him directly at Marlborough-street—I had then been told that there was a man brought up charged with forgery—I was told that there were several, and that I should have a chance of seeing them—I was told that I should see a man who had been identified on another charge—before I looked into the cells of the House of Detention I had not been told that there was a man there like the description I had given—I was asked by Mr. Mullens to go and see some prisoners—I do not positively know whether or not he said there was some one like the man.

MARY ADELAIDE FENNELL . I reside with my mother at No. 6, Oakley-crescent, City-road—we let lodgings—about 18th or 19th Feb. a gentle
man

came to engage our apartments—I showed him the two rooms on the drawing room floor, and he engaged them for three weeks, or it might be longer, at 10s. a week—he wanted them from 10 o'clock in the morning till 3 in the afternoon—he was to sleep there, but not that night, as he had no luggage, but he said those would be his business hours, he should be out in the evening—he gave his name as Mr. Hammond—he then left—I think this was between 1 and 2 o'clock in the day—he was there about ten minutes or a quarter of an hour—next day he came again—he then asked me for pen and ink—that was up stairs in the drawing room—I furnished him with, it, and I left him there—I do not know when he went out—I saw him again next day, but do not think I spoke to him—I do not remember how long he remained there—I opened the door for him, and I saw his back, when he went out, from the window—he did not come back to the house after that—he did not sleep at our house at all—I did not see him again until he was at Marlborough-street, about three weeks or a month afterwards—he was then at the police station, not before the Magistrates, but in a room with six or seven others—Mr. Mullens asked me if I could recognise the man, and I said I should not say anything about it then—I afterwards saw him at the Mansion-house at the bar—the prisoner is exactly like the man—to the best of my belief he is the man.

Croas-eaxvmined. Q. Were you the only person that saw him at your house? A. No; my sister saw him, but only for a minute—she is younger than me—she would not swear to him—she was taken to Marlborough-street and the Mansion-house to see him—Mr. Mullens took me to Marlborough-street—I told him that the man I had seen at our lodging appeared to be stouter—Mr. Mullens did not suggest that he had got thin in prison, nothing of the kind—I think I said he had got thinner since he had been in prison—the man at our place had a small piece of sticking plaster on his right cheek—I never saw him in spectacles—I did not open the door to Humphreys—did not see the prisoner at the time of his interview with Humphreys—I only saw him once that morning—he was very differently dressed to what the prisoner is now—I noticed his features—I did not exa
mine him much—I had enough time to see his hair, it appeared to me lighter when he was in prison the other day—I do not think I have ever said that the person at our lodging looked more of a gentleman than the prisoner—he was more respectably dressed.
Mr. SLEIGH. Q. Looking at the prisoner now, do you believe him to be the person who took your lodging? A. He is very like the man.
