COURT. Q. Do you believe him to be the man? A. I do—I saw him without his hat—I did not see Humphreys at all at our house—I heard of his being there, and another man also—there is no other No. 6 in our Cres
cent—when I first saw the man he had a patch on his right cheek, and next morning he had one on his chin—I did not see any scar on his cheek or chin—when he came to take the lodging he was wrapped up close to the throat—the weather was very cold—when I was asked at Marlborough-street if I could recognise him I said "I shall say nothing now"—I said that because I did not wish to go before any court—I had not any doubt about him—I wished to save myself the annoyance of coming into court—I received half a crown deposit from the man—it was when he came next morning that I saw him without his hat—he said he came from Oxford.

GEORGE HENRY BOWELLS . I am not in any employ at present. I have been a servant—I was last in the service of the Rev. Mr. Powell, in Park-street Hyde-park. (MR. BALLANTINE. submitted that in this case the evidence of act

other uttering was not receivable: such evidence could only be admissible for the purpose of shouting that the uttering charged, was wtih a guilty knowledge; the circumstances of the case were clearly sufficient to show that whoever uttered the 91l. cheque, did so with a guilty knowledge, and therefore any further evidence could but operate by way of prejudice, and ought not to be received. The RECORDER. was of opinion that if the prosecution pressed it, he must receive it. MR. SLEIGH. considered it desirable that the jury should hear the evidence.)—On 8th March I put an advertisement in the Times newspaper, and in consequence of a reply to it, I went on 11th March to No 16, Stanhope-street, Regent's-park—I inquired for a person of the name of Bates—the note I received in reply to my advertisement was from a person calling himself Bates; and it said at the bottom that I was to take it back with me—I took it back with me, and I got to the place in Stanhope-street about half-past 11 o'clock on Tuesday, 11th March—the door was opened by a servant girl, and I was shown up to the first floor—I saw the prisoner—he asked me where I had been living, and what doing, and where I lived before I lived in London—I told him at Oxford—he said he knew several persons who lived at Oxford, and mentioned some of their names, and espe
cially one at Sholam Hall, near Oxford—I had not at that time the letter I received—I had given it to the servant, and she carried it into the room without the envelope—the servant gave him the letter, and'he said I was to go and get the envelope which had been left below—I went and got it, and he engaged me for a week—he asked me to go to Camden-town station, and ask if there was any luggage come in the name of Bates—he said he had come from Rugby that morning, and he was to return to Rugby—I went to the Camden-town station, and did not find any luggage—I went back and told him, and he said perhaps it would come in the evening—he then asked if I was busy, if I had anything particular to do that afternoon—I said, "No;" Ald he said he was busy, and asked if I would go to Ransom's, and get a cheque changed for him—that was after I came back from the railway station—it was between 12 and 1 o'clock—this is the cheque he gave me (looking at it)—it is for 87l. 14s.—he said I was to get four 10l. notes, and the rest in money—I went to the bankers and presented the cheque, and got the money according to his direction—I took it back to Stanhope-street, and gave it to the pri
soner—after giving him the money he said he would go the next morning and inquire my character, and let me know the result in the evening—he said he would write to me the next day whichever way it might be—he gave me some money to get some dinner—I forget the amount—I think it was a shilling or two—I left him, and on the next day I received this note, "March 12th, 1856, Mr. Bates, being called out of town unexpectedly, will not require George Bowells to call on him till his return from the country, when Mr. Bates will write"—the next day after receiving this I went to Ran
som's, the bankers', and made a communication to them.
JURY. Q. What induced you to go to the bankers? A. His not calling for my character the next day; that induced me to go, as I thought there was something wrong.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. About a week afterwards did you see the prisoner? A. Yes, I met him in Oxford-street—he had another person with him—it was between 1 and 2 o'clock in the day—it was at the Hyde-park end, somewhere near Orchard-street—I was going down towards the Edgware-road and he was coming to Holborn way—I met him and passed him about ten yards—he looked round and nodded—I nodded again and went

to him—I asked him if his name was not Bates?—he said, "No; it is not; my name is Hawkins"—he then asked me if I was out of employ, and if I had advertised for a situation—to which I said, "Did you not answer my advertisement on Tuesday last?"—he said, "No"—he said, "I am sorry I have no money with me, or else I would give you some" (I had not asked him for any)—he said track was dull, and his friend answered to the same effect—when he said that his name was Hawkins, his companion said his name was Hawkins, and they came somewhere out of the country—he did mention the name of a place, but I do not remember it—before they left me, the prisoner shook hands with me, and they walked away towards Holborn—I followed them—they walked on as for as Duke-street, Manchester-square, and turned down there—before they got to Duke-street, the prisoner kept looking back to see if I was fol
lowing—I saw them go down Duke-street—I made a communication to an officer, 46 D, at the top of Duke-street—he accompanied me down Duke-street, and we went down several squares, but we could see nothing of them—I had seen them both run off while I was speaking to the police
man—I did not see anything more of the prisoner till Saturday, 5th April—about 7 o'clock that evening I was in Oxford-street, near the Edgware-road road—I then saw the prisoner, and his companion who was with him on the occasion when I saw him before—they were at the corner, they were coming towards Oxford-street, and I was going to the Edgware-road—I met them at the corner—I let them pass me, and when they had passed about twenty yards I turned back and followed them again—I followed them nearly 200 yards to the corner of a street—they stood there talking a few minutes, and turned back and went in to, a public house in Oxford-street—I spoke to a policeman named Smith, and as I was speaking to him they came up—the constable went to the prisoner, and said he must consider himself his prisoner on a charge of forgery at Messrs. Ransom's bank—I said, "I shall give you in charge on a case of forgery on Messrs. Ransom's bank"—he said to the officer, "It is all right, where am I to go to?"—his companion walked off towards the Edgware-road—the prisoner did not say anything till he was taken to Marylebone-lane station—he there abused me very much, called me a scoundrel and a vagabond, and made use of all sorts of abusive names—when he was taken he said he did not know where the bank was himself, and he did not know where Stanhope-street was—he was taken by the constable, in my company, to No. 16, Stanhope-street, the same evening by my desire—I had a very slight doubt about his being the person at the time when I took him—when we got to No. 16, Stanhope-street, we first saw the servant who had previously opened the door to me—the policeman asked if Mrs. Hall was at home—I think that was the name; and the prisoner said to the servant, before he allowed the police
man to speak, "Am I the man that took your lodging?"—she said, "If you are not him you are his brother"—I cannot say what observation he made in reply to that, but he called me a d—vagabond, and held up his stick to me—the policeman said he must call in another constable to assist if he did not be quiet—the servant girl then feinted away—in looking at the prisoner now I. have not the least doubt that he is the person who handed me the cheque.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you in service now? A. No, I have not been in service since I answered the advertisement—I have been obliged to borrow money from my friends—I have received none from Mr. Mullens that I am aware of, but I have received money from Mr. Mullens's clerk—that is not

the friend I alluded to—I have had a good deal from friends—Mr. Mullens did not say he would not let me have any—his clerk let me have some—I have not been examined many times by Mr. Mullens, nor by his clerk, by neither of them—I communicated to the bankers that the prisoner said his name was Hawkins—I do not remember it—I do not remember telling any one that the prisoner had told me his name was Hawkins—I might have told the constable—I will not swear that I did—I know he gave the name of Hawkins at Marlborough-street—he gave it at the police station—when I went to communicate the circumstance to the bankers, I can swear I told some one there that he had given the name of Hawkins.

Q. You told me you did not remember it. A. It went out of my mind just at that minute; at least, I quite misunderstood yon—I went to the bankers immediately after meeting him—I swear that I told them he gave the name of Hawkins—I could not say that he had any whiskers at all, if he had, they must be very fair, they were scarcely discernible—I have never said that I was not positive that he was the man, I am positive he is the man—I never said that I was not positive to anybody—I told the inspector I had a very, very slight doubt—I do not remember saying that I was not positive he was the man—I do not remember using such words—I will not swear I did not—I will not swear that I did; I may have said it, and not recollected it—this man's hair is darker than the man's hair was who employed me, but he kept his hat on all the time—his features are the same—if he had lighter hair he must have had a wig—no one suggested to me about a wag—I did not mention to Mr. Mullens that he had a wig—I did not know that there was a necessity for it—I might have said it at the police court—I might have said it to the police constable—I did not say so to Mr. Mullens—I do not remember that I said so to the clerk—he took down what I had to say.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Did the police Magistrate allow you 17s. 6d. for your expenses? A. Yes—I was not paid that at the office, but Mr. Mullens's clerk paid it me—I made a representation to him of my distressed condition, and he gave me 15s. more—during the interview I had with the prisoner on the first occasion, he kept his hat on the whole time, that was what gave me the idea of his wearing a wig—I have no doubt that this is the man I saw in Stanhope-street, and the man I saw afterwards in Oxford-street—I am positive he is the man.

HANNAH BARTON . I am servant at No. 16, Stanhope-street, Regent's-park. In March last some one came to look at the apartments—I let him in, and showed him up stairs—on the following day I let Bowells in—the same man was there then—Bowells afterwards went out—I let him in a second time—he went out again, and I let him in a third time—the man was still there—I did not see Bowells leave again, or the man—I did not see the man again until one Saturday, about a month afterwards, when the policeman brought him to the house in a cab—I opened the door, Bowells was with them—as soon as the man came into the house Bowells asked me if that was the man that came to our house and took the apartments—I said to the prisoner, "If you are not the man, you are his brother"—he said, "I am not"—he became rather violent, and I fainted away.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe you have said that you did not believe he was the man? A. Yes—I cannot say it is the man—Miss Parker is here, she saw him.
MARY ANN PARKER . I reside at No. 16, Stanhope-street, Regent's-park. About 8th March a person came to hire my apartments—if the prisoner is
the person he is very much changed, he is a very different looking person—I cannot say that he is the same person.

RICHARD HOARE . (policeman, D 46) I was on duty in Oxford-street on 13th or 15th March, when Bowells came and spoke to me—from what he said I went down Duke-street and James-street in search of some persons—I could not find them, or see any persons running—I am not confident of the day—it was in Wigmore-street that Bowells spoke to me, close to Duke-street.

ANDREW STEPHENS . I am cashier to Messrs. Bramah and Co.—they keep an account at Messrs. Hansom's—a gentleman in the establishment, named Gilbertson, generally signs the cheques—this signature is not his, or that of any person belonging to the firm—it is a very good imitation.
COURT. Q. Are you aware of ever having lost any cheques or forms? A. No—I know nothing of the prisoner.

GUILTY. of uttering. Aged 24.—
Four Years Penal Servitude

545.
WILLIAM ATTWELL
, feloniously forging and uttering an order for the payment of 71l. 10s., with intent to defraud.
MESSES. SLEIGH . and POLAND. conducted the Prosecution.

GEORGE RICHARD THORN . I am cashier at Messrs. Ransom's bank in Pall Mall—on 12th March I cashed this cheque for 71l. 10s., purporting to he drawn by Messrs. Bramah and Co.—among the notes I paid for it was one 10l. note, No. 54,167, dated 9th January—I do not know by whom the cheque was presented.
ANDREW STEPHENS . I am in the employ of Messrs. Bramah and Co., the locksmiths—this cheque is not signed by them or by any person in their employment—nor is this other cheque for 87l. 14s.

WILLIAM GOLDING . I am potman at the Prince of Wales tavern, Har-mood-street, Kentish-town—I know the prisoner—he has been a customer at our house—about the beginning of March he came for change for a 10l. note—he gave it to Mrs. Suter, the landlady, she gave it to me—I crossed the road and got it changed at Mr. Hersant's, the butcher—he gave me ten sovereigns, which I took to Mrs. Suter, and she gave them to the prisoner—I knew him by the name of Hawkes, that is the name his brother goes by—I did not know him by name, until after this case.

Cross-examined by MR. MACENTEER, Q. Was he in the habit of coming to your house? A. Yes; for his brother, for beer and other things twenty or thirty times—he asked for the change perfectly openly—it was at the bar, between 11 and 12 o'clock; in the morning.

MILTON HERSANT . I am a butcher at No. 47, Harmood-street, opposite the Prince of Wales—Golding brought me a 10l. note for change—it was before the 17th March, for I paid it away on the 17th, it might have been a week before but I think not quite so long—I gave him change for it—this is the note (produced)—I put my mark on it—I paid it away to Messrs. Hill, at the New Cattle Market.

THOMAS COBDEN FARTHING . I am cashier at Messrs. Ransom and Ca's—I cashed this cheque for 87l. 14s., purporting to be signed by Bramah and Co., on 11th March—I paid for it four 10l. Bank of England notes, Nos. 45,967 to 45,970, dated 5th November, 1855, and 47l. 10s. in gold and silver.
JOHN SHELTON . I am barman to Mr. Chamberlain, who keeps the Sportsman public house, City-road—I have known the prisoner as a customer frequenting the house—on 12th March he came there with

another man and asked Mr. Chamberlain to change him a note—he went up stairs and got the gold and gave it to me to give the prisoner—I gave it him, and asked him his name—he said, William Smith—I asked him to write it on the note—he was not very sober—the man who was with him wrote Thomas Thompson, but I wrote on it myself the name he gave me, William Smith, and my master's initials—this (produced) is the note—it is No. 45,967—I noticed the number at the time.
Cross-examined. Q. What address did the prisoner give? A. No. 8, Cottage-lane, City-road—that is his correct address—I have known him about nine months.

EDWARD THOMAS GODDARD . I am shopman to Mr. Castle, a pawnbroker, in High-street, Camden-town—on 12th March last I changed this note, No. 45,970, for the prisoner (produced)—he gave the name of William Smith, No. 81, John-street-road, which I wrote on the note—he had pledged a Geneva watch and chain in the morning and redeemed it in the afternoon with this note.
Cross-examined. Q. Did 700 know him before? A. No—I saw him again about a month afterwards—I see about 200 or 250 persons a-day—I saw him twice in that one day.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Is it a common occurrence for persons to pledge their watches in the morning and take them out in the afternoon? A. Fre
quently—I am sure the prisoner is the person who changed the note. (The RECORDER. was of opinion that the evidence was too slight to go to the Jury.)
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: NEW COURT.—Saturday, May 31st, 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. EAGLETON. and Mr. COMMON SERJEANT.

p.hi: Before Mr. Common Serjeant and the Eighth Jury.

div1.p:
546.
FERDINAND LENDEN
, unlawfully obtaining, by false pre
tences, 10l.; with intent to defraud
Henry Pearson Maples and others.
MR. ROBINSON. conducted the Prosecution.

NOEL ANTONIE GAUTIER . (through an interpreter). I am employed at the Western Railway at Paris—it is my duty to place tickets on the luggage that is registered to London. On 19th Jan. it was my duty to paste tickets on the luggage, and I did so—there was only me and the weigher to do so—I do not recollect pasting a ticket corresponding with this one (pro
duced)—I might possibly have pasted it, but I am not sure—if this bag (produced) had been brought, and registered for London, it would have been my duty to have pasted a ticket on it—the remains of the ticket on this bag correspond with the ticket I should have put on—I put a mark of a red cross on registered luggage—I put the mark where it would show most, on the front—here is the mark of the red cross on this bag—this is the way in which I should make the cross—I cannot swear to this—this is the way bill of that day, No. 13—I should enter the luggage that day—if I were absent it would have been the weigher's duty to enter it—I do not know whether I was absent.
Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Do you put tickets of this kind upon all the luggage which comes by that railway from Paris to England?

A. Tickets of the same colour, but not the same number—I do not put the game number on all the luggage on a particular day—at that time, if it went up as high as 10, it was a great number—the numbers go from 1 to 80; when we finish No. 80, we commence No. 1 again—the same number would be on a bag if a person had travelled before from Paris to London, if the same number came in rotation.

FRANCOIS XAVIER DEPRAT . I am in the service of the Western Railway of France. This is the way bill of the train No. 13—there was only one registered article of luggage by that train on 19th Jan.—this is the way bin that refers to that register—there was only one piece of luggage, No. 28—according to this way bill, it ought to have been No. 28—on this bug here is a "2" and an "8"—I delivered this ticket to the person who had the luggage registered—here is a red mark chalked on this bag; that is the mark usually pat on registered luggage—at that time of year we were five or six days exhausting the numbers from 1 to 80.

Cross-examined. Q. How many trains in a day run from Dieppe and on to England? A. One a day—we use tickets of the same colour for every train leaving Paris for England, but not the same number—we use numbers from 1 to 80—I cannot tell from this way bill whether this luggage was a carpet bag—I have no recollection of putting on this number—it is so long ago, I cannot tell whether I gave it to a man or a woman—I do not think the second figure on this bag is part of ft 6 or part of a 3—it must be an 8—we know nothing about the Dover tickets—we used the same ticket for luggage which was to be conveyed to Newhaven—there are no other tickets for places ending in "es" of this colour—this was "Londres."
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Is it your habit to express the name of luggage? A. We never give it any particular name.

CHARLES POTTER . I am landing waiter and searcher at the Custom House, at Newhaven. I produce a book of the entry of two packages—this entry satisfies me that I examined two packages in the name of Lenden, on Sun
day morning, 20th Jan.—the packages were opened by some one for me, and I examined them—I have the name of Lenden, because the person who claims the packages gives his name—as soon as the luggage is examined, I have nothing more to do with it—I make no distinction of registered or unregistered luggage—after I have done with it, it is delivered to the person from me—he may take it from the counter if he pleases—after that, persons may take registered luggage in the railway themselves.

Cross-examined. Q. You have no recollection whatever of the person or of the bag? A. No—I know nothing about the number of packages, except from this book—there were thirty-five packages delivered that day—a mark is placed on bags that have been examined—a ticket of this description, bearing the name of the boat, is placed on the bag, or whatever the luggage is, when it is brought up, and then the examining officer, which in this case was myself, stamps that ticket with a red mark, and after that it is counter stamped black—that ticket is fastened on with paste.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. What part is it put on? A. On a bag it is put at the bottom—it is put on to remain till it gets to the door, and very fre
quently they drop off.
COURT. Q. Could a passenger obtain his luggage if registered before it comes to the Custom House? A. He could not.

JOHN LIPSCOMBE . I am clerk to Mr. Henry Pearson Maples. He has partners—he has an interest in the boat that runs to Dieppe—on 25th March, I received from the traffic manager of the Brighton Railway some

letters; amongst the rest was this, which is Lenden's letter, dated Chester 6th Feb., stating the loss of his bag—this ticket was enclosed in it—I received other letters beside—this is a letter written by Mr. Slight, secre
tary to the Brighton Railway, dated 15th, 2nd, 1856—it was found at the prisoner's lodging, and on it is a copy of this letter—(This was dated "Chester, Feb. 23, 1856: To London, Brighton, and South Cocast Railway," describing the carpet bag and contents; signed "Lenden")—every inquiry was made, and letters passed between us—I eventually received a list of the things, and the prices annexed—the sum he demanded of me was 19l. 11s.; he demanded that in one of his letters—I afterwards saw the prisoner, and he demanded it personally—I had a conversation with him—I cannot recollect the first day I saw him—it was about the middle of March he came to me, and told me what his name was, and what his business was—he said, "My name is Lenden; I have received letters from you which I have replied to; I come to speak about them"—I unfolded the letters and the ticket, and he said, "That ticket was the ticket I enclosed, and those were the letters I sent"—these are the letters I showed him in my office, and he said, "These are my letters"—one is 6th Feb., another 23rd Feb., 3rd March, 6th March, 12th March, and 16th March—this one contains a list of the articles, and the amount—it is signed, "Lenden," and directed to Henry Pearson Maples, Esq.—(read: "Sir, with reference to your letter of the 15th, I beg to send you the list of the contents of my carpet bag, with the value thereof. I have fixed the price by the use I made of them. You will oblige me if you will settle the matter in course of the week. I intend to set out on a journey, and will be obliged to buy many articles that I have lost")—The amount stated was 19l. 11s.—when I saw the prisoner, he said he had not seen his bag after he registered it in Paris, and paid a shilling, and a gentleman, who came from Dieppe with him told him at Newhaven, that his bag was outside the Custom House there, and he had better take it; and he replied, that having regis
tered his bag for London, he had no control over it, nor could he touch it until he reached London; that he reached London, and had to go imme
diately to Chester—I told him that every inquiry had been made, and we should still prosecute our inquiries respecting the bag—he came afterwards and gave me a list of the articles he had been obliged to purchase, and he asked me if I would pay him 10l. on account of the 19l. he had lost, and he would let the matter rest till the middle or end of May for the balance—I told him I could make no arrangement of that kind whatever—having made inquiries, I saw him again, and offered him 10l. as a compromise, and he agreed to take it—I paid it him, and this is the receipt lie gave me,; it was written and signed by him in my presence—("Received of Mr. Maples, 10l., in full discharge for the loss of my carpet bag, &c.")—I heard nothing more of the bag—I am in the habit of seeing these tickets very frequently—I have examined this one on the bag, and in my judgment the number is 28 without hesitation—I was present at the prisoner's lodging when Carpenter took him into custody—I was there the whole time till he was taken away—I saw this letter found which, has been produced—I saw this bag there—I heard Carpenter tell him he was seeking for a bag that was lost, and he must look into his room—he passed into the room with the prisoner, took up the bag, and said, "This is the bag"—the prisoner said he never had that bag with him in Paris—Carpenter asked him why ho did not apply for his bag when he first reached London; he answered because he had to take a cab immediately, and go off to Chester—I saw this Diary found in his room, I believe it to be his writing—I have seen his
signature to these letters, and I saw him write in my office, a long paragraph.

Cross-examined. Q. You have spoken to one or two conversations; have you ever said anything about these conversations to any person not being at the police court, about his going to Chester, for one thing? A. Yes, I am quite sore I have—I have stated that he received the 10l. by way of com
promise—I did not tell him he would obtain 10l. from the French Govern
ment; decidedly not—I pledge myself that nothing of that kind occurred—nothing was said about his obtaining a large amount from another quarter; from the Packet Company—I represented the whole of the Companies on that occasion, and told the prisoner so—I will swear that—I did not pay the 10l. in consequence of something that had been said to me by Carpenter—I paid the 10l. before Carpenter knew that I had paid it—prior to the prisoner earing he never had the bag with him in Paris, Carpenter had said he was seeking a carpet bag which was lost, and this was the bag—the con
versation had previously been directed to the carpet bag that was lost, and for which'he claimed recompense.
COURT. Q. Had you any conversation with him at his lodging about the particular bag for which he had received compensation? A. No.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Carpenter was not employed in this till after you paid the 10l.? A. No—I had not been in the prisoner's room two days before—I had been in the house, not in the room—I had seen the bag once, but never touched it.

JOHN CARPENTER . (police inspector, Brighton Railway). I was first spoken to about this matter on 15th March—I did not go into it till 15th or 16th March—I received some information, which induced me to go, on 17th April, to a beer shop in King William-street, where this bag was ultimately discovered—while I was there, a person came for Dr. Lenden's luggage—it was refused—the application was made the next morning, and the same application was made the next evening at 5 o'clock, and refused—I was in the house when the person came and made the application—he left, and went out when he got his answer, and I went out too—I went twenty or thirty yards, and saw the prisoner's head peeping round the wall of the steps leading down to Thames-street—the person who had applied for the bag went to him, and insisted on his going to give an order to the persons to have his luggage delivered—the prisoner stood for a minute, and the person said, "Come along," and he followed him into the beer shop, and told the landlord to let the gentleman have his goods—he was then going out, but I stopped him, and told him I wanted to speak to him up stairs in his room—I told him I was a police officer—he said, "Very well"—he went up into his room—I followed him, and told him I came respecting his having obtained 10l. from the Brighton Railway Company, under pretence of his having lost this bag (pointing to it)—I told him he need make no reply unless he chose, as I should most likely have to repeat it—he immediately said, "Oh, that is the way the railway people pay persons for the lose of their property"—I took the bag, turned it up, and showed him the bottom—I said, "This is the French ticket from Paris"—I pointed out to him the portions of the figures, which I told him were the remains of No. 28—he said, "That bag never was in Paris with me"—I also found this other little bag, with this strap t it—I said that he had passed through the Custom House at Newhaven, and there were entries there of his having passed through the Custom House with two bags—a gentleman who was there told him to say nothing—I

said, "You went away when you arrived at London-bridge; you never made any application for it; why did you not do so?"—he said, "I got into a cab, and was obliged to go away to Chester immediately"—I took him to the police station—he gave his name, but refused to give any address—he was then asked his address in Paris, and that he also refused—he afterwards said that he lived in some rue, which he named, in Paris—I took these letters, and this diary, and carpet bag, and this wearing apparel.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know the letters that you found? A. I brought them to this Court—I found all these at the prisoner's lodging—I believe these straps were on this small bag at the time I found it, or they were lying by the side of it—I had been to that place one day before, but I had never been in the prisoner's room before that day—I never saw the carpet bag elsewhere before that day—I saw it that day before the prisoner was there—I had it in my hand, and examined it—Mr. Lipscombe was present, and also the landlord of the house—I did not know when I went that there was something due to the landlord—I knew it before I took the bag away—I knew it before I saw this man peeping round the corner—I heard some person, who said he was a solicitor, say he would pay it—the money was not paid by my advice, certainly not—when I had this bag first in my hand, I saw it about ten minutes—I examined it with the description I had given me, and found it corresponded with it—the room was locked of again.

—MACKIE. I was a fellow traveller with the prisoner from Paris to London—I was with him on board the steamboat—I believe I was the person principally associating with him—when we arrived at Newhaven I saw him—I believe we landed together—I believe we passed through the baggage warehouse together—I do not believe he said anything about his luggage—we went into the luggage place together—my impression is that he was the first person from me—I believe he had something slung round him—I think I saw a belt; I am not quite sure—I do not exactly recollect what luggage he had; it was luggage of some kind—it is my impression that he was showing something as part of his luggage—I left my luggage in the baggage warehouse—when we quitted the examination of the luggage, I believe the next place I saw the prisoner at was at the Lewes station; he left me there to go to Brighton—I was in a first class carriage; he was on the platform—he wished me good bye, and asked if madam was better—I do not know that he was going to Brighton—I did not see him do anything with a key at the baggage place—he exposed his luggage—I do not know whether it was fastened with a lock, or what it was.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you first join the prisoner? A. On board the steamer—I came from Paris—I did not see the prisoner till I arrived at Dieppe—all the packages constituting my luggage were registered—I never travelled that road before—I did not see the prisoner's luggage on board the steamer—I am not able to say what number of packages he had—other persons besides me were in conversation with the prisoner—he was no acquaintance of mine prior to that voyage—I never saw him before—just after leaving the harbour my lady became ill, and he very kindly produced some spirit, and put it on her forehead, or gave her some—I do not know whether it was brandy, I did not taste it.

MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did you remain at Dieppe? A. I remained about ten minutes—I went into a coffee shop—I paid some sous for having my luggage registered in Paris for London direct—I did not suppose I should
see it again, but I saw it at Newhaven—my luggage was one large trunk and I think a little bonnet box—I know I paid something at the time my luggage was weighed.

JURY. Q. Had the prisoner a carpet bag with him when he left you at Lewes? A. My impression is that he had something in his hand, but whether it was a carpet bag I cannot say—he did not come close to the carriage that I was in.

GEORGE EDWARD THOMPSON . I am ten years old; I live with my father in Craven-street, Strand. I recollect the prisoner coming to our house in Jan.—it was on the day before we were to go to school—I do not remember the day—it was about the middle of Jan.—I have seen this paper before (looking at it), it was sent to my papa after I went to school—I came home from school before Christmas—we were to have six weeks' holidays—we were to go to school on a Wednesday—the day we were to go to school the prisoner came—he asked if I was going to school, and if not he asked if he should come and teach me private lessons in the house—he said if my mamma would give him a room he would teach me and my two sisters—that was agreed to by my mamma—he went down to Hoddesden on Tuesday—he said he was going to get his things, and he would come back on Wednes
day—I had known him before—he was the French master at Hoddesden—he came on the Wednesday—I saw this bag on the Thursday, the day he began to teach us—I was in the room every day, he used to keep this bag on the sofa in the room—it was a bag exactly like this—I have handled it, I used to take the things out of this bag, and put them on the table for him—he taught me in his room—I saw the bag a good while; while he was there.

Cross-examined. Q. Are you able to say positively whether this is the bag? A. It is exactly like it—he had a portmanteau with him—I did not see that he had a small bag with swaps—he brought his things in a cab—he came about 9 o'clock.

COURT. Q. How long did he continue to teach you after the Wednes
day day? A. About a fortnight.

GEORGE BENCHARD . I have examined the entries in this diary with this translated copy—I find them perfectly correct—(some of these entries were ready as follows: "1856, Saturday, Jan. 19th, departed from Paris. Mon
day, 21st, arrived in London. Wednesday, 23rd, went to Thompson. Wednesday, 30th, went to Chester.")
MR. LILLEY. called

AUGUST MABEE . (through an interpreter). I am a German. The prisoner is not a German—I have known him since 1849, or 1850—I was in Paris on 18th, 19th, or 20th Jan. last—I saw the prisoner, and spoke to him—it was through me that he came to London—I had no particular business with him—I recollect the time at which he left Paris—I accompanied him to the railway station at Paris—I had heard him say the evening before that he wanted to buy himself a travelling pocket for his journey; by a travel
ling pocket I mean a carpet bag—I offered to lend him my travelling pocket—I lent it him—I call this (looking at the carpet bay) a travelling pocket—this is not the one I lent him, it was a similar one to this—I took it to the railway station—I saw the prisoner had several of his packages in his dress
ing gown doubled up, clasped together—I helped him to put them into the bag—the bag was not quite fall; not over full—after the things were put into the carpet bag, he locked it, and the prisoner himself gave it to the employé who received it at the railway—the prisoner had my bag, and another beside it, and a courier's bag round his neck—he registered only one bag, the bag

I had lent him—that is not the bag that I lent the prisoner—this is not mine—my bag was as large as this, or nearly so—it was in squares of a lighter colour—it had three pockets, and two divisions inside.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. What are you? A. A distiller and farmer—I have distilled in France, Belgium, and Germany—I am not established in any business—I get money sent from home, at Stettin—it is one year and eight months since I was in Stettin—I have received money from home during that time—I received a letter from the son of the prisoner, and through that I knew he was in Paris—I was in Valenciennes when I received the letter through the prisoner—I wanted to come to London, in hopes of getting something to do in the distillery—I was living in Paris, in Rue d'Amsterdam, near the railway—I do not know the number, it was 20 or 30—I lived alone—I was a lodger—I do not know the name of the persons I lodged with—I lodged with them two days—the prisoner was lodging in the Rue de la Paix—I remained two days after 19th Jan.—I then went to Valenciennes—I do not know exactly when I arrived in London; either in March or April—the prisoner fetched me from the station when I arrived, and took me to the public house where the things were found—I could pay my lodging at the public house.

Q. Will you swear that the landlord did not detain what little you had for payment of the lodging in King William-street, and that he did not say that he would turn you out of the house unless you paid, and then the prisoner became security for you? A. Yes, the arrears that there was—the evening before the prisoner was taken, the landlord threatened to keep my things, to pay, the arrears—I was not the person who went twice to the house in King William-street to ask for the prisoner's things.

Q. Will you swear that you did not go to that house on 17th April, and demand Lenden's things, and were they not refused you? A. I do not know the dates—on the day before the apprehension of the prisoner, I took a letter to the house and demanded London's things—I did not go again on the morniog of the 18th—the carpet bag I lent to the prisoner was the only one I had—I had a courier's pocket besides—I was before the Magistrate when the prisoner was examined—I have been to Newgate every day to see him—I am now living over Westminster-bridge—I do not know the name of the street—I do not know the name of the person I am living with.

MR. LILLEY.: Q. Was the place at which you lodged at Paris an hotel? A. A furnished lodging—I lodge opposite Astley's Theatre, at the first coffee house on the left hand over Westminster-bridge—I was not examined before the Magistrate when I was at the police court—I have my passport and certificate at my lodging—what I have said about the carpet bag is true—I have not said anything in order to favour the prisoner.

COURT. Q. When before the Magistrate, was any attorney appearing for the prisoner? A. Not that I know of—I do not know that any one pot any questions to the witnesses for him—when the prisoner was at the rail
way he had one carpet bag registered—he took the other with him into the railway carriage, and also a pocket that he had on his shoulder—I hardly know what he had in the carpet bag that he took into the railway carriage, but he had some dirty linen, which he took out of my bag and put in his.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. Did not this gentleman (Mr. Bickley) appear before the Magistrate? A. Yes.

GEORGE BICKLEY . I am an attorney, and live in Devereux-court—I acted as attorney for the prisoner before the Magistrate on the third occasion—I saw the last witness outside, but I could not understand from him what
He could prove—I heard the Magistrftte say he should send the prisoner for trial, and, not knowing what the witness could prove; I did not think it prudent to call him.

GUILTY . Aged 52.—
Confined Twelve Months.

div0.p: THIRD COURT.—Saturday, May 31st, 1856.
PRESENT—Mr. Ald. CUBIT.; Mr. Ald. EAGLETON.; and MICHAEL. PBENDERGAST, Esq.

p.hi: Before Michael Prendergast, Esq., and the Seventh Jury.

div1.p:
547.
HENRY CHARNELL,
WILLIAM MARTIN,
JOHN SALE,
CHARLES PESHELL , and
JOHN TILLETT
, stealing, in the dwelling house of
Richard Trott Fisher, the master or Charnell, 1 silver tea kettle, and a variety of articles of plate, value 500l.; his property.
MR. GIFFARD. conducted We Prosecution.

RICHARD TROTT FISHER . I live at No. 30, Eaton-place, in the parish of St. George's, Hanover-square. Charnell was my butler—on the night of the 4th April I went to bed about half past 12 o'clock—I went by accident into my study, got hold of a book, and sat there for half or three quarters of an hour—the house was perfectly quiet when I went to bed—I supposed that every body was in bed—my dressing room is in a situation that I can hear the least talking or noise (I do not make a practice of going to bed after the servants, I generally go at about 11 o'clock)—about 7 clock in the morning in consequence of something a female servant said to me, I went down and saw Charnell—I should have been up soon after 8 o'clock, in the ordinary course—Charnell met me on the stairs, and began in rather an extravagant way to ask that I would forgive him—there were two maid servants stand
ing there, and I told him to go into the drawing room and say what he had to say—he said, "I hope you will forgive me, I am sure you never will forgive me"—I said, "Just go into the room, and I will oome and speak to you"—I went in and shut the door, and he said that he had been called out at night soon after he got into bed, a relation came or had sent for him, that a cousin of his was dangerously ill, that he got up, went away at 12 o'clock, was absent two hours, and when he came back he found that the plate was taken—I said, "Why, I was up myself at 12"—he said that it might been twenty minutes or half past 12, that the husband of his cousin had come and called him up—I went and dressed, saw him afterwards, and asked if he had gone for the police—he said that he had not—he told me after
wards that his bed was put down, he sleeps in the pantry, and he told me that his watch was lying on the bed—the plate was kept in a very strong plate closet, built on purpose, fire proof, and opening out Of his pantry, and there are two strong chests to keep what is not used in, and which I believe are in Court (produced)—there is a fire proof door which opens out of this butler's pantry, where he sleeps, and the two chests are in the closet; in which to send the plate backwards and forwards—they are fitted up for each parti
cular article—the keys of the chests, as well as of the closet, were in the possession of the butler—I gave him the keys and the entire control of all the plate—I have no reason to believe that there were marks on the cheats before—the last time I saw them was when I sent them up from the country

to the silversmith's, and they came from him to the prisoner, Charnell, in December—it was his duty to sleep in the room where the plate closet was—I dressed on the ground floor, and came out immediately, went to the police station, brought a policeman, and examined the place down stairs with him, and examined the locks—I think Charnell was present—he told me that he had locked the door of his pantry when he went out, and took the key with him—he spoke to me so often that I cannot exactly recollect the time—he said that he had locked up the key of the plate closet, a large key, and deposited it in a side press, a wooden fixture in the room, with a very weak lock, which had been shoved open, and the key taken out, and he found it in the plate closet—he also said that he had locked up the plate chests, and had taken those keys with him, that he found the door of the pantry broken open when he came home—I asked him if there was any appearance of anybody having been in the house—he said that there was not, and that he went out by the area door, and took the key of that door and the key of the area in his pocket—I said, "Then who can have taken the plate?"—he said, "That is what puzzles me, Sir"—I said, "Of course it was taken either by you or some of your friends"—that was before I knew that he had had any friends—he said, "None of my friends would do it"—afterwards, in my room, before the policeman, he told me the address of his cousin who had sent for him, and I told the policeman to take it down—I then said, "A cousin may be a near or a distant relation, and it is very strange to send for you"—I cross-examined him about the nature of the cousin's illness—he said, "She is the only relation I have," either "in the world," or "in Lon
don," I do not know which—I said, "How is she related?"—after a good deal of hesitation, he said, "She is the daughter of my mother by a former marriage"—I said, "Why, that is your sister"—he said no more, that seemed to embarrass him—he seemed surprised to hear that she proved to be his sister and not his cousin—Thurstell afterwards went away, and about two or three hours after he went away I was reading the paper in my study (it was about 11 o'clock), and Charnell came in and said, "Sir, I will not conceal the truth any longer; what I have told you is false; I went out last night with some friends"—I took down this note of what he said at the time (produced)—he told me that he went out with some friends, and mentioned the names of Peshell and Martin, who lived at No. 7, Princes-street: that Martin had called in the morning about 11 o'clock, and told him that there was a ball that night at Willis's rooms, that he did not like to ask me to go out, but after a good deal of persuasion he consented to go after I had gone to bed; that Martin told him he would let Tillett know, and that he wrote to Tillett himself to meet them at the ball, and Martin put the letter into the post (I think he must have mentioned that Peshell was to go to the ball, as I have his name on the top of my paper)—he said that Tillett came unexpectedly to him about 10 o'clock, and Martin also; that they waited in the pantry together till I had gone to bed—he then locked up all his things, took the keys in his pocket, went out with Martin and Tillett, and met Peshell in the street, just outside; that they three took a cab at the end of the street and went to Willis's-rooms, but they were not open; they then went to Evans's, and heard a song or two, waited till it was getting late, then came home, and arrived about half-past 4 o'clock—I do not think he told me where he parted with the others, but he said that they all four were together at Evans's-rooms—he made no mention of the prisoner Sale to me—he said that they went out by the area door, and locked both the house door and the area door—I asked him how the hall door was found—he said that it was
unbolted but the latch lode and the other lock were both sprung, as they would be if anybody had gone out—that was the state of things when he came back—he had not a latch key, I have one.

Cross-examined by MR. MAC ENTEER. Q. You say that when he first came in he appeared in a state of great excitement? A. Yes; I never saw him so excited before; but I was never robbed before—he came into my service on let Dec. last—I had a character with him from Mr. Fuller, a clergyman in my parish, who had only had him a month—he gave me the character which he had with him—I have communicated with several of his former masters since—I cannot exactly say that the inquiries were satisfac
tory, but I do not wish to say otherwise—he lived for a year and a half at Mr. Kemp's, who seemed quite satisfied—one of the prosecutors afterwards found a dozen and a half of old silver spoons, a pint tankard, and a tray which had been taken out and left—with that exception all the plate was gone—I cannot form an estimate of the weight of it—a great deal of it had been presented to me—it was worth, I believe, 500l. or 600l.—there is an entrance by the area to my house; it has a lock, and with that gate and one door, you can gain admission to the house—he told me that he had not spoken to a policeman when he found it out—I said, "How did you know when you came home that the people were not in the house?"—he said, "I looked into the dining room"—I said, "Did you look into the drawing room?"—he said, "No"

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Have you made inquiry about the character of Peshell? A. Yes; his master called on me—he been a high character; and I hope his master will be here to-day; here is a letter from him giving him an excellent character (produced)—I asked Chamell why he did not call me when he found out the state of the home—he said that he did not like to disturb me.
Cross-examined by Mr. COOPER. Q. Have you made inquiry about Tillet's character? A. I believe his master has a good opinion of him; I know nothing about it, except that he is a respectable man.

THOMAS THURSTELL . (police inspector V). On Saturday, 5th April, about half-past 7 o'clock, I was fetched to Mr. Fisher's—I examined the premises, but found no trace of any entry being effected at any part of the house—I examined the area gate, the door leading from the area into the house, and the front door, but there was not a single mark on either of them—I had the lock of the door leading from the area into the passage, taken off by a smith, but could discover nothing to show that it had been tried—in the butler's pantry I found a small plate chest which bore marks of having been forced—I have examined the larger chest carefully, but there are only very slight marks on it—I am of opinion that those marks were not made then, but that the chest was actually open—there are two locks on it, and both were in perfect order—these (produced) are the keys; they were given to me by Charnell among other keys on a ring—the door of the plate closet was perfectly sound—it is a large iron door, about the size of one of the doors of this Court—it could not have been broken open without a sledge hammer—the proper key was in the door, and it locked it.

COURT. to R. T. FISHER. Q. Where was the plate in ordinary use kept? A. In the butler's pantry. He took it down, and put it away—I believe there is a witness who will speak to his putting it away that night—that was all gone, and a great deal which was not in common use also—the chests are fitted up with green baize shelves on purpose to receive plate—I expect that all the articles I am not in the habit of using were looked up in the large
chest—that is what ought to have been done—nobody but himself would go into his room—his habit was always to lock his pantry door when he went out.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Did you find some plate in a slide under the larger chest? A. Yes; the old spoons—the goblet appeared to hate been left by mistake—Charnell told me that he had left his own watch and chain on his bed, and that they were taken at the same time; that he took them off when he went out, and left them on the bed—he sleeps in the pantry.

THOMAS THURSTELL . (continued). There were several marks on the pantry door, out not sufficient, in my opinion, to make an entry—the box of the lock had not been broken, and when I locked the door, I could not push it open—the box of the lock would make considerable noise in breaking it—few days after the robbery, I am not sure of the date, I called at No. 7, Princes-road, Pimlico, and saw Peshell, Martin, and Sale—I do not think I was in uniform, but they knew I was an officer—constable Fells, who had been there before introduced me as his inspector—Martin said that a friend of Peshell's, a person named Fisher, but whose real name turns out to be Holt, called on him on the Friday, and stated that there was to be a ball at William's-rooms, Brewer-street, Golden-square, that he, Martin, went to 30, Baton-place, and asked Charnell if he would go, and returned in the evening, saying to Peshell that Charnell would go, and had written to invite a friend to accompany him—that friend was not Sale, it was Tillett, a servant at Westbourne-terrace, Hyde-park—he said that later in the evening Sale called on them, and they asked him to accompany them to the ball, and they all went together to 30, Baton-place, at half past 10 o'clock, that Martin went into the house, and Sale and Peshell remained outside, but Gharnell came to the area gate and called then in; that they were very reluctant to go in, thinking it improper, but were overruled by Charnell who pressed them—they stated that before they got to the house they found that Tillett was there; that they waited a considerable time, that Charnell left the pantry frequently to see if Mr. Fisher had retired to bed; that they became very impatient, add at length Charnell said that it was all right, that Mr. Fisher had gone to bed, and they then left the house together by the area door and steps—Sale and Peshell added, that on leaving the house, they fancied that they heard a rustling of a dress, apparently on the stairs leading to the upper part or the house, and told Charnell that they thought it was not all right, and wished him not to leave home, but he replied, that there was nothing to fear, and he had frequently gone out without Mr. Fisher knowing anything about it; that they got into a cab at the comer of Eaton-place and Belgrave-street, and were driven to Brewer-street, Sale stating that he left them there, he having previously stated to the others that he could not go to the ball, as he was not properly dressed, and that his ball days were over, and he had no desire to go, but was driven there, it being part of his way home; that when they found the room closed they went to the other Willis's-rooms at St. James's, thinking that the ball might be there, found those rooms closed also, and then called at several public houses and coffee shops about the Haymarket—(Charnell mentioned Evans's, but I do not know whether the others did or not, that is in Covent-garden)—that Peshell left them in the Haymarket, they had some little dispute about taking some more refresh
ment, and Martin, Charnell, and Tillett walked together to we end of St. Jaraes's-street, where Tillett left, and Martin and Charnell came on their way home to the corner of Arabella-row, Pimlico) Martin going home, and

Charnell to his master's house, Peshell stated that he had only been in bed a very few minutes when Martin arrived, and shortly after that Charnell came to the house and stated that his master's house had been broken open during their absence and the plate stolen—he was let into the house by Peshell, who slept in the front parlour, and Martin in the back room, and as soon as they were both acquainted with it, Martin stated that Charnell wished him to write a note for him to Mr. or Mr. Gilbert, forming an excuse for his absence on that night.

COURT. Q. From the course of the conversation, did you ascertain from him that Charnell made his proposal to Martin to write at the time he gave information of the robbery? A. Yes; and Martin refused, saying that he would have nothing to do with writing, but thai he might write it himself if he chose, there were writing materials there; that Charnell wrote a note, wished Martin to carry it for him, but he objected, telling him that he was tired, and that he had better put it in his pocket, and the delay would not be much longer—I think that was about the whole of the conversation.

Cross-examined by MR. MAC ENTEE. Q. You say that some plate was found in the large chest? A. Yes; that was covered by a slide there were marks of violence on the lid of the small chest, if it had been broken open certainly—there were marks on the pantry, door—the closet door had not been tampered with, at all—the proper key was in it when I arrived—I know nothing about it being taken out of the press—the area keys were ordinary ones.

Cross-examined by MR. PAREY. Q. When you saw these parties, did they give the elaborate account you have described in an unembrrassed manner? A. I thought so—the Monday after the robbery was, I believe, the first time I saw Sale—Fells saw them before me—I did not go by appointment, they did not expect me—Sale did not live there—the inter
view lasted half or three quarters of an hour—I saw them three or four times, still pursuing my inquiries to detect the perpetrators or the robbery—I took Sale on the evening of the 24th by the direction of Mr. Fisher, he insisted on it—I did not suggest to him that any of them should be taken, I merely stated the facts—it is my duty to take persons in custody, against whom there is a case—it is my duty to take a party who I consider criminal—I took Sale a fortnight afterwards, on the 24th, at his own lodging—I knew the address of all of them, and they knew that I was pursuing these inquiries—Sale is a butler out of place—Martin is a butler—Peshell is a foreigner; he told me that he expected a situation at the Lord Warden hotel at Dover, and gave me that address—I saw him again, and he told me that he had got it—I took Sale on the morning of the 25th April, about half past 12 o'clock—I also took Martin on the 25th at his lodging, about midnight—I waited for him to come home—Peshell was apprehended at the Lord Warden hotel—all that was done; by Mr. Fisher's instructions, he was determined that they should be taken in custody—I told Sale that I was sorry I was obliged to apprehend him—I searched their lodgings—I made certain inquiries of William Ault, a butler out of place, and mentioned the result to Mr. Fisher—these inquiries were made in consequence of the very minute information that Martin and these three parties gave me as to their movements on that evening—I know Brewer-street, Golden-square—I know a place called Willis's-rooms there, they are sometimes taken by one individual, who arranges for a ball to take place at intervals of several weeks—I know Evans's in Covent-garden.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. You said that Mr. Fisher directed you to take them;

do you know bow he came to do that? A. I believe there was a commu
nication with Mr. Paynter, the Magistrate—I know that Mr. Paynter and Mr. Fisher had interviews, and the result was, that I took the parties into custody—I have seen Ault here to-day, he is not subpœnaed on the part of the prosecution—the keys of both these boxes were given to me by Charnell—he showed me the cupboard where the key of the closet was deposited—that was within the pantry—there were marks on the pantry door as if it had been attempted to be broken open, but had not been—I think it was opened with a key, the lock was in good condition.

MR. COOPER. Q. If the box was locked, it must have been unlocked by a key, because there was no force apparently applied to it. A. Yes—but if it had been left unlocked, it would require no key—I heard Charnell say that all the plate which had been in use that evening was in the closet, within the iron door; that is a recess two or three yards deep, which opened out of his room.
COURT. to MR. FISHER. Q. Did Charnell say anything to you abort going to the house or lodging of any one else when he found out that the robbery had been committed? A. No.

HENRY FELLS . (policeman, A 279). On the morning of 5th April, in consequence of information I received, I went to No. 39, Somens-street, Portman-square, about 9 o'clock, and found a person named Gilbert—he did not at that time give me any letter—on the same morning I took Charnell, and on the way from the station to the police court, between 11 and 12 o'clock, after the charge had been taken, he said, "What can we do?"—I said, "I really do not know, unless you can give us any assistance"—he said, "I left my master's house about half past 12 o'clock last night, in company with four other men; we took a cab and drove to Brewer-street, Golden-square; one of the men, who was a perfect stranger to me, left us there; we went to Willies-rooms and found them closed" (that is in Brewer-street, it is called Little Willis's;) "we then went to Willis's-rooms in King-street, St. James's, and finding them closed we went back to the Haymarket, when Peshell, who felt tiffed at some little circumstance which happened, left us; we afterwards went to the corner of St. James's-street, when Tillett left us, and myself and Martin returned as far as Arabella-row, where Martin left me"—after he had been remanded that day, Saturday, 5th, I went again to Gilbert's, on the Monday morning, about 9 o'clock, and received from him this letter (produced)—on 2nd May I took Tillett in custody, and he stated the same as nearly as possible as Martin and Peshell had to the inspector—I asked him for the letter which Charnell had sent him to invite him to the ball, and he gave it to me—he said that he received it about tea time on Friday, 4th April.

Cross-examined by MR. MAC ENTEER. Q. Did you ask Charnell where Sale lived? A. No, he told me that Sale was a perfect stranger to him—I may have made inquiry about it—his answer about being a stranger was not in reply to my asking him where Sale lived—Charnell was in custody when I did ask him—it was on some occasion when he was brought up on remand—I cannot swear that he said anything at all about him.
Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Did Peshell tell you that after the tiff he joined them again in the Hay market? A. Yes, and saw Charnell there again.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. When did you first see Tillett? A. On Saturday, 5th April—it was then that he made the statement—I asked him first what account he could give of the robbery which had taken

place, and told him that, during the night they were out the whole of Mr. Fisher's plate was stolen—he said that he was not aware of it, and was very sorry it had occurred—after he made the statement I left him, and went to him again a few days afterwards—I have not seen his master—on the second occasion I asked him for the letter which he had received from Charaell, and he at once produced it, enclosed in an envelope—I took it away—he did not show me a letter on the first occasion—three or four days after this second occasion I went to him again, and asked him how it was that the letter did not bear the proper date (I had found out that it appeared to be an envelope of an improper date)—he said that he supposed it was the envelope of another letter which he had received, and went and hunted for it, he answered all my questions fairly—I did not go with him to hunt for it—I might have done so—I have heard from his fellow servant that he has lived three years with his master, and bears the highest character for honesty, and has the entire care of the plate—he was taken into custody, I think, a fortnight after that—it was two or three weeks after the robbery—I found him at his master's house every time I went, except once, when he had gone out with his master.

MR. GIFFARD. Q. Did he ever give you any envelope which bore the same date as the letter? A. No—(The letter was written from Eaton-place; the post mark was March 22nd, 1856; addressed, "Mr. Tillett, No. 80, Westbourne-terrace, Hyde-park" inviting him to meet the writer at a ball at Willis's Rooms, Brewer-Street, that evening at half-past 11 o'clock, and signed, "HARRY.")

JAMES GILBERT . I received a letter about half-past 2 o'clock on a Saturday afternoon, which I afterwards gave to Tillett—I cannot say the date—it was on the same day that Tillett came to me, early in the morning, about 9 o'clock—(Read: Post mark 10th April, 5, 1856. "Mrs. Gilbert, No. 37, Somerset-street, Portman-square. No. 30, Eaton-place. My dear Mrs. Gilbert,—I am distressed beyond all measure, as I was out Friday night without permission, and what was my distress when I came home to find some one had broken in the house and stolen all our plate! Fancy my distress! Now, what have I to say? Pray let me rely on you to say you sent for me, and do you pass as my cousin; I will say you was taken very dangerous ill, and sent for me about 11 or 12 o'clock, or between that and 12. Now, do let me trust this to you and Gilbert, as there is no other friend would say this. What am I to do? No friends, character, or place to go to! What am I to say when they come down stairs this morning, Satur
day? Do carry this out for me, if there should be any inquiries about Your very sincere friend, H. Charnell.")

JAKE FENNER . I am cook in the service of Mr. Fisher. I have seen Martin at Mr. Fisher's—he may have been there twice a week, and Tillett two or three times a week—they visited Charnell—on Thursday night before this happened, the servants sopped at 9 o'clock, and at a quarter to 10 o'clock I went across the pantry into the kitchen to turn off the gas, and saw Tillett, Charnell, and M'Gavin in the pantry—at a little after 7 o'clock next morning, Charnell came to me in the kitchen, and asked me if I had heard what had occurred—I said, "Yes"—he said that he had been out to see a cousin who was ill—I asked him if he knew anything of the plate going—he said, "No"—I asked him if he went for a policeman—he said that he went on the area steps at 2, 3, and 4 o'clock, and could not see one—I asked him why he did not leave the house, and go and see for one—he said that he was afraid of being suspected of the robbery—I asked him
if he had told Mr. Fisher—he said, "Yes"—he said afterwards, about 9 o'clock, that he did not like to disturb Mr. Fisher so early.

Cross-examined by MR. MACENTEER. Q. On the evening of the robbery was Mr. Fisher in the house? A. I do not know, but he was there at dinner—I do not know at what time his brother left that night—they dined at half-past 7 o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. Do you see much company down stairs at Mr. Fisher's? A. Not a great deal—friends have called and will call—there is a man servant and four women servants—I have friends to see me occasionally of an evening—gentlemen do not look in to see me.
Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. I suppose a male cousin sometimes calls on you? A. Sometimes—I have a brother that has called once.

MARGARET AUGHTIE . I am lady's maid to Mrs. Fisher, and have been so ten years. I know Martin by his coming to see Channel—he came about half-past 10 o'clock on the Friday—the rest of the female servants had gone to bed—I heard a knocking at the area door, and let him in—he said, "I want to speak to Charnell for a minute"—he went straight to Charnel's room, and I saw no more of him—the bell is dose under the area door, and if rung would be heard over the lower part of the house—the area gate is generally locked at that time.
Cross-examined by MR. MAC ENTEER. Q. Is there a knocker on the door? A. No.

Cross-examined by MR. PARRY. Q. He might knock at the door or kick? A. Yes—I have never heard anybody knock at the door at night before, unless our servants are shut out, then they go to the coal cellar—I have not knocked with my knuckles, and never knew any one do so—no gentle
man who came to see me complained that his knuckles were sore with knocking.
MR. GIFFARD. Q. Is there a bell close to the door which you can ring if you like? A. Yes.

HANNAH LAWSON . I am in Mr. Fisher's service as kitchen maid. I went to bed on that night about a quarter post 10 o'clock—M'Gavin was there when I went to bed, and he let Tillett in—I saw the pendulum of the area bell moving, but the bell was not ringing—I went to the door and saw Tillett; he asked if Charnell was in, and I said, "Yes"—he went into Charnell's room, and I saw no more of him.
Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. Does the bell go easily? A. It depends on how you pull it—bells sometimes make a greater clatter than people intend.

CHARLES M'GAVIN . I live at No. 27, Doyle-street, Chelsea, and job about at gentlemen's houses. I have several times done jobs at Mr. Fisher's—I was there on Friday night, the 4th, at 6 o'clock in the evening, to clean boots and shoes—I left somewhere about 10 o'clock, and just before I went away I was in the pantry, and Tillett came in—it was then ten minutes or a quarter to 10 o'clock—after dinner I saw Charnell put all the plate that had been used into the closet—I have seen Martin there once or twice, but not that night.

Cross-examined by MR. MAC ENTEER. Q. When you left, was the entrance
gate unlocked? A. Yes.

Cross-examined by MR. COOPER. Q. What were you doing? A. Wiping up the dessert things in the pantry—he could not know that I was there—he just said, "How do you do?"—he was not there when the plate was put in. (The prisoners received excellent characters.)
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: ESSEX CASES.

div1.p:
548.
JAMES WILLIAM HONNER
, embezzling and stealing 5s. and 10s.; the moneys of
Joseph Conquest Hartwell, his master: to which he

PLEADED GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Four Months. (There were two other indictments against the prisoner.)

549.
JAMES GRAWLEY
, stealing 16lbs. weight of leaden pipe, value 10s.; the goods of
Frederick Corfield.
MR. SLEIGH. conducted the Prosecution.

MARY JONES . I am the wife of John Jones; I live in Gurney's-road, West Ham. On Thursday, 8th May, about 12 or 1 o'clock, I saw the pri
soner in a back yard, near to some unfinished houses, near to my house—I saw him pick up some leaden pipe, and I believe he had two pieces in his hand—there was another lad with him—I called to the prisoner, and asked what he was doing there—he threw the pieces of lead on the ground, and ran away—I picked them up, and gave them to the policeman—these are them—I have known the prisoner some years—I have no doubt he is the boy.
JOSEPH BENTON . (policeman, K 381). I took the prisoner into custody—I told him it was on suspicion of stealing some lead from some new houses—he said he knew nothing about it, he was not there.
FREDERICK CORFIELD . I am the owner of those houses—I believe this lead pipe to be mine—I was about to enclose the yards—they are not yet enclosed.
NOT GUILTY .

550.
ANN WINCHESTER
, stealing 2 sovereigns; the moneys of
James Kettle, her master.

HARRIET KETTLE . I am the wife of James Kettle. The prisoner came into my service on 4th April—on. 11th April I had 50l. in a glove on the mantelpiece—I had tied it up two days before—I saw it safe at 7 o'clock, at a quarter past 7 I saw it had been untied—I counted it, and found two sovereigns were missing; one was marked—I had the rheumatism, and could not dress myself, and I asked her to assist me, and I sent her to fetch the remainder of my clothes from my sleeping room, where the glove was.

JOHN PADDICK . (policeman, N 301). On the morning of 11th April I was sent for to the prosecutrix's house—Mrs. Kettle said she would give the prisoner in charge for stealing two sovereigns—I said to the prisoner, "You must go along with me"—she went into the back room to put on, her bonnet and shawl, and she took up this basket (producing it)—I said to her, "Does this belong to you?"—she said, "Yes"—I looked into it, and found these two sovereigns—the prisoner said she did not know how they came there—before I found them she said she would give Mrs. Kettle her watch, and stop in her service till such time as the money was paid.
HARRIET KETTLE . These are the two sovereigns, one is marked.
JURY. Q. How came you to leave the money there? A. I meant to have taken it down, but I forgot it—I generally carry it in my bosom, but laid it on the mantelpiece at night.
Prisoner. I know nothing about it; there was another servant who swept the room a quarter before 7 o'clock. Witness. I have a girl to nurse the children, but she had not been up stairs.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.

551.
JOHN FENNELL and
SARAH HOWES
, stealing 2 blankets, 4 sheets, and other articles, value 18s., and 350l. in money; the property of
William Horne.
MESSRS. SLEIGH. and THOMPSON. conducted the Prosecution.

WILLIAM HORNE . I am an excavator, and live in North Woolwich-road. I resided there with my wife in April last—I have been married about eleven years—I had some money, which I had saved up—it was in a box at the foot of the bed, in the bedroom up stairs, where I slept—I cannot say exactly the amount, I believe nearly 400l., it was all in gold, in sovereigns and half sovereigns—on 21st April I left home between 8 and 9 o'clock in the morning; I went to Chatham to seek for employment—I returned between 9 and 10 o'clock in the evening—I found my wife was not at home, and I missed my money and my clothes—there was some little money left, about 30l.—the box was always kept locked, and my wife kept the key of it—I missed all my wife's wearing apparel, and some blankets, and sheets and other things, and five shirts, these articles which were brought from Liverpool—I can identify this patchwork quilt, and this towel I know—these sheets and blankets are mine—I can speak to them as being my pro
perty—my wife did not return that night—I went over to the Borough, where I expected to find her—I never saw Howes but once before, which was at my wife's father's house at Maidstone—I knew Fennell before—he had lodged with me for two years I dare say, but he had left me a good while, for more than a year—I saw Howes the next day in the Borough—I asked if she knew where my wife was; she said she did, and she said she would bring her to me, and I should see her, which she did not do—she told me times and times over that she would bring her to me, but she did not do it—she said the same again till I got tired of it—I saw her seven or eight days, and she always repeated the same words to me—I offered her 5l. if she would show me the house where my wife was, that I could see her—I asked her if there was a man with my wife—she said no, there was no man with her, and she asked whether I thought there was—I said I did not know; I could not say exactly whether there was or not, but I had a suspicion—the last conversation I had with Howes was on the Monday before I gave her into custody—she then told me if I would come the next morning she would take me to her—on the Tuesday I saw her again, and gave her in charge of the police—when she was given in charge I and the policeman went with her to a house in Brook-street, West-square—the first house we went to we did not go in—when we did get into a house, there was a great deal of conversation—Howes said that my wife was staying with Mrs. Hughes, and likewise Fennell—we could not find them—Mrs. Hughes's husband was there—Mrs. Hughes said that Howes, had done all the mischief, and wanted to get all the trouble off her, and Mrs. Hughes's husband said if Howes came there any more he would throw her out of the window—Howes said she did not want to come there, she did not know that she had done anything wrong—after that I made further search for my wife—I did not find her—I never saw her—I gave the case into the policeman's hands—this gold watch and chain are mine.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. Your wife kept the key of the box in which the money was? A. Yes; it may have been six months since I saw the money—I know this quilt to be mine—it has no mark on it—I know it by seeing it made, and by the work that is put in it—this towel I know—it has a mark on it—I had seen these things before the officer brought them from Liverpool, and had used them too—I know them—I

know this blanket—there is no mark on it—I have made the beds lately—I had worked for that sum of money—I had been saving it about eleven years—the reason I did not put it in the saving-bank, was became my wife would not agree to it.

CHARLES ABBOTT . (policeman, K 322). I took Howes into custody on 29th April, in Park-street, Borough. I said I took her for being concerned with Mrs. Horne, in removing her things away from her husband—she said she knew she had done wrong, and her husband would have persuaded her not to have gone—she said, "I will go and tell Mr. Borne where his wife is"—I said "Very well, come with me"—we took a cab, and went to No. 77, Brook-street, Lambeth, to Mrs. Hughes, who, Mrs. Howes said was her sister-in-law—when we got there, Mrs. Howes said to Mrs. Hughes, "Do you know where Mrs. Horne is gone to?"—Mrs. Hughes said, "Perhaps she is over the way, where she has taken the room"—we went over the way, to No. 46, and when we got there Howes asked where Betsy was gone—the old lady said, she did not know, she had not seen her that morning—Howes then said that a man went away in a van, and Mrs. Horne had gone with him—I then took Howes to the station.
Cross-examined. Q. Where was it that Mrs. Howes said this? A. In Brook-street, when we came away from No. 46.

HARRIET SMITH . I am the wife of John Smith. On the morning of 21st April, I passed Mr. Horne's house, and Mrs. Horne called me in—I went in, and staid several minutes—I went away, and came back again, and went in myself—Mrs. Horne was there, and Howes, and the next-door neighbour—I saw one box and two bags on the floor—Mrs. Horne asked me to help her, which I did—I carried one bag, and Mrs. Horne, and Mrs. Howes, and I, all proceeded to Blackwall, carrying those things—I left them there and went home.

JOHN SULLIVAN . I am a detective police-officer at Liverpool. In conse
quence of a telegraphic message, I found the prisoner Fennell in a public-house, in Robert-street, Liverpool, kept by Mrs. Pearce—Mrs. Horne was with Fennell—I asked Mrs. Horne what her name was—she said, "Mrs. Jones"—I then asked Fennell what his name was—he said, "Mr. Jones"—I said, "No, your name is Fennell; you absconded with this woman, taking with you a quantity of property, and between 300l. and 400l."—he then said, "My name in Fennell;" and he said he merely met that woman at the railway station at London—I took them to the police office, and two bags, a carpet bag, a box of provisions, and other articles—I searched Fen
nell, and found this belt round his body—I asked him what was in it—he said "Gold"—I asked him what amount?—he said, "I can't tell within 7l. or 8l.; I think about 120l."—I opened it, and found in it 127l. 10s. in gold; and on his person a half-sovereign, and five shillings, a sixpence, and 5 1/2 d. in coppers—I asked him where he got the gold—he said he had been working in the Crimea, and brought the money from there—I asked him if he knew who paid him then—he said he could not tell me—I also found on his person this shipping ticket for John Jones and Elizabeth Jones, to Australia, and 25l. paid for their passage—the date of sailing is 5th May—Mrs. Horne said she knew nothing about the money—I found a silver watch and a chain in one of the boxes which Fennell claimed.

Cross-examined. Q. When you first saw them at the lodging at Liver-pool, did you notice that there was an address on the box? A. Yes; "Mrs. Brown, Liverpool"—on one of the bags was "Mr. Jones, Liverpool" and no
direction on the other—Fennell told me he had been working at the railway in the Crimea, for Peto and Brassey—these sheets, and blankets, and towels were in the bags which I found.

MR. SLEIGH. Q. Did you go in the house where Fennell and Mrs. Horne were, and get these things out of the bedroom where they both slept? A. Yes; I asked Fennell if he slept in the room where these things were found—he said he did—I brought all the property from Li
verpool to London.

FRANCES LAWSON . I am searcher at the police station at Liverpool I searched Mrs. Horne; I took from her 60l. in sovereigns and half sovereigns and this gold watch and chain—I gave them to the last witness.

MABY REED . I am a widow, I live at No. 46, Brook-street, West-square, Lambeth.
