The prisoner, Fennell, and Mrs. Brown, occupied the parlour in my house—Mrs. Hughes recommended Mrs. Brown as a widow—she came on Tuesday, 22nd April, and remained till the 28th—Fennell joined her there at the latter end of the week, it might be on Friday, and he remained till the Monday—he went into the country on the Sunday morning, and came back—I do not know whether he slept there—I saw him late and I saw him early—they left on Monday evening—I was not at home when they left—the prisoner, Howes, came to my house on the Wednesday, and asked for Mrs. Brown—I said she was not at home—I saw Howes once or twice afterwards, but Mrs. Brown was to be denied to her.

Cross-examined. Q. Who took the room? A. Mrs. Hughes came with Mrs. Brown, and gave her a recommendation—Mrs. Brown came on Tues
day—I am positive I saw the man on the Friday, it might be earlier—I saw him several times after the Friday, and was in company with him—I saw him on Saturday night between 10 and 11 o'clock—I saw him in the garden on Sunday morning between 7 and 8 o'clock—I saw him in the house afterwards.

EMMA HUGHES . I am the wife of William Hughes; I live at No. 77, Brook-street, West-square, Lambeth; Mrs. Howes is my brother's wife On 22nd April, she brought a woman to my house in the name of Betsy Wood—I had seen her before, about twenty years ago, when I was quite a child—she was then Betsy Wood—I had not seen her within the last year or two—I have seen her since, and have been told she is Mrs. Horne—when Mrs. Howes brought her, she wanted to know if Betsy Wood could remain with me a little while—I had (no room, and I took her to the last witness's house—we all three went together—on the following Monday I saw Betsy Wood leaving Mrs. Reed's house, and the prisoner, Fennell, was with her—they got into a van and went away—I went with them—they took with them a box and a carpet bag—the box was a great deal like this box that is here—I did not see any card on it—I saw Mrs. Howes when these persons were going—we all walked to the public house at the corner together—then I went with the van, but Mrs. Howes did not.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you not some doubt whether it was this man or not? A. I did not know him before—I went with them a little way—I had only been living in London a fortnight—I did not know Fennel's name at all till it was on my paper—Mrs. Reed's house is No. 46, Brook-street—my house is No. 77.
THOMAS SHARP HOLMES . (police inspector, K This box was handed to me by inspector Sullivan—it was opened in my presence, and this property produced.

JOHN SULLIVAN . re-examined. This is the box that I took from the room where Fennell and the woman were living—I locked the box up and deli
vered the key to the last witness.

FREDERICK MOORE . Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. I am in the ser
vice of Peto and Brassey. I knew Mr. Currey, he was one of the time keepers lately in our employ—the railway from Balaklava to Sebastopol was constructed by Peto and Brassey—there was a man employed there named John Fennell—there was only one John Fennel—I paid John Fennell his last account—I cannot recognise the man at the bar—it is impossible to recognise one man out of 500—I paid some of the men; I paid a person who called himself John Fennell—I have no belief whether this man is the John Fennell, I do not know him—the men received personally the money that was due to them—the balance that I paid to John Fennell was 12l. 7s. 6d.—I have not my books here—I did not pay John Fennell any more money, nor did I see it paid—the other money was paid in the Crimea by Mr. Bartlett—I have the balance sheet in my writing—this is from the book—a receipt was given—I have not the receipt here; I have a copy of it.
WILLIAM HORNE . re-examined. I know that Fennell left this country for the Crimea—I cannot tell when he came back, I think some time in Nov.

FREDERICK MOORE . re-examined Some of the men were in the Crimea about six months—some longer, some not so long—a labourer on the rail
way there would earn 5s. a day—John Fennell was a horse keeper—he wonld earn 7s. 6d. a day—he would have overwork—he might, as horse keeper earn as much as 110l. Or in six months—he would not have to provide for himself out of his wages—some rations would be furnished to him by Government—it was the duty of Mr. Beattie to hire persons going to the Crimea, but he is dead now—I believe two or three clerks used to assist him, but I am sure I do not know their names—when the men come back there is some one sent down on board each vessel to arrange the time and place of payment—I went down as well as others—when I went down I suppose I should see John Fennell as well as others.

FENNELL—
GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Two Years.

HOWES—
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: KENT CASES.

div1.p:
552.
WILLIAM PONMAN,
JOHN REYNOLDS,
WILLIAM REY
NOLDS , and
JOHN GORE
, stealing a purse, and 2l.; the property of
William East, from the person of
Sarah East.
MR. LILLEY. conducted the Prosecution.

SARAH EAST . I am the wife of William East, and keep a sweet
stuff shop, at Lower Sydenham. On 14th April, about 6 o'clock: in the evening, the two Reynolds and Gore came into the shop, and asked for some almond rock; I could not reach the glass, and asked one of them to take it down from the window for me—they would not do so—John Reynolds said, "Come round and get it yourself"—I went round the counter and got it; in doing so I passed the prisoners—I had the glass in my hand, and then they said they would not have any sweets, I sold them too dear—I told them it was 2d. an ounce—they said they would have a biscuit—John Reynolds

took one out of the window, and gave his brother one—they each took one, and each gave me a farthing—they then went away in a hurried manner—before they came in I had a purse in my pocket—I know I had it safe about a minute before they came in, because I had just paid a bill, and had used it—I had about 2l. in it—there was a half sovereign, three or four half crowns, and the rest in shillings and sixpences—the half sovereign was wrapped up in a small piece of paper, a kind of newspaper, which was rather dirty—I missed my purse about a minute after the prisoners had left the shop—a customer came in immediately they had gone, and wanted change, and I found my purse was gone—I informed my husband of my loss, and he went to the station, and returned with the police, and they went in pursuit of the prisoners about ten minutes after they had left the shop—I should know the piece of paper again in which the half sovereign was wrapped—this (produced) is it, and this is my purse—I only know the paper from the wear—I had used it for the same purpose for perhaps three weeks or a month, and it had worn a hole.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Where did you get your purse? A. From a man that picked it up in a gentleman's garden close by—he brought it into the shop, and gave it me—I do not know him—he is not here—this piece of paper was shown to me at the station house by one of the policemen—I had told him that the half sovereign was in a piece of dirty sort of newspaper, and that it had got a small hole in it from wear—I did not tell him it was torn in a triangular shape—the bill I paid was for butter and bacon, to a young man who called for it—no one serves in the shop but myself—my husband interferes very little in the business—I did not see Ponman at all till I went to the station—nobody came into the shop after the butterman left, except the prisoners.
MR. LILLEY. Q. Had you your purse safe after that man left? A. Yes; I am sure of that.
COURT. Q. Had you ever seen any of these boys at your shop before? A. No, nor in the neighbourhood—none of my money was marked.

THOMAS INGRAM . (policeman, R 474). I was on duty at Sydenham, about half past 6 o'clock, on 14th April, and, in consequence of information, I apprehended William Reynolds and Gore—as I was taking them to the station, some one called out, "Policeman, mind one of these has got some
thing in his hand"—I found that William Reynolds had two half crowns and three shillings in his left hand—I afterwards searched him at the station, and found 5d. in copper, and a penny on Gore—when I took the money from Willian Reynolds, I said, "What have you there?"—I laid hold of his hand, and he dropped it into my hand—he did not say anything.

Cross
examined. Q. Did not he put his hand into his pocket and take out the money? A. I cannot say positively whether he did or not—Mrs. East had told me she had been robbed by three boys—I afterwards went to fetch her to the station—I asked her what money there was—she said, "A half sovereign, wrapped up in a piece of paper"—I asked her if she would know the piece of paper; she said,. "Yes"—that was all she said—she said it was a piece of old newspaper—that was all the descrip
tion she gave of it—when she was at the station this piece of paper was lying on jthe desk, with several others, and she looked down, and said, "That is the piece of paper the half sovereign was wrapped up in; I have had it in my possession three or four weeks"—the other pieces were not like this, quite different—I believe all the prisoners live in one street, somewhere in Shoreditch.

JOHN ROBERT REYNOLDS . (policeman, R 289). On the evening of 14th April I saw the four prisoners in High-street, Sydenham—I apprehended Ponman and John Reynolds—Ingram took the other two—I searched them at the station; on Ponman I found a half sovereign, a piece of paper, 7s. 6d. in silver, and 5d. in copper—the half sovereign fell as I went to lay it on, the desk; whether it fell from the paper I could not tell—I also found a tobacco box and a knife on Ponman; and on John Reynolds a tobacco box—when they were charged with the robbery, Ponman said he knew nothing of it—the others did not say anything in my hearing.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not each of them say they knew nothing of the robbery? A. Not in my presence or hearing—I recollect no one speaking but Ponman at the station—the paper may have been separate from the half-crown, for aught I know—there was a piece of brown paper in his pocket, something similar to what sugar is wrapped in—there was nothing else in the same pocket but a piece of string—the tobacco box was in a different pocket, but I have kept the paper in it since—the purse was found in a gentleman's garden—I did not see it found—the person who found it pointed out the spot to me, but could not state the day on which he found it—it was about half a mile from where I took the prisoners into custody—Ponman was with his barrow when I met him—he had it nearly filled with iron ware, shovels, and hoops, and things—the other boys were with him—I did not see that they had anything.

JOSEPH JOHN HUSSEY . I am a blacksmith, of No. 3, Charlotte-street, Turville-street, Bethnal-green—I have known Ponman two or three years—he has been working for me for the last five months—I always considered him honest and industrious—I never knew anything against him.

Cross-examined by MR. LILLEY. Q. How came he to have his head cropped so? A. He has been ill since his imprisonment, and has had his head shared—I live near him—he is married—I know all the other prisoners perfectly well, and have done so for two or three years—Ponman worked for me up to the time of his being taken into custody—I sent him out on that day to dispose of goods—he had with him about 3 cwt of goods, worth between 5l. and 6l.—I got the goods back from the policeman at the station—about 1l. worth had been sold—he has been in the habit of travelling for me with goods in that way, daily, for five months, to every part within twenty miles of London, and he used to account to me daily—I have known the Reynolds from their infancy, and never knew any harm of them—they are employed by their father, who is a hawker of hardware—Gore was employed by Ponman to help push his barrow—he lives in the same street.

JAMES REYNOLDS . I am a hawker in Charlotte-street, Church-street, Shoreditch—the two prisoners are my sons—they go out hawking for me—they have always been well conducted—I sent them out on this occasion with 8s. or 9s. worth of cinder shovels, funnels, and other things, and they sold as many as came to 7s. 6d. in one place, Mr. Charles's, who keeps the Coal club in Woodbine-grove, Anerley, ana here is his writing to prove it (pro
ducing a paper)
(Several other witnessed deposed to the prisoner's good characters.)

JOHN ROBERT REYNOLDS . re-examined. I have been on duty at Sydenham nearly two years—that is not far from Anerly—I do not know Anerley at all—I cannot tell whether there is a Mr. Charles keeping the Coal club there.
NOT GUILTY .

553.
ISABELLA STUART
, stealing a necklace, the goods of
John Townley, from the person of
Emma Townley: and
ANN STUART
, feloniously receiving the same; to which

ISABELLA STUART
PLEADED GUILTY .—
Discharged.

MARY ANN TOWNLEY . I am the wife of John Townley, a blacksmith at Woolwich—I have a little girl eighteen months old—on 13th April, about half-past 12 o'clock in the day, she was standing at my front door—she had a coral necklace on—I saw Isabella Stuart there—I had not known her before—she spoke to my child, and remained there about a quarter of an hour—she took her up in her arms, and then put her down—I heard the child cry, and went, and missed the necklace off her neck—I then went after the prisoner, but did not see her—she was afterwards taken to the police station—she then said she lived in St. Mary's-street—first she said No. 25, and afterwards No. 27—I went there, but found nobody belonging to her.

JAMES ATTWOOD . (policeman, R 313) The child Isabella was brought to the station and given into my custody—I told her she was charged with taking this coral necklace from a little child—she said, "I took it and chucked it under a box in the room my father and mother occupied"—I asked her where she lived—she said, "No. 25, St. Mary-street"—I after
wards went to No. 56, Warwick-street—I went there in consequence of finding the name of Stuart in a prayer book which the child had in her possession—I knew persons of that name living at No. 56, Warwick-street—I went there, and found the prisoner Ann Stuart—I asked her if she had a daughter named Isabella—she said she had—I asked her whether Isabella had been out in the morning—she said, "No"—I asked her that again, and she said, "Yes, she was out about an hour, about dinner time"—I asked her if she had a little boy—she said, "Yes"—I asked where he was—she said he was gone to the barrack school—I asked her whether either of them had brought anything home this morning—she said, "No, nothing"—I said, "Are you sure of that?"—she said, "Yes"—I then said, "Isabella is at the station, in charge for stealing a coral necklace with a gold snap, and I must search your room, as Isabella says she took it, and it is here"—she said, "Oh, my little boy brought home a necklace, and said he had found it," and she went to a cupboard and brought out this necklace which I now produce—I told her she must go to the station along with me, which she did.

Ann Stuart's Defence. At a quarter to 2 o'clock ray little boy went out to play in the back lane; when he came in he showed me these beads, and said he had picked them up; I asked where he got them; he said, "Mother, I will show you," and I went with him, and he showed me where he found them; I put them in my cupboard, intending to make inquiry about them; about half-past 4 o'clock the prosecutor and the policeman came, and I told them the same; I did not know they were stolen; the policeman waited till my tittle boy came home, and he told the policeman where he had picked them up.

JAMES ATTWOOD . re-examined. The little boy came home just before I left—he was asked where he found them, and he told me, in the back lane—he is about eight or nine years old—he is here—the prisoner's husband is a pensioner, and works at shoe making.

ANN STUART—
NOT GUILTY .

554.
JOHN BEALE,
PATRICK MURPHY , and
DANIEL MURPHY
, stealing a quantity of leather, value 10l., the goods of
James Crossley.

JOHN BURBIDGE . I am a boot maker, and live in Douglas-street Deptford. I have known Besle these twenty years—I saw him on 26th March, he said he had lost sight of me for some time, and he could have put a few pounds in my way—I said, "In what way?"—he said, about some leather that was got on the cross, and he supposed I did not mind buying it on the cross—I said, "No," and I asked him how much there was of it—he said, there was a pretty good swag, but the greater part was gone—I asked him how much he could get of it—he said he did not know exactly, but he would see me again—I appointed to see him in about an hour or an hour end a half—when he was gone I went to Mr. Crossley's, I had heard he had lost some leather—I saw Beale again at the top of Douglas-street, I asked him where the man lived who had the leather, and whether I should go with him—he said, no, perhaps, he should not see him till night—I saw Beale again on the following day, but he said he could not get it—on the Saturday morning he came to my house with a piece of leather bound round him, under his clothes (my daughter opened the door)—he took it out, and I saw it was Mr. Crossley's, it had his dressers' mark and the number—I asked him how much he asked for it—he said 5s.—I said, "I must get you to call again in half an hour, and then I will make it all right"—he went away and I went out the other way—I rather think he watched me—he came back to my house, but I was not at home.

MARY ANN DAVIS . I am the wife of John Davis, and daughter of the last witness—I was at his house on 29th March, I remember Beale coming—he asked for my father, and they went in the parlour and stood talking—I went in the kitchen—my father went out and I asked Beale whether he would stay or call again in half an hour—he said he would call again—he went away, and in three or four minutes Beale came back and said he wanted the leather for my father, who was waiting at the end of the street—I said, I would not give it up except my father came—Beale staid some time and went away.

JAMES CROSSLEY . I am a currier and live in Church-street, Deptford. On 26th March I received some communication from Burbidge—on 19th March my place was broken into, and some leather taken away—on 29th March I received this piece of leather from Mr. Burbidge—it is the same description of leather that I had, but my foreman will speak to it more fully.

CHARLES THOMPSON . I am in the service of Mr. Crossley—this leather is his property—it is part of what was stolen—I saw it safe on the evening of 19th March, and missed it on the morning of the 20th—this piece formed the outside of a bundle of twenty-eight pieces—here are my own initials on it—it is part of a hide cut in two, and my own mark is on it.

JOSIAH TURNER . (policeman, R 307). I was on duty at Deptford on 20th March, and I received information of the robbery—on 28th March I met Beale on Deptford-bridge—he said to me, "Are you looking after a certain party, Jem, the currier?"—I said, "No"—he said, "You are aware there has been a robbery at Mr. Crossley's?"—I said, "Yes"—he said, "I thought you were looking after it"—I said, "No, I was not"—he then said he thought he could find out something about it, if I met him the following morning at 9 o'clock he should be able to give me some information—he said, he should be able to go in the tap room amongst the men, and should hear something more about it—he said, they were two Irishmen, living in Giffin-street—I went at 9 o'clock and waited till 20 minutes to ten o'clock—he did not come—I did not see him till the

evening—on the Saturday evening I took Beale into custody at the corner by the Prince Regent public house—the other two prisoners were with him—I told Beale I should charge him with being concerned in stealing the leather—I said to him, "Do those other two know anything about it?"—he said, "They do"—and an officer took them into custody—in going along, Beale said he was very sorry he had not brought the leather to me instead of taking it to Burbidge, and he should have been all right—at the station he said he had received the leather from Pat Murphy, and Patrick Murphy struck him a violent blow on the eye, using an oath.
Beale. You said, "If you can make out anything about the leather with the two Murphys, do. Witness. I do not believe I mentioned the name of Murphy.

WILLIAM BEEVES WILSON . I am a police inspector—I assisted in taking Patrick and Daniel Murphy to the station—I took the charge and explained that they were charged with stealing a quantity of leather from Mr. Crossley, in Church-street, Deptford—Beale said he had received the leather, which was then lying there, from Pat Murphy, and Patrick Murphy struck him and became violent, and he was removed—Daniel Murphy said, as Beale had implicated his brother, he would tell me all about it—I took him out in the yard, and he said, "A man named Jem, the currier, asked me to lend him a hand to drive a barrow with the leather up to London; I did so, and he took it to a shop in Bermondsey-street and sold it, and he gave me 25s. as my part"—he said, "We left the barrow in the street; that is all I know about it"—I asked him if he knew where the shop was—he said he thought he should be able to find it if he was taken there—he was not taken there, but we inquired at all the shops in Bermondsey-street, and they knew nothing of it.

Daniel Murphy. Q. When you took me, was I drunk or sober? A. You were sober, you had been drinking a little, but you knew what you were saying, and I cautioned you before you spoke—I did not come to you on the Sunday morning at the cell door, and ask you if you knew what you had said.
JAMES CROSSLEY . re-examined. On the night that Daniel Murphy was taken, I merely walked to the station and gave the charge—Daniel Murphy was sober.

ALFRED JOHN CROUCH , (policeman, R 92). I assisted in taking the Murphys to the station—Daniel Murphy was sober, and perfectly able to judge of his own actions—when we arrived at the station Beale put his hand on Patrick Murphy, and said, "This is the man that I had the leather from"—Patrick Murphy struck him a blow on the eye, and he was removed—I left, and went to search Murphy's house in Giffin-street—I found no
thing there—Daniel Murphy said he wished to tell the inspector something—I accompanied the inspector into the yard, and he said he had assisted to take the leather to Bermondsey-street, and he had 25s. for his share—I came in again, and saw this leather on the table—I said to Patrick Murphy, "How do you account for this?"—he said "I picked it up in a passage of a house"—he would not say where the house was.

Beale's Defence. I received this leather from Patrick Murphy; he first told me of it, and it was a week afterwards before I got it; I took it to Mr. Burbidge, and asked him 5s. for it; he offered me 4s.; I am perfectly innocent of the robbery.
Patrick Murphy's Defence. I was going to work at 6 o'clock in the morning, and saw a door partly open; no person had lived in the house for

six months; I saw this piece of leather, and picked it up; I told Beale I had found it, and I did not know what sort it was; I saw him five or six days afterwards, and he asked me if I had sold it; I said "No," and I gave him the leather; I know nothing of it; any person might go in that house, and sleep for a night; there has been no rent paid for the house for above twelve months.
JAMES CROSSLEY . re-examined. This piece of leather produced is worth about 5s.—the whole I lost was worth about 12l.

BEALE—
GUILTY. of receiving . Aged 38.
Confined Twelve Months.

PATRICK MURPHY—
GUILTY. of receiving. Aged 39.
Confined Twelve Months.

DANIEL MURPHY—
NOT GUILTY .
(Patrick Murphy woe also charged with having been before convicted; but James Wiliam Crouch being called to produce the certificate, did not answer.)

555.
MARY ANN MUGGERIDGE
, stealing 1 watch and 1 ring, value 1l. 18s. 6d. and 2l. 15s. in money, the property of
Thomas Jukes, from his person.

JANE KIRK . I am the wife of John Kirk, and live in Queen-street, Greenwich. The prisoner lodged at my house for a month—on Friday before 11th April she gave me a gold finger ring—she asked me to pawn it, which I did, at Mr. Carter's, for 1s. 6d—I gave her the shilling, and the sixpence was laid out for victuals—she told me a marine gave her the ring.

THOMAS JUKES . I am a corporal in the Royal Marines. I was in com
pany with the prisoner on the evening of 2nd of April—I went to bed with her, and in the morning when I awoke, I was deficient of my watch, my money, and the ring—I had put my jacket and trousers under my head—they were withdrawn from under my head, and the watch and money were gone—the ring was taken off my finger without waking me—the prisoner was gone.

CORNELIUS GREENY . (policeman, R 424.) I went to the prisoner's lodging, in Queen-street—I found this duplicate of a ring in a book—I asked the prisoner who put it there—she told me she did—I asked her where she got the ring—she told me it was given her by a marine.
(The prisoner, in her defence, stated that the prosecutor had given her the ring: and that before she left him the landlord had asked him if all was right, and he said"Yes.")

THOMAS JUKES , re-examined. There were two other persons in the room where we were, but there was a partition between us—I did not give the prisoner the ring—I was not exactly sober—the prisoner did not come with the landlord to me, not did the landlord ask if it was all right.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Six Months.

556.
MARTIN MAXWELL
, unlawfully assaulting
Isabella Scopes, with intent, &c.

GUILTY .** Aged 28.—
Confined Two Years.

557.
JOHN DOOLEY
, stealing 1 watch, value 6l.; the goods of
Thomas Fewins, from his person.

THOMAS FEWINS . I am a shipwright, and live at Northfleet. On 12th May, in the afternoon, I was coming out of Greenwich Park about a quarter before 5 o'clock, and on passing through the gate, the prisoner pushed against me and two or three other men—my wife sung out that they were hurting her—I put my arm round her waist, and felt a pull at my watch, and I heard the chain snap like the sound of a gun—I did not see

the prisoner pull my watch, but he was nearest to me, and I collared him—he slipped something over his shoulder, and some other parties tried to break my hold—it could not have been taken by one of the other parties who were near me—I did not see his hand near my person at all, but no one was so near me as him—he was the very next man to me—the person who did it must have used two hands—the guard was too strong to be broken—he broke the ring of the watch.

Prisoner. Q. Were there not 200 or 300 persons? A. The crowd was round me, you, and others—I said to you, "You have got my watch"—you said that you had not, and put your hand behind you—you did not tell me to call a policeman.

ELIZABETH FEWINS . I was with my husband coming through the gate—there was a crowd round—I saw my husband take hold of the prisoner—I saw him deliver the watch over to another person—I distinctly saw the watch in the prisoner's hand.
JAMES PAKKY . (policeman, R 157). The prisoner was given into my custody—he said he was innocent.

Prisoners Defence. I was coming through Greenwich Park; there was a great lot of people; one scratched me on the back of my neck, and nearly knocked my hat off, and then this man seized mef and said, "You have got my watch;"I said, "I have Lot, call a policeman, I know nothing about the watch."

GUILTY .* Aged 22.—
Confined Twelve Months.

558.
MARIA BLACKWELL
, stealing 3 yards of drugget, value 10s.; the goods of
Josiah James.
MARGARET JAMES . I am the wife of Josiah James. I do not know the prisoner—I saw her before the Magistrate—I did not see her on 12th April.

ALEXANDER WAXES . I work for Mr. Combes, of Chapel-street, Wool
wich. On 12th April, between 3 and 4 o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner stand at Mr. James's door, for two or three minutes—two sailors then went in, and the prisoner directly afterwards—I did not see her come out—I had never seen her before—I did not see her again till the policeman pointed her out, and asked if I knew her.
RICHARD CLARK . I am a pawnbroker. I took in this drugget of the prisoner on the evening of 12th April for 4s.—I knew her before.

MARGARET JAMES . re-examined. I know this drugget—there are two or three stains on it, and one in particular—I saw it safe between 10 and 11 o'clock in the morning, and had it in my front parlour—I keep a dairy—we have sailors there on Saturdays, and we take up the carpets and put them aside—I did not miss this on the Saturday, but missed it on Monday morning.

JOHN NEWELL . (policeman, R 59). I took the prisoner into custody—I asked her where she got the piece of drugget that she had pawned—she said she received it of a little child, who asked her to pawn it, saying her mother was ill—she said it was a little girl about eleven years old, the size of her own daughter—she said she had seen her many times, but did not know where she lived.

Prisoner's Defence. I was at home that night; I was not there; I was not out of the house from 2 o'clock till between 5 and 6; I then went out; a person asked me to pawn this for her, and I did; I pawned it in my own name, which I objected to; I redeemed two articles of my own at the time.
RICHARD CLARK . re-examined. I do not remember that she objected to it being in her name.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined Three Months.

559.
RICHARD JORDAN
, stealing 3 planes, value 1l. 2s., the goods of
George Notley.

GEORGE NOTLEY . I am a joiner, and live in Fox's-place, Plumstead. A fortnight before 2nd May, I left a basket of tools at a beer shop—I was there daily—I went there to dine—I saw them safe the day before I missed them—I missed three planes and some other things—these are the planes—the other things have not been found.

CAROLINE DUNSTONE . I am the wife of William Dunstone, he keeps a beer shop near the Royal Arsenal. The last witness left a basket of tools at my house—they were placed in the kitchen—I saw them safe many times—the prisoner came and took a lodging on the 22nd or 23rd April—he slept there on the 22nd and 23rd—I saw the tools safe when he got up on the morning of the 24th—he left about 9 o'clock—I missed the tools about a quarter of an hour afterwards—the prisoner had been in the kitchen between 7 and 9 o'clock—I left him there—I saw him leave the house carrying something in front of him, covered with something that seemed to me like a handkerchief.
JOHN THORP . I live with Mr. Moore, a pawnbroker, in Woolwich. These planes were pawned by the prisoner on the 24th April, about 10 o'clock in the morning.
JAMES WESTBROOK , (policeman, R 114). I took the prisoner—I found on him seven duplicates—one of them related to these planes.
Prisoner. I did not offer to make away. Witness. I did not give him a chance, I took hold of him—he tried to get rid of the duplicates.
Prisoner. I have been in custody nearly a month; it is the first thing I have ever been guilty of in my life.

GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Confined Twelve Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

560.
HENRY SMART
, stealing 28lbs. weight of rags, 30 plates, 7 dishes, and other articles, the goods of
Thomas Charles Andrews, his master; and
CHARLOTTE PERRIN
, feloniously receiving the same, knowing them to have been stolen.
MR. RIBTON. conducted the Prosecution.

THOMAS CHARLES ANDREWS . I keep a china shop and deal in rags at No. 16, Richard-street, Woolwich—Smart was in my service as carman over twelve months—I have missed a great quantity of rags and other goods, and I have called his attention to it—on 10th April I was called in to my dinner—I was busy, and was not more than ten minutes—I went to the front door and saw Smart coming across the road—I had ordered him not to leave the back door, and that gave me suspicion—he had a bag and a screw wrench with him—I said to him, "Where have you been?"—he said, "Over the way to borrow this wrench"—I said, "Where have you been with the bag?"—he said, "Round the comer"—I said, "Where?"—he said, "Round the corner," and began to be very insolent—I said, "I insist on knowing"—I took it from him, and found that rags had been in it—I said, "Where did you get it?"—he said, "From Dr. Stewart's"—I took him round to Dr. Stewart's, and I said to Dr. Stewart, in Smart's presence, "Have you seen my carter come in here?"—he said, "I have not, I have been sitting at the desk this last half hour, and no one has come in at all"—Smart appeared confused, and I said to him, "This satis-faction is not sufficient,"I took him to the station, and he was detained, and the inspector sent a policeman to make inquiries—I examined the bag and found some pieces of white ragin it—I went to the house of Mr. Seymour,

who is a dealer in rags—some rags were shown to me there—I was able to identify two pieces as my property—one was a piece of dimity curtain, and the other was half a corded petticoat—I can swear to these, I had seen them amongst my own rags at my own place that morning—after that I went to Smart's lodging, which is at Perrin's house—I think it is called Myrtle-place—we saw Perrin—the sergeant asked her if a man lived there who worked for me—she said, "Yes"—he asked her what his name was?—she said, "Smart"—he said, "Have you got anything here belonging to him?"—she said, "No"—he said, "Are you sure of that?"—she said, "No"—we searched, and found some pans, which I identify as my property, with my mark on the bottom of them—I asked her where she got them from—she said she bought them at different shops—I said, "What shops? they are marked with my mark"—she said she did not know—I said, "They came from my shop"—she then said, "I will tell you all about it: Smart brought them in place of money for his board and lodging"—she said since Dec. he had not paid her any money—she said, "I will tell you all about it: here is some more in this box"—the box was then opened; it was a long trunk or box, like a clothes box, and in it was found this gilt tea service—these are things that have been in my place—they might have been sold—here is a dinner set—these things have at one time formed part of my stock—I will not undertake to say they have not been sold—here are six plates and other things—I can say the same with regard to them—here is a toy cup and saucer, which I can swear was in my place, and had never been sold—I had seen it in my place within two or three months—I missed it and spoke about it to all my men, and to Smart amongst the rest—here is a tea spoon, which I can swear was never sold; here is my mark on it—here is a square glass inkstand I can swear to—we sell these to Government, and supply cadets with them, no one else—when they came up I put them in a particular place—there were twenty-four of them, and I missed one of them—there were but twenty-three left—I had missed the one about a month before 10th April—here is a glass salt cellar, which I can identify—I find there is one of mine gone—with regard to this China tea service, I had not missed the teacups, but teapots and sugar basins I had missed—these pans are mine; I do not know when I missed them, we have five or six hundred at a time—I could not say how many rags I missed.

Cross-examined by MR. DENNEY. Q. Did you have any reference with Smart? A. No, I took him without reference, because I knew he had worked for the parish—I paid him 1l. a week—I did not form any suspicion of him at first—I had some suspicion of him for about three months, when I found things done up in different places, ready to take away—I think it was between 12 and 1 o'clock when I saw him at the door with the bag under his arm—he has not been in the habit of carrying a bag—he went out with goods in the pony cart—if any person came and bought a few things, and I had not another man, I would send him—when I asked him to go to the police station, he was very insolent at first—I said, "You must go"—he said, "Very well"—I knew where he lodged, a few doors from my back premises—I did not ask him if he bad any objection to his lodging being searched—I was not in the habit of entrusting him with goods for sale on commission—the back of my warehouse goes back into Myrtle-place—we unload vessels and bring up all our goods from the back—there is access to the premises from the back as well as the front—I have a number of men coming backwards and forwards—these are such articles as are not sold in Woolwich—there are not such articles as these there—I purchase them from

Staffordshire, Yorkshire, and other places—if I saw these articles in Staf-fordshire or Yorkshire I could not swear to them—there are not articles of this pattern sold in Powis-street—I know some of these have not been sold—I do not know that Smart's father is in a large way of business at Maid
stone—I heard his father say he was sorry he was his son, he had behaved very badly to him—I can tell you how I came by this dimity, when rags are bought they are put into a basket, and I opened the bundle of rags to see what was in it, and I looked particularly at this piece of dimity and this corded petticoat in it, and when we went to get the rags I said, "If they are mine you will find a piece of dimity and a corded petticoat in it"—this is the corded petticoat, and this is the dimity—I know these two pieces were in the bundle when I opened it that same morning—I cannot tell who I bought these rags of—I buy of anybody—we know the persons as our customers—we have bought of strangers—I do not keep any books of these things—we have removed goods for Mr. Serjeant—I should not think it likely that he would leave any rags behind—I have no mark on this inkstand, but they are ordered to this one pattern for the cadets—we supply them to one person only.

Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Is there any mark on the pans? A. Yes—they have been in my shop—I cannot say they have not been sold—I have supplied tea sets to a bazaar—these are common patterns—all the crockery was taken at Perrin's house.
MR. RIBTON. Q. Had Smart any authority to sell any goods of yours? A. Never—I strictly forbade him.

COURT. Q. What is the value of the whole of the property? A. I put them down at 3l. or 4l. altogether—I never sold any of these articles to Smart—my daughter and two men and a boy all serve in my shop.

MARY SEMON . I am the daughter of George Semon, a rag merchant, in Powis-street, Woolwich—Smart came to me on 10th April about 1 o'clock, with a bag of white rags with him—I gave him 5s. 11d. for 28lbs.—I laid them down by the side of the door of the shed by themselves—these are them—shortly afterwards the prosecutor and the policeman came, I showed them the rags and they were taken away.

Cross-examined by MR. DENNEY. Q. How do you recollect it was on the 10th of April? A. I went to the Court the same day—I had no other rags in the same place where these were—this is the bag they were brought in.

JOHN NEWELL . (policemen, R 59.) I went to Perrin's house when Smart was in custody—I put some questions to Perrin—she at first denied all knowledge of these articles, and then she said she would tell all, and she said Smart brought them there—I searched Smart at the station and found on him 8s. 10d. and a key of Mr. Andrews' street door, which I gave to Mr. Andrews.
THOMAS CHARLES ANDREWS . I received this key and tried it to my street door—it was the key of that door—we had missed it for six weeks.

Cross-examined by MR. DENNEY. Q. Did you give Smart the key to get in and out? A. No; I never did—I missed this key—it was a patent lock on the door—I spoke to the prisoner and the other men, they all said they knew nothing about it.

SMART—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Twelve Months.

PERRIN—
GUILTY .—
Confined Four Months.

561.
JOHN NASH
, stealing 10s. 6d.; the moneys of
James Munday, his master.
MR. LOGIE. conducted the Prosecution.

ALFRED STRIDE . I am Mr. Munday's cousin, and assist him in his busi
ness; he is a butcher, at Woolwich. On Saturday night, 5th April, the pri
soner was in Mr. Munday's service—he and I were in the shop, and Mr. Mun
day was outside—the scales are about two feet six inches from the till, and the prisoner was between them—there had not been any customers for a few minutes, but about 11 o'clock, Mr. Munday told the prisoner to weigh a piece of fat—I went to get it from a quarter of beef which hung up, and heard a jingle of silver in the till; I turned round, gave the prisoner the fat, he took it from me with his right hand, and I saw him drawing his left hand from the till, with silver in it; his fore finger was not clenched, as he had a bandage on the tip of it—I believe his hand came out of the till—I did not see him literally take it out—on Saturday evenings we take the till and put it near the scale quite open—I whistled, made a signal to Mr. Munday, and pointed to the prisoner's hand—whistling is a general custom of ours, but it had not been agreed upon—Mr. Munday came in, and as he came in the prisoner took out his handkerchief, wiped his nose, or pretended to do so, and as he returned his handkerchief to his pocket, I heard the jingle of silver—he had put the fat on the scale—Mr. Munday said, "George, what have you put in your pocket?"—he said, "Nothing"—he drew his handkerchief out, and there was 14s. and 1d. or 2d.; the prisoner took a slight glance at the money, and then Mr. Munday asked him how much he had, and he said, "About 14s. 6d."—and then, I believe, he put it into his side pocket, from which he had taken it—the pocket was loose; it was a round frock—there was no occasion to go to the till; there was a customer in the shop, but no money was exchanged.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. Q. Do you know how much was in the till? A. No; there might be 20l., and there might be 100l.—I do not interfere with Mr. Munday's business sufficient to know—the prisoner has been there two or three months—I have been there all the time he has been there—there has been no quarrel between us—he has used a great deal of abusive language against me, but never in my presence—I thought it was a boyish action and let it pass; it is about six weeks ago—perhaps he wanted to shut up the shop of an evening, and I wanted to go elsewhere; it was not my duty to do so—I am not paid, I only go to oblige Mr. Munday—I work at the Arsenal, but not as a butcher; I shall not answer you in what way, it is not requisite.
COURT. Q. Tell it? A. Well, Sir, if you have a wish to know, I will tell you; sometimes I assist an engineer there.

MR. RIBTON. Q. What else? A. I think that is sufficient—I shall decline your question—I will not answer—there was not much meat on the counter—the prisoner was to put the piece of fat into the scale to make weight—I did not tell him to move the piece of fat—he was weighing a piece of fat for a customer in the shop—I am confident there was a customer, because Mr. Munday passed the meat in to be weighed—I do not recollect whether I gave the customer any change; I put the money into the till—Mr. Munday went to look for an officer, and the prisoner went across to a public house—while the prisoner and Mr. Munday were talking, the customer paid me—I made no entry of the weight of the beef in any book—I sleep in Union-street, Woolwich—I have done work and been paid for it up to Saturday at dinner time—I was working for Government last Saturday—I do not consider that I am bound to answer when I last received money from anybody for work—I received money from Govern
ment last Thursday or Friday—the prisoner's hand was about two inches

from the till, which was on his left hand, and the scale on his right—he had his face to me; I saw him attempt it once before the same evening, which caused my suspicion—I had had no previous arrangement with Mr. Munday.

JAMES MUNDAY . I am a butcher of Eyre-street, Woolwich—the prisoner was in my employ—on the evening of 5th April, there was but little meat, and there was not the slightest obstacle to my seeing to the scale where the prisoner was weighing a piece of meat for a woman—Stride was inside the shop—I saw him hand a piece of fat to the prisoner—he then whistled and pointed to the prisoner's left hand and I saw some money in it—he pre
tended to wipe his nose and dropped the money into his pocket—I then heard the chinking of silver—he put his hand back and I said, "George, what have you put in your pocket?"—he said, "Nothing, you may search me"—I went in, and he took out four half crowns and four shillings and twopence before I asked him how much he had—I said, "How came you by that?"—he said, "It is what I have saved out of my wages"—I said, "How can that be, when you only have a crown a-week?"—he said, "I have saved it"—I boarded and lodged him—he said, "I went over to Mr. Fry's, had a quartern of gin, changed half a crown and he gave me 2s. 2d. out"—the silver I saw in his hand appeared to be two shillings and a half crown by the gaslight—there are three compartments in the till; there was 9l. or 10l. on the silver side—I went for a policeman and gave him in charge—he had been in my service seven or eight weeks.

Cross-examined. Q. What light was there? A. Five or six gas lights flaring in different parts of the shop—the woman paid for the beef but not to the prisoner—it was one pound and a little more; I handed it in, the prisoner weighed it, and my wife, who came in, received the money—I am a cousin of the last witness—there was a bit of rag on one of the prisoner's fingers; his hand was slightly open—I believe the prisoner had received money that night, but he was not instructed to do so—I had told Stride to give a signal, and I believe I said a whistle—this was on Saturday—I appeared before the Magistrate on the Monday—I was not talking to Stride about it on Sunday.
MR. LOGIE. Q. Did the prisoner say anything to you about having received any of that money from customers? A. No.

WILLIAM BUTCHER . (policeman, R 85). I took the prisoner—I told him the charge—he said that the money he had was what his father had given him as pocket-money, and some which he had saved up—there were four half-crowns and six shillings, and in his blue pocket, two shillings and some halfpence.

COURT. to JAMES MUNDAY. Q. Where was the money? A. In his breast pocket; butchers do not usually use that pocket for money—it is only a slop pocket for a handkerchief; it was not a coat—it was a slop—I do not know whether he had a breeches pocket as he scarcely ever had his slop off.
WILLIAM BUTCHER . re-examined. I found 14s. in his trousers pocket, and 2s. and 2d. in his slop pocket.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

div0.p: SURREY CASES.

div1.p:
562.
HENRY WILMOT
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Clare, and stealing 1 tea-caddy, and other goods, value 3l., of
John Clare.
MR. BALLANTINE. conducted the Prosecution.

LYDIA CLARE . I am the wife of John Clare, of No. 49, Commercial-road, Lambeth. On the morning of 27th April, about a quarter past 3 o'clock, I was awoke by a person named Jenkinson—I ran down stairs and found my parlour window open—I found that two dresses and a coat had been removed from behind the door to the centre table, and the tea-caddy and tea-pot from the sideboard, where they had been when I went to bed about a quarter past 10 o'clock the night before—I had fastened the window the night before, but had not put the shutters up—my husband and I occupy the back and front parlours—we were the last up in those room—we had lodgers in the house—we looked up the parlours, and took the keys with us stairs—when I came down in the morning I found the doors still locked as I had left them—the parlour doors open into the pas
sage—nobody else in the house has a key of those doors.

Prisoner. When I was taken she said she could not speak to the fastening of the window from the Sunday previous. Witness. I said I had not had it open since the Sunday; but I saw that it was quite secure when we went to bed on the night of the robbery—I did not fasten it, I saw that it was fast—I did not put up the shutters, because it darkens the room so.

JANE JENKINSON . I am the wife of Thomas Jenkinson, of Lett's Wharf, Commercial-road, Lambeth. On the morning of 27th April, about half past 3 o'clock, I got out of bed and looked out of window, and saw a man and woman at the corner of Cottage-place—I saw the man open Mr. Clare's window, and get into the room—we live opposite them—I do not know what became of the woman, she did not go in—I went down stairs, and made an alarm to my husband, who is watchman in Mr. Lett's timber yard, and then went with him over to Mr. Clare's—I threw up the window, which the man had closed again after getting in, and he jumped out of the window, and knocked me down backwards—the prisoner is the man, I am certain of him—he did not strike me, he knocked me down by jumping out to make his escape—my husband ran after him, calling "Stop thief!" but he could not catch him.
Prisoner. Q. How can you swear to me? A. I really cannot tell, but I can swear that you are the man by your appearance.
COURT. Q. What sort of light was there? A. Very good—we are between gaslights—it was just getting daybreak.

THOMAS JENKINSON . I am the husband of the last witness. My wife came down to me soon after 3 o'clock on the morning in question, and gave me information, in consequence of which I went with her over to Mr. Clare's—I saw the prisoner jump out of the window, I have not the least doubt he is the person—I followed him, but did not catch him—I called "Stop thief!"—he ran along Cornwall-road, across Stamford-street, and down Cornwall-road again, and then I lost sight of him—I did not see him stopped.
THOMAS GARFORTH . (policeman, L) About half past 3 o'clock, on the morning of 27th April, I was on duty in the Cornwall-road, and saw the

prisoner running from the direction of Stamford-street down the Cornwall-road—he stopped a few paces before I got to him, and I took him into custody—he had no shoes on—I asked him what he was running for—he said he had been upset by some men in Stamford-street—I asked him where his shoes were—he said he had been without any for two days—I took to him to the Commercial-road, and showed him to the two witnesses, and they recognized him at once—I searched him, and found some lucifer matches in his waistcoat pocket.

Prisoner's Defence. I left my lodging on the Thursday night previous to the robbery; I had no shoes, having sold them on the Wednesday; I was walking the streets all night, on account of a few words I had with my sister on the Thursday night; going along Stamford-street a nightman came up to me, took hold of me, and began to use me roughly, and when he let go of me, I went in one direction, and he in another;. as I stood at the corner of the street, the policeman came running along; he stood in the road for about three minutes, looking up the road, hearing the cry of "Step thief!"when he saw me, and said I must go with him; he took me back, and when about twenty or thirty yards from the prosecutor's house, they cried out, "Bring him along, that is the man,"and they would have said the same of any person.
LYDIA CLARE . re-examined. The window was fastened with a hasp, the usual fastening—it was not broken—a knife was found by which it might have been opened, by putting it in between the sashes.

THOMAS GARFORTH . re-examined. A knife was found, about an hour after he was taken, in a court close by; by putting that knife between the sashes, so as to push back the catch, the window might have been opened.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Twelve Months.

563.
MARGARET MINTON
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.
MESSRS. LAWRENCE. and POLAND. conducted the Prosecution.

BENJAMIN CARTLEDGE . I am a fishmonger in the Borough. On 28th March the prisoner came to my shop, between 8 and 9 o'clock at night—she purchased a piece of fish, which came to 7d. or 8d.—she gave me a 5s. piece—I gave it to my wife, and the change was given to the prisoner, and she left—on the Monday following my wife gave me a crown piece—I gave it to some one to try—I saw it tried, and it was returned to me as bad—I gave that crown back to my wife—while the person tried it I did not lose sight of it.

ANN CARTLEDGE . On the evening of 28th March my husband gave me a crown. The prisoner was at the door—I gave her part of the change—I put the crown into a cash box—it was locked up—there was no other crown there—I took it out on the following Monday, and showed it to my hus
band—he returned it to me, and I found it was bad—I locked it up again, and afterwards gave it to the constable—there was no other crown in the box when I took it out.

Prisoner. When you saw me you pointed to another woman. Witness. There were three women there—the first person I set my eyes on was a woman who had passed a bad shilling to me—I said, "That is the woman that passed the shilling"—the gaoler took me out, and I said, "That was not the woman that passed the crown"—he took me in again, and I pointed out the prisoner as the woman that passed the crown—I had not observed the prisoner at first—I am sure she is the person who passed the crown.

CHARLES EVE . I am a fishmonger, and live in Great Suffolk-street. On 31st March, the prisoner came about a quarter after 10 o'clock in the evening—she purchased a small haddock which came to 5d.—she tendered me a crown—I gave it to my wife to get change of my next neighbour—it was brought back to me in two or three minutes as bad—the prisoner said she could not account for it—she could not give any address—I gave her into custody.

ELIZABETH EVE . I am the wife of the last witness. My husband gave me a crown, and I saw the prisoner in the shop—I went to the next door neigh
bour to get change—he tried it in a trier; it bent, and I brought it back, and gave it to my husband—it was given to the policeman.
PATRICK AHERN . The prisoner was given into my custody at Mr. Eve's shop—Mrs. Eve gave me this crown—I afterwards received this other crown from Mr. Partridge.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint. These are both bad, and from the same mould.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Nine Months.

564.
ANNIE BROWN and
JOHN EDWARDS were indicted for
a like offence.
MESSRS. LAWRENCE. and POLAND. conducted the Prosecution.

JOHN EMPSON . My brother keeps the Three Compasses, in Lower Marsh, Lambeth, and I assist him. On 30th April I was there—the prisoner Brown came in for a glass of porter—she put down a bad sixpence—I told her it was bad, and she said that I must take the porter back, as she had no more money—she said that she got it in change in Westminster-road—I broke it in two pieces, returned it to her, and she left—I followed her; she went into Westminster-road, under the railway arch—she stood there a short time, and Edwards joined her—they stood close to each other for some time—Edwards then left her—he returned in about ten minutes, and joined her again, and, after having stood some time, they both proceeded down West-minster-road, till they got within a short space of the Rodney—Brown went in there—I went into the other box, and heard Brown call for a glass of porter—I cautioned the person about her—I had before seen a constable, and told him.

CHARLES JACKSON . I am barman at the Rodney public house, near the Bridge Railway, Lambeth. On 30th April Brown came in, about 3 o'clock in the afternoon—she asked for a glass of porter, and gave me in payment a sixpence—the last witness came in, and made a motion to my young master, and I broke the sixpence with my teeth, and told Brown it was bad—she said she did not know it—I jumped over the counter, and detained her till a constable came, and gave the sixpence to him—he brought Edwards into the bar, and took both the prisoners to the station.

JOHN NEWMAN . (policeman, L 79.) On 30th of April, I was on duty in the afternoon in Westminster-road—Empson spoke to me and pointed out the two prisoners who were under the railway arch—I watched them, and saw Brown go into the Rodney, Empson followed her in—he came out again, and I went and took Edwards who was about thirty yards on the other side of the Rodney—I said to him, "Come along with me"—he said, "What for?"—I said, "You shall see presently," and I took him into the Rodney—Brown was there, and she was given into my charge by the barman for passing a bad sixpence—the sixpence was given to me—I said to Edwards, "You are charged with being connected with this female in passing bad money"—he said, that he knew nothing of it, and he did not

know the woman at all, only by living in the same house—I took both the prisoners to the station, and on the way Brown put her hand into her pocket and took it out again—I said, "What have you got in your hand?"—she said, "Nothing"—I opened her hand and took out this bad sixpence—she said, "That is all I have got, don't lock me up"—I searched Edwards at the station, I found on him 5 1/2 d., and on Brown, a good sixpence, and 1d. in copper—they gave their address, No, 2, Kent-street, Borough—I found that they lived there as man and wife.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are both bad.
(Edwards' statement before the Magistrate was here read as follows:—"I gave her the sixpence—she did not know they were bad.")

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 29.
Judgment Respited.

EDWARDS—
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Confined Nine Months.

565.
ELIZABETH ANN CARTER was indicted
for a like offence.
MESSRS. LAWRENCE and POLAND. conducted the Prosecution.

MARY GRAHAM . My husband keeps an eating house at No. 27, Stangate-street. On Saturday, 12th April, I was there—the prisoner came at near 10 o'clock at night—she asked for a quarter of a pound of pork and a 1d. worth of potatoes—they came to 4 1/2 d.—she laid down a 5s. piece—my little boy said, "Mother, I will go for change"—he went over the way to Mr. Broadhurst and brought the change back—I gave it to her, and she left—soon after Mr. Broadhurst came and said the crown was bad—on Saturday, 3rd May, the pri
soner came again about the same time in the evening—I was in the parlour—I heard her talking to my husband—I recognised her voice, and went into the shop—I said to her, "You are the same woman that was here this night three weeks"—she said, "I think you are mistaken, ma'am."

GEORGE ALFRED GRAHAM . I am eight years old. On Saturday evening, 12th April, I saw the prisoner in my mother's shop—I was sent for change to Mr. Broadhurst—I got it, and gave it to my mother—on Saturday, 3rd May, about 10 o'clock in the evening, the prisoner came for a quarter of a pound of roast pork and 1d. worth of potatoes—she asked my father for them, and put down a 5s. piece, which was given to my mother—I was in the shop when she came in, and heard my mother say something about her having been there before, and then I saw she was the same person.

HENRY BROADHURST . I keep the Crown public house at Stangate. On Saturday night, 12th April, this little boy came with a crown—I gave him change, and after he was gone I found the crown piece was bad—I put it away in a drawer by itself—on Saturday, 3rd May, Mrs. Graham came to tell me the woman was there—I went, and found the prisoner in the shop—I fetched a constable—I gave him the crown which I had received on 12th April.

GEORGE GRAHAM . I am the husband of the first witness. On Saturday, 12th April, I saw the prisoner in my shop, about 10 o'clock—I was having my supper in the back parlour—my wife asked me if I had change—I came through the shop during the time that my little boy went for change—on Saturday, 3rd May, I saw the prisoner in my shop a little before 10 o'clock—I recognised her the moment she came in, but did not speak to her—she came in just at a busy time, as she had done before—I served one or two persons, and took particular notice of the prisoner—she then asked for two ounces of pork, and a 1d. worth of potatoes—she put down a 5s. piece—I said, "I think you are the woman that paid me a visit this day three weeks"—I put the 5s. piece in the trier, and it was bad—my wife came in, and
said, "You are the woman"—my wife went to Mr. Broadhuret and he gave the prisoner into custody—I gave the crown piece to the constable.
Prisoner. Q. Did you not say that the first time I Had a black eye? A. No; I said you had paint on your eye; it was not a black eye.

THOMAS NORMAN . (policeman, L 195). The prisoner was given into my custody on 3rd May—Mr. Graham gave me a crown, and Mr. Broadhurst gave me another—the prisoner had 2d. in her hand—I asked where she lived, she said she lived anywhere, she had no fixed residence.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These are both bad.

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Nine Months.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, JUNE. 16, 1856.
